Author: Ahmad ibn Ishaq (Abu Ya'qub) ibn Ja'far ibn Wahb ibn Wadih al-Ya'qubi (Died after 292 AH)




[Book pagination matches the printed version]

Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub Ishaq ibn Ja'far ibn Wahb ibn Wadih, the famous Isfahani writer and chronicler known as Al-Ya'qubi, and as Ibn Wadih. He was a researcher in history and news of countries in the second Abbasid era. It has been said of him that he can be considered a geographical teacher for Muslims, and it is said that many geographers following his era, such as Ibn Rustah, Ibn al-Faqih, al-Masudi, al-Istakhri, Ibn Hawqal, al-Maqdisi, and others considered him their teacher. His grandfather Wadih was one of the Mawali (clients) of al-Mansur al-Dawaniqi, the Abbasid Caliph, and Salih ibn Mansur; hence his family was famously known as al-Abbasi. His grandfather and father were government officials, but it is not known whether he had a government position or not, although this can be assumed from his frequent travels. Al-Ya'qubi was born in Baghdad and lived there, then emigrated to the land of Persia (Fars) and prolonged his stay in the land of Armenia, being there in the year 260 AH. He also entered India and the Arab countries, then the Levant (Al-Sham), then the Maghreb to Al-Andalus. In Egypt and the Maghreb, he enjoyed the attention of the Tulunid state. His date of birth is unknown, but his death appears to have been in the year 284 AH.

His Works:
He has several compositions, including: A book on the conquests and achievements of Tahir ibn al-Hasan, Geography of the Byzantine Empire, History of the Conquests of Africa, News of Past Nations, The Roads and Kingdoms (Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik), Kings of the Romans, The Conformity of People to Their Time, History of Al-Ya'qubi, and Al-Buldan (The Countries).

Introduction

In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Among the most enjoyable books to read and benefit from are those that recount the history of countries, cities and their origins, reasons for their naming, and the customs and traditions of their people, especially since many of them still exist to our present day. The book "Al-Buldan" (The Countries) by the historian and traveler Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, famous as Al-Ya'qubi, is very rich in its broad horizons and historical outlook on the reasons for the emergence and naming of countries, cities, nations, and their history. It is worth mentioning that Al-Ya'qubi in this book mentions his observations in those countries and cities, and also mentions his questioning of their inhabitants about certain matters therein. Then he presents his opinion on what he heard from them, whether it was logical and convincing or mere myth circulated by the people of that region. In the course of his speech, he comments on that, pointing out the distance of the narration of the people of that time from logic and reason. He mentioned who conquered the lands among the Caliphs and Emirs and the amount of their land tax (Kharaj), leaving no small or large detail he came across without counting it in the book. Thus, his compilation "Kitab Al-Buldan" became the oldest geographical source, and the most trustworthy due to the effort, trouble, care, and good performance he endured in its composition. However, whatever the case may be, "Kitab Al-Buldan" came as an enjoyable historical and geographical book at the hands of a knowledgeable traveler in journeys and news of past nations.

Muhammad Amin Al-Dinnawi

Biography of the Author (1)
He is Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub Ishaq ibn Ja'far ibn Wahb ibn Wadih, the Isfahani Writer and Chronicler famous as Al-Ya'qubi, and as Ibn Wadih. He used to be called: Mawla (Client) of Banu al-Abbas, and Mawla of Banu Hashim, because his grandfather was one of the clients of al-Mansur al-Dawaniqi, the Abbasid Caliph. He was a researcher in history and news of countries. He gave exploration its due right in his travels in the lands, east and west. He entered the land of Persia and prolonged his stay in the land of Armenia, being there in the year 260 [AH]. He also entered India and the Arab countries, then the Levant, then the Maghreb to Al-Andalus. He immersed himself deeply in research, so he began questioning the people of the regions about them and about themselves, their customs, sects, governments, and the distances between lands. If he trusted their transmission, he recorded it in his book. He mentioned who conquered the lands among the Caliphs and Emirs and the amount of their land tax, leaving no small or large detail he came across without counting it in the book. Thus, his compilation "Kitab Al-Buldan" became the oldest geographical source, and the most trustworthy due to the effort, trouble, care, and good performance he endured in its composition. His prominence was in the third century because he was alive in the year 292 AH; on the night of Eid al-Fitr of that year, he remembered what the Banu Tulun used to enjoy on such a night of luxurious living, ample comfort, and abundant wealth, and he elegized them with verses beginning with: [Al-Kamil meter]
If you ask about the majesty of their kingdom ... Then pasture and stop by the grazing grounds of the square.
Therefore, what is in Mu'jam al-Udaba' (Dictionary of Writers) from Abu Umar Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Ya'qub al-Misri in his history that Al-Ya'qubi died in the year 284 [AH] is hardly correct, nor what Al-Zirikli mentioned in

Al-A'lam that his death was in the year 278 [AH]. It seems he followed Jurji Zaydan who started his biography with this date, but he says during it in Tarikh Adab al-Lughah al-Arabiyah (History of Arabic Literature) (1): "But it is understood from the context of his books that he died after the year 278 [AH]." The subject of the biography is a contemporary of Abu Hanifa al-Dinawari (2), who died in the year 282 [AH]; just as Sa'id the Physician (3) accompanied him, and his grandson Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Khalil al-Tamimi al-Maqdisi, son of the mentioned Sa'id, narrates in his book "Jayb al-Arus wa Rayhan al-Nufus" from Al-Ya'qubi via his father Ahmad and his grandfather Khalil.

His Works:
Yaqut al-Hamawi (4) mentioned in Mu'jam al-Udaba' among the works of the subject of this biography the Great History which

was published by the orientalist Houtsma in Leiden in the year 1883 [AD], in two volumes. The First: "On Ancient History in general from Adam and what followed to the appearance of Islam," including the news of the Israelites, Syrians, Indians, Greeks, Romans, Persians, Nubians, Beja, Zanj, Himyarites, Ghassanids, and Lakhmids (Munadhira). And the Second: "On the History of Islam, ending in the time of Al-Mu'tamid Ala Allah, the fifteenth of the Abbasid Caliphs," meaning to the year 259 [AH]. He arranged it according to the Caliphs. Among the features distinguishing it from other general histories, besides its antiquity, is that its author brings forth the core of history and investigates true issues, which only a characteristic historian commits to. Thus, he dictates to you the facts and correct events as if you witnessed them yourself and saw them with your own eyes, with smooth expression and an attractive style. Also among his works is "Kitab Al-Buldan" in geography, which is this book we present to the honorable readers. It was first printed in Leiden in the year 1861 [AD] under the care of the orientalist "Juynboll", and was also printed within the Geographical Library series in which eight volumes of Arabic geographical books were printed under the care of the orientalist "de Goeje". We have informed you of the importance of the book, its author's effort with it, and the extent of trust in it. Also among his works is a small book on "News of Past Nations", and a book "The Conformity of People to Their Time". These four books are the ones mentioned by Yaqut al-Hamawi in Al-Mu'jam. It appears from the end of the printed copy of "Kitab Al-Buldan" that he has another book he named the book of "Al-Mamalik wa al-Masalik" (The Kingdoms and Routes). The subject of the biography was a poet, and his prominence was before Al-Tabari and Al-Masudi. Among his exquisite poetry is his description of Samarkand (1): [Al-Munsarih meter]

Samarkand has risen above being called ... The adornment of Khorasan, the garden of districts.
Are not its towers suspended ... Such that they cannot be clearly seen by sight?
And below its towers are its trenches ... Deep, unassailable from any gap.
As if it is, while in the middle of its wall ... Surrounded by shadows and trees.
So a full moon, and its rivers are the Galaxy, and the ... Fortresses are like shining stars.

In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

[Sermon of the Book]
Praise be to Allah who opened His Book with praise, and made praise a recompense for His blessings, and the last prayer of the people of His Paradise. Creator of the high heavens and the low earths, and what is between them and what is under the soil. Knower of what He created before its existence, and Manager of what He originated without a precedent from other than Him. He encompassed everything in knowledge and counted it in number. To Him belongs the dominion, authority, and might, and He is over all things competent. And may Allah bless Muhammad the Prophet and his family and grant them peace.

Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: I was concerned in the prime of my youth, and at the changing of my years, and the sharpness of my mind, with the science of news of countries, and the distance between each country and another, because I traveled young in age, my travels were continuous, and my alienation lasted long. So whenever I met a man from those countries, I asked him about his homeland and region. If he mentioned to me the location of his abode and the place of his settlement, I asked him about that country of his regarding... its fertility (1), what is it? And its crops, what are they? And its inhabitants, who are they, Arabs or non-Arabs? ... the drink of its people, until I ask about their clothing ... and their religions and sects, and those dominant over it and the Minra (2) ... the distance of that country, and what countries are close to it... and the riding camels. Then I recorded everything informed to me by one whom I trust in his truthfulness, and I sought verification by questioning group after group, until I asked many people, and a world of people during the Hajj season and other than the season, from the people of the East and the West. I wrote down their news, narrated their hadiths, and mentioned who conquered country by country, and garrisoned region by region (3) among the Caliphs and Emirs, and the amount of its land tax and what rises from its wealth. I continued writing these news and composing this book for a long time, attributing every report to its country, and everything I hear from trustworthy people of the regions to what knowledge I had previously acquired.

And I knew that the created being does not encompass the limit, nor does the human reach the end. There is no law that must be complete, nor religion that is perfect except by encompassing it. Scholars of the science of religion, which is Fiqh (Jurisprudence), may say: Summary of the book of so-and-so the jurist. And scholars of literature in books of literature such as language, grammar, maghazi (expeditions), news, and biographies say: Summary of such-and-such book. So we made this book a summary of the news of countries. If anyone comes across news of a country from what we mentioned that we did not include in this book of ours, [know that] we did not intend to encompass everything. The wise man has said: My seeking of knowledge is not out of greed to reach its furthest extent, nor to seize its end, but to know what cannot be ignored, and what it is unbecoming for a rational person to contradict. I have mentioned the names of the regions (Amsar), the districts (Ajnad), the provinces (Kuwar), and what is in every region of cities, territories, and Tassujs (sub-districts) (1), and who inhabits it, dominates it, and leads in it from Arab tribes and non-Arab races, and the distance between country and country, and region and region, and who conquered it from the leaders of the armies of Islam, and the date of that in its year and times, and the amount of its land tax, its plains, mountains, land, sea, its air in the intensity of its heat and cold, its waters, and its drink.

Baghdad
I began with Iraq (1) because it is the center of the world and the navel of the earth. I mentioned Baghdad (2) because it is the center of Iraq, and the greatest city, which has no peer in the easts of the earth and its wests in capacity, size, urbanization, abundance of water, health, and air. And because it was inhabited by varieties of people, and people of regions and provinces (3), [and] (4) people moved to it from all distant and near countries. All people of the horizons preferred it over their homelands. There are no people of a country but they have a quarter, a trading place, and a business therein. Thus, gathered in it is what is not in any city in the world.

Then flow on its sides the two greatest rivers, the Tigris (1) and the Euphrates (2), so trades and provisions (3) come to it by land and sea with the easiest effort, until every merchandise carried from the East and the West, from the land of Islam and other than the land of Islam, is completed in it. For indeed, things are carried to it from India (4), Sindh (5), China (6), Tibet (7),
the Turks (1), the Daylam (2), the Khazars (3), Abyssinia (4), and other countries, until there are in it from

the trades of the countries more than what is in those countries from which the trades originated. Moreover, it is more available and accessible, as if the goods of the earth were driven to it, the treasures of the world gathered in it, and the blessings of the world completed in it. With this, it is the city of Banu Hashim (1), the abode of their kingdom, and the seat of their authority. No one started it before them, and no kings inhabited it other than them. Because my ancestors were the ones establishing it, and one of them took charge of its affair, and it has the famous name and widespread mention. Then it is the center of the world, because, according to what the calculation agreed upon and what the books of the ancient wise men contained, it is in the fourth clime, which is the middle clime where the air is moderate in all times and seasons. The heat in it is intense in the days of summer, and the cold is intense in the days of winter. The two seasons, autumn and spring, are moderate in their times. The entry of autumn into winter is with non-disparate air, and the entry of spring into summer is with non-disparate air. Likewise, every season transitions from air to air, and from time to time. Therefore, the air moderated, the stay became pleasant (2), the water became sweet, the trees thrived, the fruits became good, the crops became fertile, the goods increased, and the source of its spring became near (3). Due to the moderation of the air, the goodness of the soil, and the sweetness of the water, the characters of its people improved, their faces became radiant, and their minds opened up until they surpassed people in knowledge, understanding, literature, observation, discrimination, trades, industries, earnings, skill (4) in every debate, mastery of every profession, and perfection of every craft. There is no scholar more knowledgeable than their scholar, nor narrator more recounting than their narrators, nor debater more argumentative than their theologian, nor grammarian more eloquent (5) than their grammarian (6), nor reciter more correct than their reciter, nor physician more skilled than their physician, nor singer more proficient than their singer, nor artisan more delicate than their artisan, nor scribe more writing than their scribe, nor

speaker more articulate than their speaker (1), nor worshiper more devout than their worshiper, nor ascetic more pious than their ascetic, nor judge more jurisprudence than their judge, nor orator more eloquent than their orator, nor poet more poetic than their poet, nor jester more daring than their jester. Baghdad was not a city (2) in the preceding days, meaning the days of the Chosroes (3) and the Persians (4), but rather it was a village among the villages of Tassuj Baduraya (5). That is because the city of the Chosroes which they chose (6) from the cities of Iraq was Al-Mada'in (7), which is

seven farsakhs from Baghdad. In it is the Iwan (1) of Kisra Anushirvan (2). There was nothing in Baghdad except a monastery at the place where the Sarat (3) flows into the Tigris, which is called: Qarn al-Sarat. It is the monastery called the Old Monastery (Al-Dayr al-Atiq), standing in its state until this time, inhabited by the Catholicos (4), the head of the Nestorian Christians (5). Baghdad also did not exist in the days of the Arabs when Islam came, because the Arabs planned Basra and Kufa (6). Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas al-Zuhri (7) planned Kufa in the year seventeen, while he was the governor for Umar ibn al-Khattab (8).
Utbah ibn Ghazwan al-Mazini (1) - Mazin of Qays - planned Basra in the year seventeen, while he was at that time the governor for Umar ibn al-Khattab.

The Arabs planned their quarters in these two cities, except that all the people, their notables, dignitaries, and wealthy merchants (1) moved to Baghdad. The Umayyads did not settle in Iraq because they were settlers in the Levant (Al-Sham). Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan (2) was the governor of the Levant for Umar ibn al-Khattab, then for Uthman ibn Affan (3) for twenty years. He used to reside in the city of

Damascus, and his family with him. When he overcame the matter and authority (1) came to him, he made his residence and abode Damascus, where his authority, supporters, and partisans were. Then the kings of Banu Umayyah after Mu'awiyah resided there because they grew up there knowing no other, and only its people inclined towards them. When the Caliphate passed to the cousins of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from the descendants of Al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib (2), they knew by their good discrimination, sound minds, and perfect opinions the excellence of Iraq, its majesty, vastness, and centrality to the world. And that it is not like the Levant with its pestilential air, narrow dwellings, rugged land, continuous plagues, and harsh people. Nor like Egypt with its variable air, abundant epidemics, which is merely between a humid putrid sea (3) with many bad vapors that generate diseases and spoil food, and the dry hard mountain (4) which due to its dryness, salinity, and corruption grows no greenery nor does a water spring burst from it. Nor like Africa (Ifriqiya) (5), distant from the peninsula of Islam and the Sacred House of Allah, with harsh people and many enemies.

Nor like Armenia, remote, cold, chilly (1), rugged, surrounded by enemies. Nor like the mountain districts (Kuwar al-Jabal), rugged, rough, snowy, the abode of the Kurds (2), harsh-hearted. Nor like the land of Khorasan, thrusting into the sunrise, surrounded on all sides by a rabid enemy and a fighting warrior. Nor like the Hijaz (3), miserable in livelihood, narrow in earning, whose people are fed from elsewhere. Allah, Mighty and Majestic, has informed us in His Book about His friend Abraham, peace be upon him, saying: {Our Lord, I have settled some of my descendants in an uncultivated valley} [Ibrahim: 37]. Nor like Tibet, where due to the corruption of its air and food, the colors of its people changed, their bodies became small, and their hair became curly. When they knew that it [Iraq/Baghdad] is the best of countries, they settled in it choosing it. Abu al-Abbas the Commander of the Faithful, who is Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib, settled in Kufa the first time, then moved to Al-Anbar (4). He built a city on the bank of the Euphrates and named it

Al-Hashimiyah (1). Abu al-Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, died before he could complete the city. When Abu Ja'far al-Mansur (2) assumed the Caliphate - and he is also Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib - he built a city between Kufa and Hira (3) and named it Al-Hashimiyah. He resided there for a period, until

he resolved to send his son Muhammad al-Mahdi (1) to fight the Slavs (Saqaliba) (2) in the year one hundred and forty. He arrived at Baghdad, stopped there and said: "What is the name of this place?" It was said to him: "Baghdad." He said: "By Allah, it is the city which my father Muhammad ibn Ali informed me I would build and inhabit, and my descendants would inhabit after me. Kings in the Jahiliyyah (Pre-Islamic period) and Islam neglected it until Allah's plan came to me and His decree regarding me, and the narrations prove true, and the signs and indications become clear. Otherwise, it is an island between the Tigris and the Euphrates; the Tigris is to its east and the Euphrates to its west, a watering place for the world. Everything that comes via the Tigris from Wasit (3), Basra, Ubulla (4), Ahwaz, Fars (5),

Oman (1), Yamama (2), Bahrain (3), and what connects to that, ascends to it and anchors at it. Likewise, what comes from Mosul (4), Diyar Rabi'a (5), Azerbaijan, and Armenia which is carried in ships on the Tigris.

And what comes from the lands of Mudar (Diyar Mudar), Raqqa (1), the Levant (Al-Sham) (2), the Frontier (Al-Thaghr) (3), Egypt, and the Maghreb (4) which is carried in ships on the Euphrates. In it, loads are put down and people settle. It is the thoroughfare for the people of the Mountains (Al-Jabal), Isfahan, and the districts of Khorasan. So praise be to Allah who stored it for me and made everyone who preceded me neglect it. By Allah, I will build it then inhabit it for the days of my life, and my descendants will inhabit it after me. Then it will surely be the most prosperous city on earth. Then I will build after it four cities, none of which will ever fall into ruin." So he built it, and it is Al-Rafiqah (5) but he did not name it [after himself?], and he built Malatya, Al-Massisa, and he built Al-Mansura (6) in Sindh. Then he sent to bring engineers and people knowledgeable in building, and science

of measuring (Dhar'), surveying, and division of lands, until he laid out the plan of his city known as the City of Abu Ja'far (1). He brought builders, laborers, and craftsmen from carpenters, blacksmiths, and diggers. When they gathered and were complete, he assigned them wages and established their pay. He wrote to every country to send anyone therein who understood anything of building, so one hundred thousand of various professions and industries attended him. A group of Sheikhs reported this, that Abu Ja'far al-Mansur did not begin building until one hundred thousand laborers and people of professions were complete for him. Then he laid it out in the month of Rabi' al-Awwal in the year one hundred and forty-one. He made it circular, and no round city (2) is known in all regions of the world other than it. He laid the foundation of the city at a time chosen by Nawbakht the Astronomer and Mashallah ibn Sariya. Before laying the foundation, huge bricks were molded. The full square brick was a cubit by a cubit, weighing two hundred Ratls, and the half brick was a cubit long and half a cubit wide, weighing one hundred Ratls. Wells were dug for water, and the canal was made which takes from the Karkhaba river (3), which is the river taking from the Euphrates. The canal was perfected and made to flow into the city for drinking, molding bricks, and wetting clay. He made four gates for the city: a gate he named the Kufa Gate, a gate he named the Basra Gate, a gate he named the Khorasan Gate, and a gate he named the Sham (Levant) Gate. Between each gate and the other is five thousand cubits by the Black Cubit (4) from outside the trench. On each gate are two great, majestic iron doors; a single door is not closed nor opened except by a group of men.

A horseman enters with a banner, and a lancer with a long lance, without tilting the banner or bending the lance. He made its wall with huge bricks the like of which had never been seen, according to the size and clay we described. He made the foundation of the wall ninety cubits by the Black [Cubit], then it tapers until it becomes twenty-five cubits at its top. Its height is sixty cubits with the battlements. Around the wall is a majestic great Fasīl (intermural space/low wall) (1); between the wall of the Sur (main wall) and the wall of the Fasīl is one hundred cubits by the Black [Cubit]. The Fasīl has great towers and round battlements on it. Outside the Fasīl, surrounding it, is a dyke (Musa'nah) (2) of baked brick (3) and lime (Saruj) (4), perfected, solid, and high. In the trench beyond the dyke, water flows from the canal that takes from the Karkhaba river. Behind the trench are great streets. He made four great vaulted vestibules (Dahaliz) (5) for the city gates, all vaulted. Around each vestibule is eighty cubits, all vaulted with baked brick and gypsum. When one enters from the vestibule on the Fasīl, he comes to a courtyard paved with stone, then a vestibule on the Great Wall with two majestic great iron doors; each door is not closed or opened except by a group of men. All four gates are like that. When he enters from the vestibule of the Great Wall, he walks in a courtyard to arches vaulted with baked brick and gypsum, containing Roman windows (6) from which sun and light enter, but rain does not enter. In them are the dwellings of the servants (Ghilman). For each of the four gates there are arches. On every gate of the city which is on the Great Wall is a great gilded vaulted dome. Around it are sitting places and elevated areas where one sits overlooking everything done therein. These domes are ascended via vaults built partly with gypsum and baked brick, and partly with huge mud bricks. They are made as arcades, some higher than others. The interior of the arcades is for the garrison and guards,

and on their backs is the ascent to the domes on the gates on beasts. On the ascent are doors that close. When one exits from the arches, he exits to a courtyard, then to a great vaulted vestibule vaulted with baked brick and gypsum, on which are two iron doors. He exits from the door to the Great Courtyard (Rahbah). It is likewise for the four arches, on a single pattern. In the middle of the Courtyard is the Palace whose gate is called the Golden Gate (Bab al-Dhahab). Beside the Palace is the Congregational Mosque (Masjid al-Jami'). Around the Palace there is no building, nor house, nor residence for anyone except a house on the Sham side for the guards, and a large portico (Saqifah) extended on columns built with baked brick and gypsum; in one part sits the Chief of Police (Sahib al-Shurta) and in the other the Chief of Guards (Sahib al-Haras). Today, people pray in it. Around the Courtyard, surrounding it, are the residences of al-Mansur's younger children and those of his servants close to his service, the Treasury (Bayt al-Mal), the Armory (Khizanat al-Silah), the Bureau of Correspondence (Diwan al-Rasa'il) (1), the Bureau of Land Tax (Diwan al-Kharaj) (2), the Bureau of the Seal (Diwan al-Khatam) (3), the Bureau of the Army (Diwan al-Jund) (4), the Bureau of Needs (Diwan al-Hawa'ij) (5), the Bureau of Retinue (Diwan al-Ahsham) (6), the Public Kitchen, and the Bureau of

Expenditures. Between the Arches (1) to the Arches are the alleys (Sikak) (2) and paths (Durub) known by his commanders, his clients (Mawali), and the inhabitants of each alley. From the Basra Gate to the Kufa Gate: The Police Alley, al-Haytham Alley, al-Mutbaq Alley - in it is the Great Prison called al-Mutbaq, of solid construction and sturdy wall - the Women's Alley, Sarjis Alley, al-Husayn Alley, Atiyyah Mujashi' Alley, al-Abbas Alley, Ghazwan Alley, Ibn Hanifa Alley, and the Narrow Alley. From the Basra Gate to the Khorasan Gate: The Guard's Alley, al-Nu'aymiyah Alley, Sulayman Alley, al-Rabi' Alley, Muhalhil Alley, Sheikh ibn 'Amira Alley, al-Marwarrudhiyah Alley, Wadih Alley, the Water Carriers' Alley, Ibn Bariha ibn Isa ibn al-Mansur Alley, Abu Ahmad Alley, and the Narrow Path. From the Kufa Gate to the Sham Gate: Al-Akki Alley, Abu Qurra Alley, Abduwayh Alley, al-Samayda' Alley, al-Ala' Alley, Nafi' Alley, Aslam Alley, and Manarah Alley. From the Sham Gate to the Khorasan Gate: The Muezzins' Alley, Darim Alley, Isra'il Alley, an alley known at this time as al-Qawariri - the name of its owner has escaped me -, al-Hakam ibn Yusuf Alley, Sama'ah Alley, Sa'id - client of Abu Ja'far - Alley, an alley known today as al-Ziyadi - the name of its owner has escaped me -, and Ghazwan Alley. These alleys are between the Arches, and the Arches are inside the city and inside the wall. In every alley of these alleys are the prominent commanders trusted to dwell with him, and his prominent clients and those needed for important matters. On each alley at both its ends are strong gates. No alley connects to the wall of the Courtyard where the Caliphate Palace is, because around the wall of the Courtyard is the road surrounding it. Those who engineered it were Abdullah ibn Muhriz, al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf (3), Imran ibn al-Waddah,

and Shihab ibn Kathir, in the presence of Nawbakht, Ibrahim ibn Muhammad al-Fazari (1), and al-Tabari, the astrologers and mathematicians. He divided the suburbs (Arbad) (2) into four quarters, and assigned a man from the engineers to oversee each quarter. He gave the masters of each quarter the amount of measurement allotted to the owner of each land grant (Qati'ah), and the amount of measurement for constructing markets in each suburb. He assigned the quarter from the Kufa Gate to the Basra Gate, and the Muhawwal Gate (3)

and Karkh (1) and all that connected to that to al-Musayyib ibn Zuhayr (2), al-Rabi' his client, and Imran ibn al-Waddah the engineer. The quarter from the Kufa Gate to the Sham Gate, and the street of the Anbar road to the limit of the suburb of Harb ibn Abdullah (3) [and] (4) Sulayman ibn Mujalid and Wadih his client, and Abdullah ibn Muhriz the engineer.

The quarter from the Sham Gate to the suburb of Harb and what connected to the suburb of Harb, and the street of the Sham Gate, and what connected to that to the bridge at the end of the Tigris to Harb ibn Abdullah and Ghazwan his client, and al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf the engineer. And from [the] Khorasan [Gate] to the bridge over the Tigris extending in the street along the Tigris to the Baghayyin (1), and the gate of Qatar ibn Hisham [ibn] (2) Amr al-Taghlibi and Amara ibn Hamza (3) and Shihab ibn Kathir the engineer. He signed to all the masters of the quarters what measurement falls to each man, and to those with him of his companions, and what he estimated for shops and markets in every suburb. He ordered them to widen the shops so that there would be in every suburb a comprehensive market gathering trades. And to make in every suburb alleys and thoroughfares, passing through and dead-end, such that the houses are balanced by them. And to name every path by the name of the commander residing in it, or the noble man who settles it, or the people of the country who inhabit it. He set the limit for them to make the width of the streets fifty cubits - by the Black [Cubit], and the paths sixteen cubits. And to build in all suburbs, markets, and paths sufficient mosques and baths for those in every district and quarter. He ordered them all to designate from the land grants of the commanders and the army a known measurement for merchants to build and inhabit, and for the common people, and people of the countries. The first of his family to be granted land outside the city was Abd al-Wahhab ibn Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn al-Abbas (4) opposite the Kufa Gate on the Lower Sarat (5) which takes from

the Euphrates. His suburb is known as Suwayqat (Little Market of) Abd al-Wahhab, and his palace there is ruined. It has reached me that the Suwayqa also is ruined. He granted land to al-Abbas ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib, the island between the two Sarats, so al-Abbas made it a garden and cultivated land. It is the famous Abbasiyah mentioned, whose yields do not cease in summer, nor winter, nor at any time. Al-Abbas requested for himself, when he made the island a garden, the land on the eastern side. At the end of the Abbasiyah, the two Sarats meet, and the Great Mill called the Mill of the Patrician (Raha al-Batriq) (2), which had one hundred

stones and yielded one hundred million dirhams every year. A patrician who came to him from the King of the Romans engineered it, so it was attributed to him. He granted land to the Sharawiyah, who are clients of Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn al-Abbas, below Suwayqat Abd al-Wahhab next to the Kufa Gate. They were doorkeepers, their chief was Hasan al-Sharawi. He granted land to al-Muhajir ibn Amr, head of the Bureau of Alms, in the courtyard facing the Kufa Gate. There is the Bureau of Alms, and opposite it is the land grant of Yasin, master of the noble camels (Naja'ib), and the Khan of the Naja'ib. Below the Khan of the Naja'ib is the stable of the clients. He granted land to al-Musayyib ibn Zuhayr al-Dabbi, the Chief of Police, to the right of the Kufa Gate for one entering the city next to the Basra Gate. There is the house of al-Musayyib and the Mosque of al-Musayyib with the tall minaret. He granted land to Azhar ibn Zuhayr, brother of al-Musayyib, behind the land grant of al-Musayyib facing the Qibla (south), and it is on the Sarat. There is the house of Azhar and the garden of Azhar to this day. Connected to the land grant of al-Musayyib and his family is the land grant of Abu al-Anbar, client of al-Mansur, facing the Qibla. On the Sarat is the land grant of the Companions (Sahaba), and they were from all tribes of the Arabs: from Quraysh, Ansar, Rabi'a, and Yemen. There is the house of Ayyash al-Mantuf and others. Then the land grant of Yaqtin ibn Musa (1), one of the men of the state and leaders of the Call (Da'wa). Then we cross the Great Sarat in which

the two Sarats gather: the Upper Sarat and the Lower Sarat. On it is the bridge vaulted with gypsum and baked brick, solid and sturdy, called the Old Bridge (Al-Qantara al-Atiqa), because it was the first thing he built and excelled in its construction. You turn from the bridge to the right towards the Qibla to the land grant of Ishaq ibn Isa ibn Ali. His palaces and houses overlook the Great Sarat from the eastern side. The Great Road is between the houses and the Sarat. From the land grant of Isa ibn Ali (1) to the land grant of Abu al-Sari al-Shami, client of al-Mansur. Then the vaulted Arch on which is the gate known as the Muhawwal Gate. You proceed from it to the suburb of Hamid ibn Qahtaba al-Ta'i (2). Hamid's suburb overlooks the Upper Sarat. There is the house of Hamid and his companions and a group from the family of Qahtaba ibn Shabib (3). Then that connects to the land grant of the Farashin (Bed-makers/Attendants), known as the House of the Romans (Dar al-Rumiyyin), overlooking the Karkhaba river. Then you return to the Great Street, which is the street of the Muhawwal Gate. In it is a great market with varieties of trades. Then that connects to the Old Pool (Al-Hawd al-Atiq), and there are the residences of the Persians, companions of the Shah. Then the path continues to the place known as al-Kunasa. There are the tie-up places for the common people's beasts, and places for beast brokers. Then the old cemetery known as al-Kunasa extending to the river of Isa ibn Ali which takes from the Euphrates and the Tanners. Opposite the land grant of the Romans

on the Karkhaba river, over which is the bridge known as [the Bridge of] the Romans, is the house of Ka'yuba the Gardener, who planted palms in Baghdad. Then connected orchards planted by Ka'yuba al-Basri up to the place known as Baratha (1). Then we returned to the Old Bridge. Before you cross the bridge going east to the suburb of Abu al-Ward Kawthar ibn al-Yaman, treasurer of the Treasury (Bayt al-Mal), and a market containing all goods known as Suwayqat Abu al-Ward to the Karkh Gate. Behind the land grant of Abu al-Ward Kawthar ibn al-Yaman is the land grant of Habib ibn Raghban al-Himsi. There is the mosque of Ibn Raghban, and the mosque of the Anbaris, scribes of the Bureau of Land Tax. Before you cross to the Old Bridge, coming from the Kufa Gate in the Great Street, is the land grant of Salim, client of the Commander of the Faithful, head of the Bureau of Land Tax, and the land grant of Ayyub ibn Isa al-Sharawi. Then the land grant of Rabawa al-Kirmani and his companions. You end at the City Gate known as the Basra Gate, which overlooks the Sarat and the Tigris. Opposite it is the New Bridge, because it is the last of the bridges built. On it is a large market with all trades extending continuously. Then the suburb of Waddah, client of the Commander of the Faithful, known as Qasr Waddah, keeper of the Armory. There are markets there, and most of those in it at this time are the Paper-sellers (Warraqun), owners of books; for there are more than one hundred shops for Paper-sellers. Then to the land grant of Amr ibn Sim'an al-Harrani, and there is the Arch of al-Harrani (2). Then al-Sharqiyah (The Eastern [Quarter])

It was named al-Sharqiyah (1) because it was planned as a city for al-Mahdi before he resolved that al-Mahdi's residence would be on the eastern side of the Tigris, so it was named al-Sharqiyah. In it is the Great Mosque, where Friday prayer used to be held, and it has a pulpit. It is the mosque where the judge of al-Sharqiyah sits. Then the pulpit was removed from it. You turn from al-Sharqiyah passing to the land grant of Ja'far ibn al-Mansur on the bank of the Tigris. In it is the house of Isa ibn Ja'far, and close to it is the house of Ja'far ibn Ja'far al-Mansur. Then you exit from these four roads we mentioned to the street of the Karkh Gate. Its beginning is at the Gate of the Slave-traders (Bab al-Nakkhasin). Then the markets extend on both sides of the street. You turn from the Karkh Gate to the right to the land grant of al-Rabi', client of the Commander of the Faithful, in which are the merchants of Khorasan, the cloth merchants (Bazzazun) (2), and varieties of what is carried from Khorasan of clothes, mixed with nothing else. There is the river that takes from Karkhaba on which are the merchants' houses, called the Chicken River (Nahr al-Dajaj) (3) because chickens were sold on it at that time. Behind the land grant of al-Rabi' (4) are the houses of merchants and mixed people from every country. Every path is known by its people and every alley by who inhabits it. Karkh is the Great Market extending from Qasr Waddah (5) to the Tuesday Market (Suq al-Thulatha') (6) [Note: Suq al-Thulatha is usually on the East side, text might mean something else or refer to a specific market in Karkh]

in length the amount of two farsakhs, and from the land grant of al-Rabi' to the Tigris in width the amount of a farsakh. For every merchant and trade there are known streets and rows in those streets, and shops and courtyards (2). People do not mix with other people, nor trade with trade, nor is a type sold with other than its type. Professionals of various industries do not mix with others. Every market is separate, and every people are isolated with their trades. Every people of a profession are secluded from other than their class. Between these suburbs we mentioned and the land grants we described are the houses of people from the Arabs, the army, the Dehghans (landed gentry) (3), the merchants, and other mixed people; the paths and alleys are attributed to them. This is one of the quarters of Baghdad, and it is the Great Quarter which al-Musayyib ibn Zuhayr, al-Rabi' client of the Commander of the Faithful, and Imran ibn al-Waddah the engineer managed. There is no quarter in Baghdad wider or grander than it. From the Kufa Gate to the Sham Gate is the suburb of Sulayman ibn Mujalid (4) because he managed this quarter, so it was attributed to him. In it is the land grant of Wadih, then the land grant of Amir ibn Isma'il al-Musli, then the suburb of al-Hasan ibn Qahtaba (5), and his houses and the houses of his family overlook the path known as al-Hasan. Then the suburb of

the Khwarazmians (1), companions of al-Harith ibn Raqqad al-Khwarazmi, and the land grant of al-Harith in the path. Then the land grant of ... client of the Commander of the Faithful, master of the Stirrup (Rikab). It is the house that went to Ishaq ibn Isa ibn al-Hashimi, then a scribe of Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir bought it, called Tahir ibn al-Harith. Then the suburb of al-Khalil ibn Hashim al-Bawardi. Then the suburb of al-Khattab ibn Nafi' al-Sahawi. Then the land grant of Hashim ibn Ma'ruf, which is in the Cages Path (Darb al-Aqfas). Then the land grant of al-Hasan ibn Ja'farat, which is in the Cages Path also, connected to the Bleachers' Path (Darb al-Qassarin). From the street of the Anbar road are land grants: the land grant of Wadih, client of the Commander of the Faithful, and his son. The path of Ayyub ibn al-Mughira al-Fazari in Kufa, and the path is known as the Kufans' Path. Then the land grant of Salama ibn Sim'an al-Bukhari and his companions, and the Bukharis' Mosque and the Green Minaret in it. Then the land grant of al-Lajlaj the physician. Then the land grant of Awf ibn Nizar al-Yamami and the Yamama Path leading to the house of Sulayman ibn Mujalid. The land grant of al-Fadl ibn Ja'waba al-Razi, which is the one that went to Dawud ibn Sulayman the scribe, scribe of Umm Ja'far, known as Dawud al-Nabati. Then al-Sib and the house of Hubayra ibn Amr. On al-Sib is the land grant of Salih al-Baladi in Sabah Path leading to Suwayqat Abd al-Wahhab. The land grant of Qabus ibn al-Samayda'. Opposite it is the land grant of Khalid ibn al-Walid (2) which went to Abu Salih Yahya ibn Abd al-Rahman the scribe, head of the Bureau of Land Tax in the days of al-Rashid (3), so it is known as the Houses of Abu Salih. Then the land grant of Shu'bah ibn Yazid al-Kabuli. Then the suburb of Al-Qass (The Priest)

client of al-Mansur, and the Priest's Garden known by him. Then the suburb of al-Haytham ibn Mu'awiyah (1) at the Char-suq (Crossroads market) of al-Haytham. There is a large continuous market, houses, paths, and alleys, all attributed to Char-suq al-Haytham. Then the land grant of the Marwarrudhis, family of Abu Khalid al-Anbari. Then Abu Yazid al-Shawawi, client of Muhammad ibn Ali (2), and his companions. Then the land grant of Musa ibn Ka'b al-Tamimi (3), who

headed al-Mansur's police. Then the land grant of Bishr ibn Maymun and his houses. Then the land grant of Sa'id ibn Da'laj al-Tamimi. Then the land grant of al-Shakhkhir and Zakariya ibn al-Shakhkhir. Then the suburb of Abu Ayyub Sulayman ibn Ayyub known as Abu Ayyub al-Khuzi al-Muryani (and Muryan is a village of a district of Ahwaz called Manadhir). Then the land grant of Raddad ibn Zadhan known as al-Raddadiya. Then al-Mamdudar [?]. Then the border of Harb's suburb, and below it al-Ramliya. This is the quarter managed by Sulayman ibn Mujalid, Wadih client of the Commander of the Faithful, and the engineer Imran ibn al-Waddah. The quarter from the Sham Gate: First is the land grant of al-Fadl ibn Sulayman al-Tusi. Beside it is the prison known as the Sham Gate Prison and the markets known as the Sham Market. It is a great market containing all trades and goods extending right and left, populous and bustling streets, paths, and courtyards. It extends in a great street with long paths; each path is attributed to people of a country who inhabit it on both its sides up to the suburb of Harb ibn Abdullah al-Balkhi. There is no suburb in Baghdad wider, larger, or having more paths and markets at present than it. Its people are the people of Balkh, Merv, Khuttal, Bukhara, Isfijab, Ishtakhanj, Kabul Shah (1), and Khwarazm (2). For every people of a country there is a commander

...and a chief. And the plot of Al-Hakam ibn Yusuf Al-Balkhi, the master of the spears (harpoons), who had been in charge of the police. And from the Syrian Gate [Bab Al-Sham] in the Grand Avenue extending to the bridge that is over the Tigris, there is a market on the right and on the left. Then a suburb known as Dar al-Raqiq [House of Slaves] (1), in which were Abu Ja'far's slaves who were sold from the horizons, and they were attached to Al-Rabi' his mawla. Then the suburb of the Kermanis and the commander Buzan ibn Khalid al-Kermani, then the plot of the Sogdians and the house of Kharqash the Sogdian, then the plot of Mahan the Samghanian and his companions, then the plot of the Marzban Abu Asad ibn Marzban the Faryabi and his companions and the owners of the pillars, then it ends at the bridge. This is the quarter that Harb ibn Abdullah, the mawla of the Commander of the Faithful, and the engineer Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf took charge of. And the quarter from the Khurasan Gate to the bridge over the Tigris and what is after that opposite it is Al-Khuld (2)...

...And in it were the stables and the place of review [military parade ground] (1) and a palace overlooking the Tigris that Abu Ja'far continued to inhabit. And Al-Mahdi was in it before he moved to his palace in Al-Rusafa (2) which is on the eastern side of the Tigris. So if the location of the bridge (3) is crossed, then [there is] the bridge, the council of the police, and a shipyard for the bridge. If you pass that, the first of the plots is the plot of Sulayman ibn Abi Ja'far on the Grand Avenue on the Tigris and in a lane known as Darb Sulayman. And next to the plot of Sulayman in the Grand Avenue is the plot of Salih ibn the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur, who is Salih the Poor, extending to the house of Najih, the mawla of Al-Mansur, which became [the property] of Abdullah ibn Tahir. And the end of Salih's plot is the plot of Abdul Malik ibn Yazid Al-Jurjani, known as Abu Awn, and his companions the Jurjanis, then the plot of Tamim Al-Badhghisi connected to the plot of Abu Awn, then the plot of Abbad the Farghani and his companions the Farghanis, then the plot of Isa ibn Najih known as Ibn Rawdah and the slave-boys of the chamberlainship, then the plot of the Africans, then the plot of Tammam the Daylami adjacent to the Bridge of the Straw-Sellers, and the plot...

...of Hanbal ibn Malik, then the plot of the Baghis, the companions of Hafs ibn Uthman, and the house of Hafs is the one that became [the property] of Ishaq ibn Ibrahim. Then the market on the Tigris at the harbor (1), then a plot for Ja'far ibn the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur which became [the property] of Umm Ja'far in the area of the Qatar Gate, rather it is known as the plot of Umm Ja'far (2). And what is towards the Qibla [South] is the plot of Murar Al-Ijli and the plot of Abdul Jabbar ibn Abdul Rahman Al-Azdi (3), and he used to be in charge of the police, then he [the Caliph] removed him and appointed him over Khurasan, but he rebelled there, so Al-Mahdi sent armies against him and fought him until he overcame him, so he carried him to Abu Ja'far who struck off his neck and crucified him. And in these suburbs and plots are things we did not mention because all the people built plots and other than plots and inherited [them]. I counted the lanes and streets, and they were six thousand lanes and streets. And I counted the mosques, and they were thirty thousand mosques excluding what was added after that. And I counted the bathhouses, and they were ten thousand bathhouses excluding what was added after that. And he drew the canal that takes from the Karkhaba River, which takes from the Euphrates, in solid arches from its bottom, reinforced with waterproof cement and baked brick from its top, arched with a firm arch, so it enters the city and penetrates most of the streets of the suburbs, flowing summer and winter. It was engineered in a way that water is not cut off from it at any time. And another canal from the Tigris following this example, and he named it Dujayl. And he drew for the people of Karkh and what is connected to it a river called the River of Chickens (Nahr al-Dajaj), and it was named River of Chickens only because the chicken sellers used to stand near it, and a river called the River of Tabaq (4) Ibn al-Samiyya, and they have the river...

...Isa the Great, which takes from the main body of the Euphrates. Great ships enter it coming from Raqqa [Syria], carrying flour and merchandise from Al-Sham [Levant] and Egypt [Egypt], arriving at a harbor upon which are markets and shops of merchants that do not cease at any time, for the water does not cease. And they have wells into which water enters from these canals, so they are fresh; all the people drank from them. These canals were only needed due to the greatness of the city and its vastness, otherwise, they are between the Tigris and the Euphrates from all sides; waters flow upon them until they planted palm trees that were brought from Basra [Iraq], so there became more in Baghdad than in Basra, Kufa [Iraq], and the Sawad (1). And they planted trees and they bore wonderful fruit, and orchards and gardens multiplied in the suburbs of Baghdad from every side due to the abundance of water and its goodness. And everything that is made in any country was made in it because the skilled people of industries moved to it from every country and came to it from every horizon and migrated to it from the near and far. This is the Western Side of Baghdad, which is the side of the City, the side of Karkh, and the side of the suburbs. At every end of it is a cemetery, connected villages, and extending settlements. The Eastern Side of Baghdad was settled by Al-Mahdi ibn Al-Mansur while he was the heir apparent of his father. He began its construction in the year one hundred and forty-three [760 AD]. So Al-Mahdi laid out his palace in Al-Rusafa next to the Congregational Mosque which is in Al-Rusafa. And he dug a river that takes from Al-Nahrawan (2), which he named the River of Al-Mahdi, flowing in the Eastern Side. Al-Mansur granted fiefs to his brothers and his commanders after he had granted fiefs on the Western Side, which is the side of his city...

...And the plots were divided in this side, and it is known as Askar Al-Mahdi (Camp of Al-Mahdi) (1), just as they were divided in the side of the City. People competed to settle near Al-Mahdi due to their love for him and his generosity towards them with money and gifts, and because it was the more spacious of the two sides in land, because people had raced to the Western Side, which is an island between the Tigris and the Euphrates, so they built in it, and markets and trades became established there. So when construction began on the Eastern Side, it was restricted for those who wanted ample building space. The first of the plots at the head of the bridge belonged to Khuzayma ibn Khazim Al-Tamimi, who was in charge of Al-Mahdi's police. Then the plot of Isma'il ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib, then the plot of Al-Abbas ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib, because he made his plot on the Western Side a garden. Then the plot of Al-Sari ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Harith ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib, then the plot of Qutham ibn Al-Abbas ibn [Ubayd] (2) Allah ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib (3), Abu Ja'far's governor over Al-Yamama. Then the plot of Al-Rabi', the mawla of the Commander of the Faithful, because he made his plot in the area of Karkh into markets and income-generating properties, so he was granted a plot with Al-Mahdi, which is the Palace of Al-Fadl ibn Al-Rabi' and the square (Maydan) (4). Then the plot of Jibril ibn Yahya Al-Bajali, then the plot of Asad ibn Abdullah Al-Khuza'i (5), then the plot of Malik ibn Al-Haytham Al-Khuza'i (6), then the plot of Salm ibn Qutayba...

...Al-Bahili (1), then the plot of Sufyan ibn Mu'awiyah Al-Muhallabi, then the plot of Rawh ibn Hatim (2), then the plot of Aban ibn Sadaqa the Scribe, then the plot of Hamawayh the Eunuch, mawla of Al-Mahdi, then the plot of Salamah the Page (Al-Wasif), keeper of Al-Mahdi's armory, then the plot of Badr the Page with the Market of Thirst (Souq al-Atash) (3), which is the great spacious market. Then the plot of Al-Ala the Eunuch, mawla of Al-Mahdi, then the plot of Yazid ibn Mansur Al-Himyari (4), then the plot of Ziyad ibn Mansur Al-Harithi, then the plot of Abu Ubayd Mu'awiyah ibn Barmak Al-Balkhi at the Baradan Bridge (5), then the plot of Umara ibn Hamza ibn Maymun, then...

...the plot of Thabit ibn Musa, the scribe over the land tax (Kharaj) of Kufa and what the Euphrates irrigated. Then the plot of Abdullah ibn Ziyad ibn Abi Layla Al-Khath'ami, the scribe over the Divan of Al-Hejaz [Saudi Arabia], Mosul [Iraq], Al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia], Armenia [Armenia/Turkey], and Azerbaijan [Azerbaijan/Iran]. Then the plot of Ubaydullah ibn Muhammad ibn Safwan the Judge, then the plot of Ya'qub ibn Dawud Al-Sulami (1), the scribe who wrote for Al-Mahdi during his caliphate. Then the plot of Mansur, mawla of Al-Mahdi, which is the place known as the Gate of the Pitched [Area] (Bab al-Muqayyar). Then the plot of Abu Hurayrah Muhammad ibn Farrukh the Commander in the place known as Al-Mukharrim (2). Then the plot of Mu'adh ibn Muslim Al-Razi (3), grandfather of Ishaq ibn...

...Yahya ibn Mu'adh (1). Then the plot of Al-Ghamr ibn Al-Abbas Al-Khath'ami, the owner of the brickyard (Al-Jarr). Then the plot of Salam, mawla of Al-Mahdi, in Al-Mukharrim, and he used to be in charge of the Grievances (Mazalim). Then the plot of Uqbah ibn Salm Al-Hina'i, then the plot of Sa'id Al-Harashi in the Square of Al-Harashi. Then the plot of Mubarak the Turk, then the plot of Sawwar, mawla of the Commander of the Faithful, and the Rahba (plaza) of Sawwar. Then the plot of Nazi, mawla of the Commander of the Faithful, the master of the beasts, and the stable of Nazi. Then the plot of Muhammad ibn Al-Ash'ath Al-Khuza'i (2). Then the plot of Abdul Kabir ibn Abdul Hamid ibn Abdul Rahman ibn Zayd ibn Al-Khattab, the brother of Umar ibn Al-Khattab. [Then] (3) the plot of Abu Ghassan, mawla of the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mahdi. And between the plots were the houses of the soldiers and the rest of the people from the small farmers/landowners (Al-Tanna') (4), and from the merchants and the rest of the people in every quarter and at every suburb. The greatest market of this side, in which varieties of trades, merchandise, and industries gather, is at the head of the bridge, extending from the head of the bridge eastwards, on the right and on the left, containing varieties of trades and industries. The roads of the Eastern Side, which is Askar Al-Mahdi, are divided into five sections: A straight road to Al-Rusafa where the Palace of Al-Mahdi and the Congregational Mosque are; and a road in the market called...

...Suq Khudayr, which is the source of Chinese novelties (1). And you exit from it to the square (Al-Maydan) and the house of Al-Fadl ibn Al-Rabi'. And a road to the left to the Baradan Gate, and there are the houses of Khalid ibn Barmak (2) and his son. And the Bridge Road from the house of Khuzayma to the market known as the Market of Yahya ibn Al-Walid, and to the place known as Al-Dur (3) to the Gate of Baghdad known as Al-Shammasiya (4). From there, whoever wishes exits to Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra, Iraq]. And a road at the first bridge, upon which crosses he who comes from the Western Side, taking along the Tigris to Bab Al-Muqayyar and Al-Mukharrim and what is connected to that. This was the more spacious of the two sides due to the abundance of markets and trades in the Western Side as we described. So Al-Mahdi settled in it while he was...

...heir apparent and during his caliphate. And Musa Al-Hadi (1) settled in it, and Harun Al-Rashid settled in it, and Al-Ma'mun (2) settled in it, and Al-Mu'tasim (3) settled in it. In it are four thousand lanes and streets, fifteen thousand mosques excluding what people added, and five thousand bathhouses excluding what people added after that. The rent of the markets in Baghdad in both sides together, along with the mill of the Patrician and what is connected to it, reached twelve million dirhams in every year.

Seven Caliphs settled in Baghdad: Al-Mansur, Al-Mahdi, Musa Al-Hadi, Harun Al-Rashid, Muhammad Al-Amin, Abdullah Al-Ma'mun, and Al-Mu'tasim. None of them died in it except Muhammad Al-Amin ibn Harun Al-Rashid (1), for he was killed outside the Anbar Gate near the Garden of Tahir. These plots, streets, lanes, and ways that I mentioned are as they were laid out in the days of Al-Mansur and the time of its inception. They have changed, and the early owners of them have died, and people after people and generation after generation have owned them. The construction of some places increased, and people owned the houses of other people. The notables, the majestic ones, the commanders, and the people of renown from the rest of the people moved with Al-Mu'tasim to Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra] in the year two hundred and twenty-three [838 AD]. Then residence continued with them in the days of Al-Wathiq (2) and Al-Mutawakkil (3), but Baghdad was not ruined...

...Baghdad, nor did its markets decrease, because they found no substitute for it, and because the construction and houses were continuous between Baghdad and Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra] by land and river, I mean on the Tigris and on the two sides of the Tigris. Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra]: We have mentioned Baghdad and the beginning of its affair and the time when Abu Ja'far Al-Mansur built it. We described how it was engineered, and how its suburbs, plots, markets, lanes, streets, and quarters were engineered on the Western Side of the Tigris, which is the side of the City and Karkh; and the Eastern Side, which is the side of Al-Rusafa, which is called Askar Al-Mahdi. We said regarding that what we knew. Let us now mention Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra], for it is the second city of the cities of the Caliphs of Banu Hashim. Eight Caliphs have inhabited it, among them Al-Mu'tasim, and he is the one who began it and established it; and Al-Wathiq, who is Harun ibn Al-Mu'tasim; and Al-Mutawakkil Ja'far ibn Al-Mu'tasim (1); and Al-Muntasir Muhammad ibn...
...Al-Mutawakkil (1); and Al-Musta'in Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Al-Mu'tasim (2); and [Al-Mu'tazz] (3) Abu Abdullah...

...Al-Mutawakkil (1); and Al-Muhtadi (2). Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra] was in the preceding days a desert from the land of Al-Tirhan with no construction in it. There was a monastery for Christians (4) in it at the place...

...where the Sultan's house, known as the Public House (Dar al-Amma), came to be, and the monastery became the Treasury (Bayt al-Mal). When Al-Mu'tasim arrived in Baghdad returning from Tarsus (1) in the year in which allegiance was pledged to him for the Caliphate, which was the year two hundred and eighteen [833 AD], he stayed in the House of Al-Ma'mun. Then he built a house on the Eastern Side of Baghdad and moved to it, and he stayed there in the years 218, 219, 220, and 221. He had with him a multitude of Turks, and they were at that time non-Arabs (Ajam). Ja'far Al-Khushaki informed me, saying: Al-Mu'tasim used to send me in the days of Al-Ma'mun to Samarkand [Uzbekistan] to Nuh ibn Asad (2) to buy Turks. I used to bring him a group of them every year, so about three thousand young men (ghulam) gathered for him in the days of Al-Ma'mun. When the Caliphate passed to him, he persisted in seeking them and bought those who were in Baghdad of the people's slaves. Among those he bought in Baghdad was a group, among them Ashnas, who was a slave of Nu'aym ibn Khazim Abu Harun ibn Nu'aym; and Itakh, who was a slave of Salam ibn Al-Abrash; and Wasif, who was a chainmail maker, a slave of the family of Al-Nu'man; and Sima Al-Dimashqi, who was a slave of Dhu al-Ri'asatayn Al-Fadl ibn Sahl (3). When those non-Arab Turks rode beasts, they galloped and collided with people right and left, so the mob would attack them and kill some and beat some, and their blood would go in vain [unavenged], not...

...retaliating against who did that. This weighed heavily on Al-Mu'tasim, and he resolved to leave (1) Baghdad. He went out to Al-Shammasiya, which is the place Al-Ma'mun used to go out to and stay in for days and months. He resolved to build a city in Al-Shammasiya outside Baghdad, but the land of that site was too narrow for him, and he also disliked its proximity to Baghdad. So he proceeded to Al-Baradan upon the advice of Al-Fadl ibn Marwan (2), who was the vizier at that time, and that was in the year two hundred and twenty-one [835-836 AD]. He stayed in Al-Baradan for days and summoned the engineers, then he was not pleased with the site. He went to a place called Bahamsha (3) on the Eastern Side of the Tigris and planned a city there on the Tigris and sought a place to dig a river [canal] but did not find it... [repeated text] ...the engineers, then he was not pleased with the site. He went to a place called Bahamsha (4) on the Eastern Side of the Tigris and planned a city there on the Tigris and sought a place to dig a river but did not find it. So he proceeded to the village known as Al-Matira (5) and stayed there for a period. Then he extended to Al-Qatul (6) and said: "This is the most suitable of places." He made the river known as Al-Qatul the middle of the city, such that the construction would be on the Tigris and on Al-Qatul. He began construction and granted fiefs to the commanders, the scribes, and the people. They built until the construction rose, and markets were laid out on Al-Qatul and on the Tigris. He lived in some of what was built for him, and some people lived...

...also. Then he said: "The land of Al-Qatul is of no use; it is only pebbles and stones (1), and building in it is very difficult and its land has no breadth." Then he rode out hunting and passed in his journey until he came to the site of Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra], a desert from the land of Al-Tirhan with no construction and no person in it except a monastery for Christians. He stopped at the monastery and spoke to the monks in it, saying: "What is the name of this place?" One of the monks said to him: "We find in our ancient books that this place is called Surra Man Ra'a, and that it was the city of Shem, son of Noah, and that it will be inhabited after ages at the hands of a majestic, victorious, triumphant king who has companions whose faces are like the faces of the birds of the wilderness; he will settle in it, and his son will settle in it." He [Al-Mu'tasim] said: "I, by Allah, will build it and settle in it, and my son will settle in it. Al-Rashid commanded one day that his children go out to hunt, so I went out with Muhammad and Al-Ma'mun and the elder children of Al-Rashid. Each one of us caught some game, and I caught an owl. Then we returned and presented our game to him. The servants who were with us began saying: 'This is the game of So-and-so, and this is the game of So-and-so,' until my game was presented to him. When he saw the owl—and the servants had feared presenting it lest he take it as a bad omen or I receive harshness from him—he said: 'Who caught this?' They said: 'Abu Ishaq.' He rejoiced and laughed and showed pleasure, then said: 'Lo, indeed he will attain the Caliphate, and his army and his companions and those prevailing over him will be people whose faces are like the face of this owl. He will build an ancient city, and these people will settle in it, then his son will settle in it after him.' Al-Rashid was not pleased that day by any game as he was pleased by my catching of that owl." Then Al-Mu'tasim resolved to settle in that place. He summoned Muhammad ibn Abdul Malik Al-Zayyat (2), Ibn Abi Du'ad, Umar ibn Faraj, and Ahmad ibn Khalid known as Abu al-Wazir, and said to them: "Buy this land from the owners of this monastery and pay them its price, four thousand dinars (3)." They did that. Then he summoned the engineers and said: "Choose the most suitable of these places."

...So they selected several locations for the palaces. He assigned the building of a palace to each man of his companions. He assigned to Khaqan (1) Urtuj (2) Abu Al-Fath ibn Khaqan the building of Al-Jawsaq (3) Al-Khaqani; and to Umar ibn Faraj the building of the palace known as Al-Amri; and to Abu al-Wazir the building of the palace known as Al-Waziri. Then he laid out the plots for the commanders, the scribes, and the people, and laid out the Congregational Mosque. He laid out the markets around the Congregational Mosque, widened the rows of the markets, and made every trade separate and every group on their own, just as the markets of Baghdad were designed. He wrote for the dispatching of workers, builders, and craftsmen such as blacksmiths, carpenters, and other trades; and for the transport of teak wood and other timber and palm trunks from Basra and what is near it, and from Baghdad and the rest of the Sawad, and from Antioch (4) and the rest of the coasts of Al-Sham [Levant]; and for the transport of marble workers and marble slabs. Houses for the marble industry were established in Latakia (5) and elsewhere. He separated the plots...

...of the Turks from the plots of all the people, and made them isolated from them, not mixing with any of the Muwalladun (people of mixed ancestry/locals), and no one neighbored them except the Ferghanians (1). He granted Ashnas and his companions the place known as Al-Karkh and attached to him several of the Turkish commanders and men, and ordered him to build mosques and markets. He granted Khaqan Urtuj and his companions [land] next to Al-Jawsaq Al-Khaqani, and ordered the gathering of his companions and preventing them from mixing with the people. He granted Wasif and his companions [land] next to Al-Hayr, and built a wall which he called Ha'ir Al-Hayr extending [along it]. The plots of all the Turks and the non-Arab Ferghanians were made far from the markets and the crowds, in wide avenues and long lanes. No one from the people, neither merchant nor anyone else, was with them in their plots and lanes to mix with them. Then he bought slave girls for them and married them to them, and forbade them to marry or intermarry with any of the Muwalladun (2), until children grew up for them, then they would marry among themselves. He assigned fixed stipends for the slave girls of the Turks and recorded their names in the registers, so no one of them was able to divorce his wife or leave her. When he granted Ashnas the Turk land at the end of the construction to the west (3), and granted his companions land with him and named the place Al-Karkh, he ordered him not to allow (4) a stranger, neither merchant nor otherwise, to be a neighbor to them, and not to allow (5) socializing with the Muwalladun. He granted land to other people above Al-Karkh and named it Al-Dur. He built mosques and bathhouses for them within the houses and plots, and made in every location a small market containing several shops for greengrocers (6) and butchers and those like them whom they cannot do without and have no dispense of. He granted Al-Afshin Khaydhar ibn Kawus Al-Ushrusani land at the end of the construction to the east, about...

...two farsakhs away, and named the place Al-Matira. He granted the Ushrusani companions and others attached to him land around his house, and ordered him to build there a small market containing shops for merchants for what is indispensable, and mosques and bathhouses. Al-Hasan ibn Sahl (1) requested a land grant between the end of the markets—and their end was the mountain where the gibbet of Babak came to be—and Al-Matira, the location of Afshin's plot. There was no construction in that place at that time. Then construction surrounded it until the plot of Al-Hasan ibn Sahl became the middle of Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra]. The construction of the people extended from every side and the construction connected to Al-Matira. Avenues were made for the plots of the commanders of Khurasan and their companions from the soldiers and the Shakiriyya (2). On the right of the avenues and their left were the lanes containing the houses of all the people. The avenue known as Al-Sarijah, which is the Grand Avenue, extended from Al-Matira to the valley known at this time as the Valley of Ishaq ibn Ibrahim (3), because Ishaq ibn Ibrahim moved from his plot in the days of Al-Mutawakkil and built at the head of the valley and expanded the construction. Then the plot of Ishaq ibn Yahya ibn Mu'adh, then the plots of the people connect right and left in this...

the Great Street. Paths branch off from both sides of the Great Street leading to a street known as Abu Ahmad [Street] - he is Abu Ahmad son of al-Rashid - from one side, and leading to the Tigris and what is near it from the other side. The land grants pass to the Great Bureau of Land Tax, which is in this large street. In this street are the land grants of the commanders of Khorasan. Among them are the land grant of Hashim ibn Bayanjor, the land grant of Ujayf ibn Anbasa, the land grant of al-Hasan ibn Ali al-Ma'muni, the land grant of Harun ibn Nu'aym, and the land grant of Hizam ibn Ghalib. Behind the land grant of Hizam are the stables for the Caliph's private and public beasts, managed by Hizam and his brother Ya'qub. Then the places of the date sellers (1) and the Slave Market in a square with branching roads containing chambers, rooms, and shops for slaves. Then the Police Council, the Great Prison, and people's houses and markets in this street, right and left, like other sales and industries. That connects to the Wood of Babak. Then the Great Market where houses do not mix; every trade is separate, and people of each profession do not mix with others. Then the Old Congregational Mosque where Friday prayers continued to be held until the days of Al-Mutawakkil, when it became too narrow for the people, so he demolished it and built a wide Congregational Mosque on the roads of Al-Hayr. The Congregational Mosque and markets are on one side. On the other side are land grants, houses, and markets of owners of lowly trades such as sellers of Fuqqa' (2), Harisa (3), and drinks. And the land grant of Mubarak al-Maghribi, and Suwayqat (Little Market of) Mubarak, and the Mountain of Ja'far the Tailor, where Ja'far's land grant was. Then the land grant of Abu al-Wazir. Then the land grant of al-Abbas ibn Ali ibn al-Mahdi, then the land grant of Abd al-Wahhab ibn Ali ibn al-Mahdi. The street extends, containing public land grants, to the house of Harun ibn al-Mu'tasim, who is Al-Wathiq, at the Public House (Dar al-Amma). This is the house where Yahya ibn Aktham (4) stayed in the days of Al-Mutawakkil when he appointed him Chief Judge

of Judges. Then the Public Gate (Bab al-Amma) and the Caliph's Palace, which is the Public House where he sits on Mondays. Then the Treasuries: private treasuries and public treasuries. Then the land grant of Masrur Samana the Servant (Eunuch), who is in charge of the Treasuries. Then the land grant of Qarqas the Servant, who is Khorasani. Then the land grant of Thabit the Servant. Then the land grant of Abu al-Ja'fa' and other major servants. The Second Street is known as Abu Ahmad [Street], he is Abu Ahmad son of al-Rashid. The beginning of this street from the east is the house of Bukhtishu' (1) the physician, which he built in the days of Al-Mutawakkil. Then the land grants of the commanders of Khorasan, and their Arab associates, and people from Qom, Isfahan, Qazvin, Al-Jabal, and Azerbaijan to the right in the south towards the Qibla; it leads to the Great Surayjah Street. What is towards the north, behind the Qibla, leads to Abu Ahmad Street, the Great Bureau of Land Tax, the land grant of Umar, a land grant for the scribes, and other people. The land grant of Abu Ahmad ibn al-Rashid is in the middle of the street. At its end towards the western valley called Wadi Ibrahim ibn Riyah are the land grant of Ibn Abi Du'ad, the land grant of al-Fadl ibn Marwan, the land grant of Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik al-Zayyat, and the land grant of Ibrahim ibn Riyah in the Great Street. Then

the land grants connect in this street and in the paths to its right and left to the land grant of Bugha the Younger, then the land grant of Bugha the Elder, then the land grant of Sima al-Dimashqi, then the land grant of Barmash, then the old land grant of Wasif. Then the land grant of Itakh. That connects to the Garden Gate (Bab al-Bustan) and the Caliph's palaces. The Third Street is the First Al-Hayr Street, where the house of Ahmad ibn al-Khasib was in the days of Al-Mutawakkil. The beginning of this street is from the east, and from the valley connected to Wadi Ishaq ibn Ibrahim. In it are the land grants of the army, the Shakiriyah, and mixed people, extending to Wadi Ibrahim ibn Riyah. The Fourth Street is known as Barghamish the Turk Street. In it are the land grants of the Turks and the Ferghanis. The paths of the Turks are separate, and the paths of the Ferghanis are separate. The Turks are in the paths towards the Qibla, and the Ferghanis are opposite them in the paths behind the Qibla; each path opposite a path, and no one from the people mixes with them. The last of the Turks' dwellings and land grants are the land grants of the Khazars towards the east. The beginning of this street is from Al-Matira at the land grants of Al-Afshin which went to Wasif and Wasif's companions. Then the street extends to the valley connected to Wadi Ibrahim ibn Riyah. The Fifth Street is known as Salih al-Abbasi [Street], which is Al-Askar Street. In it are the land grants of the Turks and the Ferghanis. The Turks are also in separate paths, and the Ferghanis in separate paths, extending from Al-Matira to the house of Salih al-Abbasi at the head of the valley. That connects to the land grants of the commanders, scribes, notables, and all people. Then a street behind Al-Askar Street called the New Al-Hayr Street. In it are mixed people from the commanders of the Ferghanis, Ushrusanis, Ishtakhanjis, and others from all districts of Khorasan. Whenever these streets from Al-Hayr reached land grants for a people, the wall was demolished and another wall built behind it. Behind the wall are wild animals: gazelles, wild donkeys, wild animals, deer, rabbits, and ostriches. A wall surrounds them in a beautiful wide desert. The street on the Tigris is called the Gulf Street (Shari' al-Khalij). There are the wharves, ships, and goods arriving from Baghdad, Wasit, Kaskar, and the rest of the Sawad, from Basra, Ubulla, Ahwaz, and what connects to that, and from Mosul, Ba'arbaya, Diyar Rabi'a, and what connects to that.

In this street are the land grants of all or most of the Maghrebis, and the place known as Al-Azlakh which was populated by the Maghrebi infantry when Surra Man Ra'a was first planned. People expanded in building in Surra Man Ra'a more than their expansion in Baghdad. They built spacious houses, except that their drinking water is all from the Tigris carried in water skins (Rawaya) (1) on mules and camels because their wells are deep (far rope) (2), and moreover salty and not palatable, so they have no capacity in water [from wells]. But the Tigris is close and water carriers are many. The yields and revenues of Surra Man Ra'a and its markets reached ten million dirhams per year. The transport of provisions brought from Mosul, Ba'arbaya, and the rest of Diyar Rabi'a in ships on the Tigris was close, so their prices were good. When Al-Mu'tasim finished planning and laying the foundation for building on the eastern side of the Tigris, which is the side of Surra Man Ra'a, he built a bridge to the western side of the Tigris. He established cultivation, orchards, and gardens there. He dug canals from the Tigris and assigned to every commander the cultivation of a region. He brought date palms from Baghdad, Basra, and the rest of the Sawad. Saplings were brought from Jazira, Sham, Al-Jabal, Rayy, Khorasan, and other countries. Water became abundant in this cultivation on the eastern side of Surra Man Ra'a. The date palms thrived, trees took root, fruits grew, and fruits, basil, and vegetables improved. People planted varieties of crops, aromatic plants, vegetables, and fodder. The land had been resting for thousands of years, so everything planted and sown in it thrived until the yield of the cultivations on the canal known as Al-Ishaqi and what is on it, Al-Itakhi, Al-Umari, Al-Abdul-Maliki, Daliyat Ibn Hammad, Al-Masruri, Sayf, the new Arabat (five villages), the lower villages (seven villages), gardens, and orchards, and the crop tax reached four hundred thousand dinars per year. Al-Mu'tasim brought from every country those who perform any work or practice any profession of cultivation, planting, date palms, saplings, water engineering, weighing, extraction, and knowledge

of its locations in the earth. He brought from Egypt those who make papyrus (1) and other things. He brought from Basra those who make glass, pottery, and mats. He brought from Kufa those who make oils. And from other countries people of every profession and industry. They were settled with their families in these places and granted lands. Markets were made there for the people of professions in the city. Al-Mu'tasim built the cultivations as palaces, placing in every orchard a palace with sitting rooms, pools, and squares. The cultivations became beautiful, and the notables desired to have even the slightest land there. They competed for that, and the Jarib (2) of land reached a large sum. Al-Mu'tasim Billah died in the year two hundred and twenty-seven. Harun Al-Wathiq ibn Al-Mu'tasim assumed the Caliphate. Al-Wathiq built the palace known as Al-Haruni on the Tigris and made sitting rooms in it on an eastern platform and a western platform. He moved into it, and land grants increased. He brought some people close and moved others' houses further away by steps not by distances. He granted Wasif the house of Afshin in Al-Matira. Wasif moved from his old house to Afshin's house and continued to live there, with his companions and men around him. He increased the markets, and the wharves (3) to which ships come from Baghdad, Wasit, Basra, and Mosul became great. People renewed, perfected, and mastered building when they knew it had become a populous city; before that, they used to call it Al-Askar (The Camp). Then Al-Wathiq died in the year two hundred and thirty-two. Ja'far Al-Mutawakkil ibn Al-Mu'tasim (4) assumed power. He stayed in Al-Haruni and preferred it over all Al-Mu'tasim's palaces. He settled his son Muhammad

Al-Muntasir (1) in Al-Mu'tasim's palace known as Al-Jawsaq. He settled his son Ibrahim Al-Mu'ayyad (2) in Al-Matira. He settled his son Al-Mu'tazz (3) behind Al-Matira to the east in a place called Balkuwara. The construction connected from Balkuwara to the end of the place known as Al-Dur, a distance of four farsakhs. He added Al-Askar Street and the New Street to the streets of Al-Hayr. He built the Congregational Mosque at the beginning of Al-Hayr in a spacious place outside the houses, not connected to any land grants or markets. He perfected it, widened it, and solidified its construction. He placed a water fountain in it whose water never ceases. He made the roads to it consisting of three wide rows
