great [rows] from the street that takes from Wadi Ibrahim ibn Riyah. In each row are shops with varieties of trades, industries, and goods. The width of each row is one hundred cubits by the Black Cubit so that entering the mosque would not be narrow for him when he attends the mosque on Friday with his armies, crowds, cavalry, and infantry. From each row to the next are paths and alleys containing land grants for groups of common people. Houses and dwellings became spacious for people. Market people, professionals, and artisans found space in those shops and markets in the rows of the Congregational Mosque. He granted land to Najah ibn Salama the scribe at the end of the rows towards the Qibla of the mosque. He granted land to Ahmad ibn Isra'il the scribe also near that. He granted land to Muhammad ibn Musa the astronomer, his brothers, and a group of scribes, commanders, Hashimites, and others. Al-Mutawakkil resolved to build a city to move to, to be attributed to him, and through which he would be remembered. He ordered Muhammad ibn Musa the astronomer and the engineers present at his gate to choose a location. Their choice fell on a place called Al-Mahuzah. It was said to him: Al-Mu'tasim intended to build a city here and dig a canal that existed in ancient times. He resolved on that and began looking into it in the year forty-five [245 AH]. He sent for digging that canal to be in the middle of the city. The cost was estimated at one million five hundred thousand dinars. He was pleased with that and accepted it. Digging began, and great funds were spent on that canal. The location of his palaces and houses was planned. He granted land to his crown princes, other children, commanders, scribes, army, and all people. He extended the Great Street from the house of Ashnas in Karkh, which went to Al-Fath ibn Khaqan, a distance of three farsakhs to his palaces. Before his palaces, he placed three great majestic gates through which a horseman enters with his lance. He granted land to people on the right and left of the Great Street. He made the width of the Great Street two hundred cubits. He planned to dig two rivers on the sides of the street in which water flows from the large river he was digging. Palaces were built, houses erected, and construction rose. He used to go around himself; whomever he saw diligent in building, he rewarded and gave, so people were diligent. Al-Mutawakkil named this city Al-Ja'fariyah (1). Construction connected from Al-Ja'fariyah to

the place known as Al-Dur, then to Karkh and Surra Man Ra'a, extending to the place inhabited by his son Abu Abdullah Al-Mu'tazz. There was no open space or gap between any of that, nor a place without construction. The extent of that was seven farsakhs. The buildings rose in the span of a year. Markets were placed in a separate location, and a market was made in every square and district. He built the Congregational Mosque. Al-Mutawakkil moved to the palaces of this city on the first day of Muharram in the year two hundred and forty-seven. When he sat, he rewarded people with splendid gifts, connected them, and gave to all commanders, scribes, and those who held any office. His joy was complete, and he said: "Now I know that I am a king, when I built a city for myself and inhabited it." The Bureaus were transferred: the Bureau of Land Tax, Bureau of Estates, Bureau of Control (Zimam), Bureau of the Army and Shakiriyah, Bureau of Clients and Servants, Bureau of Post, and all Bureaus. However, the canal was not completed, and water did not flow in it except a weak flow that had no continuity or straightness, even though about a million dinars had been spent on it. But its digging was very difficult; they were digging through gypsum and stones (1) that pickaxes could not work on. Al-Mutawakkil remained residing in his palaces in Al-Ja'fariyah for nine months and three days. He was killed on the third of Shawwal in the year two hundred and forty-seven in his Ja'fari palace, the most ominous of palaces. Muhammad Al-Muntasir ibn Al-Mutawakkil assumed power and moved to Surra Man Ra'a. He ordered all people to move from Al-Mahuzah (2), demolish the houses, and carry the debris to Surra Man Ra'a. People moved and carried the debris of the houses to Surra Man Ra'a. The palaces, houses, dwellings, and markets of Al-Ja'fari were ruined in the quickest time. The place became desolate with no companion or inhabitant, and the abodes became empty wastes (3) as if they had never been built or inhabited. Al-Muntasir died in Surra Man Ra'a in the month of Rabi' al-Thani in the year two hundred and forty-eight.

Al-Musta'in Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Al-Mu'tasim assumed power. He stayed in Surra Man Ra'a for two years and eight months until his affairs became disordered, so he descended to Baghdad in Muharram of the year two hundred and fifty-one. He stayed there fighting the companions of Al-Mu'tazz for a full year, while Al-Mu'tazz was in Surra Man Ra'a with the Turks and other [clients] (1). Then Al-Musta'in was deposed and Al-Mu'tazz assumed power. He stayed there until he was killed three years and seven months after Al-Musta'in's deposition. Muhammad Al-Muhtadi ibn Al-Wathiq was pledged allegiance in Rajab of the year two hundred and fifty-five. He stayed a full year residing in Al-Jawsaq until he was killed, may Allah have mercy on him. Ahmad Al-Mu'tamid ibn Al-Mutawakkil (2) assumed power. He stayed in Surra Man Ra'a in Al-Jawsaq and the Caliphate palaces. Then he moved to the eastern side of Surra Man Ra'a and built a palace described as beautiful, naming it Al-Ma'shuq. He settled in it and stayed there until matters became disordered, so he moved to Baghdad then to Al-Mada'in. Surra Man Ra'a, from when it was built and inhabited until the time we wrote this book of ours, is fifty-five years. Eight Caliphs perished in it; five died or were killed in it: Al-Mu'tasim, Al-Wathiq, Al-Muntasir, Al-Mu'tazz, and Al-Muhtadi. Two were killed in its precincts and what is connected to it or near it: Al-Mutawakkil and Al-Musta'in. Its name in earlier books is Zawra' (3) of Banu al-Abbas.

What confirms this is that the Qiblas of all its mosques are skewed (*muzawwarah*), having a deviation; there is no straight Qibla in it. However, it was not ruined nor did its name vanish. We have mentioned Baghdad and Surra Man Ra'a and started with them because they are the two cities of the Kingdom and the abode of the Caliphate, and we described the beginning of the affair of each. Let us now mention the other countries and the distances between each country and city, divided into four sections according to the division of the earth's regions between the East, the West, the blowing place of the South - which is the Qibla and the rising place of Canopus, which mathematicians call Al-Tayammun (2) - and the blowing place of the North, which is the Seat of the Daughters of Na'sh (Ursa Major), which mathematicians call Al-Jadi (Capricorn/North Pole). We attribute every country to the quarter it belongs to and connects with. And success is with Allah.

The First Quarter: The Quarter of the East
From Baghdad to Al-Jabal, Azerbaijan, Qazvin, Zanjan, Qom, Isfahan, Rayy, Tabaristan, Jurjan, Sijistan, Khorasan, and what connects to Khorasan from Tibet and Turkestan.

Districts of Al-Jabal (1)
Whoever wants to proceed from Baghdad eastward goes from its eastern side of the Tigris, then heads east to a place called Three Gates (Thalathat Abwab), which is the end of Baghdad towards the east. Then the journey goes straight to the Bridge of Nahrawan. It is a majestic ancient town on a canal taking from a river coming from the mountain called Tamarra (2). It then irrigates sub-districts (Tassujs) of the Sawad. Great boats and large ships sail in it. When one crosses the Bridge of Nahrawan, the roads of Al-Jabal branch out. If he wants to take the route of the districts of Masabadhan (3) and Mihrajan Qadhaq (4),

and Al-Saymarah (1), he takes the right upon crossing the Bridge of Nahrawan and travels six stages to the city of Masabadhan. It is a city called Al-Sirwan, of great standing, mighty and vast, between mountains and ravines. It is the city most resembling Mecca. In it are gushing water springs flowing in the middle of the city into great rivers irrigating farms, villages, estates, and orchards for a distance of three days. These springs are hot in winter, cold in summer. The people of this city are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs (Ajam).

Al-Saymarah (2)
From the city of Al-Sirwan (3) to the city of Al-Saymarah, which is the city of a district known as Mihrajan Qadhaq, is two stages. The city of Al-Saymarah is in a wide meadow (4) with springs and rivers irrigating villages and farms. Its people are a mix of people, Arabs and non-Arabs from Persians and Kurds.

Masabadhan was conquered in the Caliphate of Umar ibn Al-Khattab. The land tax of this country reaches two million five hundred thousand dirhams. Their speech is Persian.
Whoever wants to go from Baghdad to Hulwan (1) takes the left from the Bridge of Nahrawan and reaches Daskarat al-Malik (2). In it are dwellings of the Persian kings, of wondrous construction, majestic and beautiful. Then he goes from Daskarat al-Malik to Tararistan (3). In it are wondrous described ruins of the Persian kings. In it are canals one above the other vaulted with gypsum and baked brick. Some of those canals take from Al-Qawatil (4), and some take from Nahrawan. From Tararistan to Jalula al-Waqi'ah (5), which is the beginning of Al-Jabal. In it was the battle in the days of Umar ibn Al-Khattab against the Persians when Sa'd ibn Abi

Waqqas caught up with them. Allah dispersed the gatherings of the Persians and scattered them. That was in the year nineteen of the Hijra. From Jalula to Khanaqin (1), which is among the most majestic villages and greatest in importance. From Khanaqin to Qasr Shirin (2).

Shirin (1), the wife of Kisra (2), used to summer in this palace. In this place are many ruins of the Persian kings. From Qasr Shirin to Hulwan.

Hulwan
The city of Hulwan (3) is a majestic large city. Its people are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs from Persians and Kurds. It was conquered in the days of Umar ibn Al-Khattab.

The land tax of Hulwan, although it is from the districts of Al-Jabal, is included in the land tax of the Sawad sub-districts. From the city of Hulwan to the meadow known as Marj al-Qal'ah (1). In this place are the beasts of the Caliphs in the meadows. From Marj al-Qal'ah to Al-Zubaydiyyah (2), then from there to the city of Qarmasin (3). Qarmasin is a city of great standing and many inhabitants. Most of its inhabitants are non-Arabs from Persians and Kurds. From the city of Qarmasin to Dinawar (4) is three stages.

Dinawar
Dinawar (5) is a city of great standing. Its people are a mix of people, Arabs and non-Arabs. It was conquered in the days of Umar (6). It is what is called: Mah al-Kufa, because its money was carried in the stipends of the people of Kufa. It has several regions and districts (Rustaqs) (7). The amount of its land tax, excluding the Sultan's estates, is five million seven hundred thousand dirhams.

Qazvin and Zanjan
Whoever wants to go from Dinawar to Qazvin (1) and Zanjan leaves Dinawar to the city of Abhar (2). The roads branch out. If he intends for Zanjan (3), his travel is from Abhar to Zanjan, then he travels to the city of Qazvin. Qazvin is off the main road. It is at the foot of a mountain bordering Daylam (4). It has two valleys; one is called the Great Valley and the other Wadi Siram. Water flows in them in the days of winter and ceases in the days of summer. Its people are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs. It has ruins of the non-Arabs and fire temples. Its land tax with the land tax of Zanjan is one million five hundred thousand. Roads branch from it to Hamadan, Dinawar, Shahrazur (5),

Isfahan (1), and Rayy (2). The road from it is to Azerbaijan.

Azerbaijan
Whoever wants to go to Azerbaijan (3) leaves Zanjan and travels four stages to the city of

Ardabil (1), which is the first of the cities of Azerbaijan he meets. From Ardabil to Barzand (2) from the districts of Azerbaijan is a journey of three days. From Barzand to the city of Warthan from the districts of Azerbaijan. From Warthan (3) to Al-Baylaqan (4). From Al-Baylaqan to the city of Al-Maraghah (5), which is the city of Upper Azerbaijan. The districts of Azerbaijan are Ardabil, Barzand, Warthan, Bardha'ah (6),

Al-Shiz (1), Sarah (2), Marand (3), Tabriz (4), Al-Miyanij (5), Al-Rumiyah (6), Khoy (7), and Salmas (8). The people of the cities of Azerbaijan and its districts are a mix of non-Arabs, Azaris and Jawdanians of old, the owners of the city of Al-Badhdh (9) where Babak was, then Arabs settled it when it was conquered.

Azerbaijan [Azerbaijan/Iran] was conquered in the year twenty-two. It was conquered by Al-Mughira ibn Shu'ba Al-Thaqafi (1) during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan (2). Its land tax (Kharaj) is four million dirhams, increasing in one year and decreasing in another.

Hamadhan. Whoever wants to go from Dinawar [ruins near Sahneh, Iran] to the city of Hamadhan [Hamadan, Iran] (1) exits the city of Dinawar to a place called Muhammad Abadh (2), two stages away. From Muhammad Abadh to Hamadhan is two stages. Hamadhan is a vast land of great esteem, with many regions and districts. It was conquered in the year twenty-three. Its land tax is six million dirhams. It is what is called Mah al-Basra; its land tax used to be carried for the stipends of the people of Basra [Basra, Iraq]. Its people drink from springs and valleys that flow winter and summer. Some of them flow to Al-Sus [Shush, Iran] (3) in the districts of Al-Ahwaz [Ahvaz, Iran], then pass to Dujayl (4), the river of Al-Ahwaz, to the city of Al-Ahwaz (5).

Nihawand. From Hamadhan to Nihawand [Nahavand, Iran] (1) is two stages. Nihawand is a majestic city where the gathering of the Persians took place when Al-Nu'man ibn Muqarrin Al-Muzani met them in the year twenty-one (2). It has several regions, inhabited by a mixture of Arabs and non-Arabs. Its land tax, excluding the money from estates, is two million dirhams. Al-Karaj. From Nihawand to the city of Al-Karaj [Astaneh, Iran] (3) is two stages. Al-Karaj is the home of Isa ibn Idris ibn Ma'qil ibn Sheikh ibn Umayr Al-Ijli, Abu Dulaf. It was not a famous city in the days of the non-Arabs (Persians), but was among the large villages of a rustaq (district) called Qaiqa [?] of the district of Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran]. From there to the city of Isfahan is sixty farsakhs. The Ijlis settled there and built fortresses and palaces, so its palaces are attributed to Abu Dulaf, his brothers, and the people of his...

...house. Four rustaqs (districts) were added to it: one is called Al-Faiqin, Jabliq, and Barqarudh. Al-Karaj lies between four mountains, populated with estates, farms, villages, flowing rivers, and running springs. Its people are non-Arabs, except for those from the family of Isa ibn Idris Al-Ijli and those of the rest of the Arabs who joined them. The land tax of Al-Karaj was three million and four hundred thousand [dirhams] by contract; from the rustaqs one million dirhams, and from drinks four hundred thousand. Then that decreased in the days of Al-Wathiq, reaching three million three hundred thousand dirhams. Qumm and what is attached to it. Whoever wants to go to Qumm [Qom, Iran] (1) exits the city of Hamadhan towards the east and travels through the rustaqs of Hamadhan. From the city of Hamadhan to the city of Qumm is five stages. The city of Qumm the Great is called Manijan. It is of great esteem; it is said to have one thousand lanes. Inside the city is an ancient fortress belonging to the non-Arabs. Next to it is a city called Kamandan (2). There is a valley running with water between the two cities with bridges built of stone over which one crosses from the city of Manijan to the city of Kamandan. The people prevailing over it are a people from Madhhij (3), then from the Ash'aris (4). There are non-Arabs in it...

...and a people of the Mawali (clients) who mention that they are clients of Abdullah ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib. It has two rivers: one at the top of the city known as Ras al-Mawr, and the other at the bottom of the city known as Furuz. They are from springs flowing in dug channels. It is in a wide meadow about ten farsakhs, then it leads to its mountains. Among them is a mountain known as the Rustaq of Sardab and a mountain known as Al-Mallaha. It has twelve rustaqs (1): Rustaq Sitara, Rustaq Kurzaman, Rustaq Al-Farahan [Farahan, Iran] (2), Rustaq Warah (3), Rustaq Tayras, Rustaq Kurdar, Rustaq Wardrah, Rustaq Sardab, Rustaq Bar'awstan (4), Rustaq Baraha, Rustaq Qaris, and Rustaq Hindijan. Most of the drinking water for the people of the city in summer is from wells. Roads branch out from it to Rayy [Ray, Iran], Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran], Al-Karaj, and Hamadhan. Its land tax is four million five hundred thousand dirhams. Isfahan. From Qumm to Isfahan is sixty farsakhs, which is six stages. Isfahan has two cities; one is called Jayy (5), and the other city is called Al-Yahudiya [The Jewish Quarter] (6). Its people are a mixture of people...

...and its Arabs are few. Most of its people are non-Arabs (Ajam) from the nobles of the Dihqans (landed gentry). There are people of the Arabs in it who moved to it from Kufa [Iraq] and Basra [Iraq], from Thaqif (1), Tamim (2), Banu Dabba (3), Khuza'a (4), Banu Hanifa (5), Banu Abd al-Qays (6), and others. It is said that Salman Al-Farsi (7), may Allah have mercy on him, was from the people of Isfahan, from a village...

...called Jayyan (1), according to what the people of Isfahan say in narration. The people of Isfahan have many waters from valleys and springs that flow to Al-Ahwaz, from Isfahan to Tustar [Shushtar, Iran] (2), then to Al-Manadhir (3) Al-Kubra, then to the city of Al-Ahwaz [Ahvaz, Iran]. Isfahan was conquered in the year twenty-three. The amount of its land tax is ten million dirhams. Among its rustaqs are: Rustaq Jayy, in which is the city; Rustaq Bara'an (4), and its people are Dihqans with whom no others mix; Rustaq Barkhar (5), in which are also a people of the Dihqans; and Rustaq Ruyidasht (6), which is the border between Isfahan and a district of the districts of Fars [Fars Province, Iran] called Yazd [Yazd, Iran] (7),

...and Rustaq Al-Baran (1), Rustaq Mirin, and Rustaq Al-Qamidan, in which are Kurds and a mixture of non-Arabs who are not of nobility like others. From it emerged the Khurramiyya (2). It is the border between the administration of Isfahan and the administration of Al-Ahwaz. Rustaq Fahman, in which are Kurds also and Khurramiyya. Rustaq Faridayn [Fereydan, Iran], in which are the lower class non-Arabs whom the noble non-Arabs of Isfahan call Al-Liyya [?]. Rustaq Al-Radmila. The two rustaqs of Sardaqasan and Jarmaqasan; in them are nobles of the Dihqans and a people of the Arabs from the people of Yemen from Hamdan. They are the border between the administration of Isfahan and Qumm. Rustaq Ardistan [Ardestan, Iran] (3), in which are majestic Dihqans. It is said that Khosrow Anushirvan was born in this place. And the two rustaqs of Al-Taymara; they are two rustaqs inhabited by a people of the Arabs from Banu Hilal (4) and others from the clans of Qays. It is the border between the administration of Isfahan and Al-Karaj.

Al-Rayy. Whoever intends to go to Al-Rayy [Ray, south of Tehran, Iran] (1) exits from the city of Dinawar to Qazvin [Qazvin, Iran], then travels from Qazvin three stages on the main road. Al-Rayy is on the main road of Khurasan [Khorasan] (2). The name of the city of Al-Rayy is Al-Muhammadiyya. It was named by this name only because Al-Mahdi settled in it during the caliphate of Al-Mansur when he headed to Khurasan to fight Abdul Jabbar ibn Abdul Rahman Al-Azdi, and he rebuilt it. Al-Rashid was born there because Al-Mahdi stayed there for several years and built wonderful structures there. The women of the notables of its people suckled Al-Rashid. The people of Al-Rayy are a mixture of non-Arabs, and its Arabs are few. Al-Rayy was conquered by Qaratha ibn Ka'b Al-Ansari during the caliphate of Umar ibn Al-Khattab in the year three...

...and twenty. Its people drink from many springs and great valleys. In it is a great valley coming from the lands of Daylam called the River of Musa. Due to the abundance of the land's water, its fruits, gardens, and trees are plentiful. It has rustaqs and regions. In it are the estates of Ishaq ibn Yahya ibn Mu'adh, and the estates of Ibn Abi Abbad Thabit ibn Yahya, the scribe of Al-Ma'mun; both are from the people of Al-Rayy. The amount of its land tax is ten million dirhams. Qumis. From Al-Rayy to Qumis [Semnan Province, Iran] (1) on the main road and the great line is twelve stages, some in inhabited areas and some in deserts. Qumis is a vast land of great esteem. The name of the city is Al-Damghan [Damghan, Iran] (2), and it is the first of the cities of Khurasan. It was conquered by Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Kurayz (3) during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan in the year thirty. Its people are...

...a non-Arab people and the most skilled people in making fine Qumisi wool cloaks. Its land tax reaches one million five hundred thousand dirhams, except that it enters into the land tax of Khurasan. As for the land adjacent to the Sea of Daylam [Caspian Sea] from Khurasan, from Al-Rayy to Tabaristan [Mazandaran Province, Iran]. The city of Tabaristan is Sariya [Sari, Iran]; from Al-Rayy to it is seven stages. Tabaristan. To the second city of Tabaristan (1), which is called Amul [Amol, Iran], is two stages. The city of Amul is on the Sea of Daylam. Tabaristan is a separate land with a majestic kingdom. Its king has always been called: The Ispahbadh (2). It is the land of Al-Mazyar who used to write to the Caliphs, to Al-Ma'mun and to Al-Mu'tasim: "From the Jil of Jilan, the Ispahbadh of Khurasan, Al-Mazyar ibn Qarin, clients of the Commander of the Faithful," he does not say "client of the Commander of the Faithful". It is a land of many fortresses, impregnable with valleys. Its people are the nobles of the non-Arabs, the sons of their kings, and they are the people with the most beautiful faces. It is said that Khosrow Yazdegerd left [children] among his slave girls, so the faces of its people became beautiful from those slave girls because the people of Tabaristan are their children. The land tax of the country is four million dirhams. Tabari carpets and Tabari cloaks are made there.

Jurjan. From Al-Rayy to Jurjan [Gorgan, Iran] (1) is seven stages. The city of Jurjan is on the river of Daylam. The land of Jurjan was conquered by Sa'id ibn Uthman during the governorship of Mu'awiyah, then it closed up and its people apostatized from Islam until Yazid ibn Al-Muhallab (2) conquered it during the governorship of Sulayman ibn Abdul Malik ibn Marwan (3). The land tax of the country is ten million dirhams. Good wood from the Khalanj tree [Heath/Briar] is made there (4)...

...and others, and varieties of silk garments. In it are the great Bactrian camels (1). In the land of Jurjan, there are many palm trees. Tus. Connected to these lands, adjacent to the Sea of Daylam [Caspian Sea] from the districts of Nishapur and what adjoins it, is Tus [Tus, Iran] (2). It is two stages from Nishapur. In Tus, there are people of the Arabs from Tayy (3) and others, but most of its people are non-Arabs. In it is the grave of Al-Rashid, the Commander of the Faithful. In it died Al-Rida Ali ibn Musa ibn Ja'far ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Al-Husayn, peace be upon him (4). The greatest city of Tus is called Nuqan. The land tax of the country is with the land tax of Nishapur.

From Tus to Nisa [Nisa, Turkmenistan] (1) of the district of Nishapur is two stages. From Nisa to Baward [Abiward, Turkmenistan] (2) is two stages. From Nisa to Khwarazm [Khwarezm, Uzbekistan/Turkmenistan] (3) for one taking the eastern route is eight stages. Khwarazm is at the end of the River of Balkh [Amu Darya] in the place where the water of the River of Balkh exits from it into the Sea of Daylam [Aral Sea]. It is a vast land conquered by Salm ibn Ziyad ibn Abihi (4) in the days of Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah (5). In it...

...furs are made, and the rest of the fur from sable, fennec, ermine, lynx, and squirrel. These are the districts that are on this side of the River of Balkh from the land of Khurasan. The River of Balkh exits from springs between mountains; between its mouth and the city of Balkh is ten stages. Nishapur. From Qumis on the main road to the city of Nishapur [Nishapur, Iran] (1) is nine stages. Nishapur is a vast land with many districts. Among the districts of Nishapur are: Al-Tabasayn [Tabas, Iran] (2), Quhistan [South Khorasan, Iran] (3), Nisa,

and Abiward [Abiward, Turkmenistan] (1), Abarshahr (2), Jam [Torbat-e Jam, Iran], Bakharz [Bakharz, Iran] (3), and Tus. The greatest city of Tus is called Nuqan. And Zawzan [Khaf, Iran] (4), and Asfarayin [Esfarayen, Iran] (5) on the main road of Jurjan. The country was conquered by Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Kurayz during the caliphate of Uthman in the year thirty. Its people are a mixture of Arabs and non-Arabs. Its drinking water is from springs and valleys. Its land tax reaches four million dirhams. It is included in the land tax of Khurasan. Work is done there in all [fields]. Abdullah ibn Tahir (6) settled in the city of Nishapur and did not pass it to Marw as the governors used to do. He built a wonderful structure there (Al-Shadhiyakh) (7) and then built the Minaret.

Some of the people of Tahir informed me that from Nishapur to Marw [Merv, Turkmenistan] is ten stages. From Nishapur to Herat [Herat, Afghanistan] (1) is ten stages. From Nishapur to Jurjan is ten stages. From Nishapur to Al-Damghan is ten stages. From Nishapur on the main road and the great line to Sarakhs [Sarakhs, Iran/Turkmenistan] (2) is six stages. The first of the stages is Qasr al-Rih [Palace of the Wind] (3), called in Persian Dizbad, then Khaksar, then Mazdawran, and it has a clay steep pass. Sarakhs is a majestic land and its city is great. It is in a wilderness among sands, containing a mixture of people. It was conquered by Abdullah ibn Khazim Al-Sulami (4), who was at that time acting on behalf of Abdullah ibn Amir ibn...

...Kurayz during the caliphate of Uthman. Its people drink from wells; it has no river or spring. In it are a people from [...] (1) and the amount of its land tax is one million dirhams, included in the land tax of Khurasan. Marw. From Sarakhs on the great line to Marw [Merv, Turkmenistan] (2) is six stages. The first is Ishtar Maghak, then Talistana, then Al-Dandanqan (3), then Kanukard, which are the estates of the family of Ali ibn Hisham ibn Farrukh-Khusrow. These stations are in a desert wilderness. Every station among them has a fortress in which its people fortify themselves against the Turks because they might raid some of these stations. Then Marw, which is the most majestic of the districts of Khurasan. It was conquered by Hatim ibn Al-Nu'man Al-Bahili, acting on behalf of Abdullah ibn Amir during the caliphate of Uthman. It is said that Al-Ahnaf ibn Qays (4) attended its conquest, and that was in the year thirty-one,

and its people are nobles from the non-Arab Dihqans. In it are a people of the Arabs from Al-Azd (1), Tamim, and others. It was the residence of the governors of Khurasan. The first to settle in it was Al-Ma'mun, then whoever governed Khurasan afterwards, until Abdullah ibn Tahir settled in Nishapur. The people of Marw drink from flowing springs and valleys. Its land tax is included in the land tax of Khurasan. In it are made the fine garments described as garments of Khurasan. Among its districts are the district of Zarq (2), Urm Kilbaq, Sawsaqan (3), and Jarara (4). From Marw to Amul [Turkmenabat, Turkmenistan] (5) is six stages. The first is Kushmahan (6), from which comes the Kushmahani raisins. The rest of the stages are in wilderness and fortresses. This is what is on the great line of the districts of Khurasan. The people of Amul drink from wells except for what...

...is near them of the Jayhun [Amu Darya] (1), which is the River of Balkh (2). As for what is to the right of the great line adjacent to the Sea of India [Indian Ocean/Arabian Sea direction] (3), from Nishapur to Herat [Herat, Afghanistan] to the right towards the east is ten stages. Herat is one of the most populated lands of Khurasan and its people have the most beautiful faces. It was conquered by Al-Ahnaf ibn Qays during the caliphate of Uthman. Its people are nobles from the non-Arabs, and in it are a people of the Arabs. Its drinking water is from springs and valleys. Its land tax is included in the land tax of Khurasan. Bushanj. From Herat to Bushanj [Zindajan, Afghanistan] (4) is one stage. Bushanj is the land of Tahir ibn Al-Husayn ibn Mus'ab (5).

It was conquered by Aws ibn Tha'labah al-Taymi and al-Ahnaf ibn Qays, both acting under Abdullah ibn Amir during the Caliphate of Uthman. Its people are a mix of non-Arabs (Ajam), with a small number of Arabs. 

Badghis
From Bushanj to Badghis (1) is three stages. Badghis was conquered by Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah (2) during the days of Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan.

Sijistan
From Bushanj to Sijistan (3) is five stages, and it is said seven stages in Mujaba. It is a majestic country, and its greatest city is Bust (4). Ma'n ibn Za'idah al-Shaybani (5) settled there, and he was there during

the Caliphate of Abu Ja'far al-Mansur. Its people are a group of non-Arabs, and most of them say: They are transplants from Yemen (1) from Himyar (2). It has districts (Kuwar) like those in Khorasan, and more, except that it is cut off, connected to the lands of Sindh and India. It used to match Khorasan and parallel it. Among its districts are: The district of Bust, the district of Jowayin (3), the district of Rukhkhaj (4), the district of Khashk (5), the district of Bilmar, the district of Khwash (6), and the district of Zaranj (7) the Great, which is the city of the King [Rutbil] (8). It is four farsakhs, surrounded by a trench, has five gates, and a river cuts through

its middle called: The Helmand (Hindmand) (1). Tubba' al-Yamani (2) came to it and stayed there. And the district of Zaliq (3), and the district of Sanarudh (4). It has a river called: The Helmand, which comes from towering mountains. No one crosses to it from any country except through a desert. It borders Makran (5) from the lands of Sindh,

and Kandahar (1). The first to conquer it was al-Rabi' ibn Ziyad al-Harithi (2). He crossed the desert, which is seventy-five farsakhs, and reached Zaranj, which is the Great City where the kings were. That was during the Caliphate of Uthman. He did not pass the place called: Al-Qarnayn (3). Then Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah ibn Habib ibn Abd Shams went to it. Then Sijistan closed up (rebelled) until the Caliphate of Mu'awiyah. Then Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah was appointed governor, so he conquered the lands and went to Kerman and conquered it. Then he returned to Sijistan and made peace with its people. Then it closed up until al-Rabi' ibn Ziyad al-Harithi went to it. Then it closed up until Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Bakrah governed it.

Governors of Sijistan
Al-Rabi' ibn Ziyad al-Harithi for Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Kurayz during the Caliphate of Uthman. And Rab'i ibn Kas al-Anbari al-Kufi on behalf of Abdullah ibn Abbas during the Caliphate of the Commander of the Faithful Ali ibn Abi Talib (4), blessings of Allah be upon him. And Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah also in the days of Mu'awiyah, and he died there.

And al-Rabi' ibn Ziyad al-Harithi also on behalf of Ziyad in the days of Mu'awiyah. And Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Bakrah (1) on behalf of Ziyad in the days of Mu'awiyah. And Abbad ibn Ziyad (2) after the death of Ziyad governed Sijistan for Mu'awiyah. And Yazid ibn Ziyad on behalf of Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah. And Talhah ibn Abdullah ibn Khalaf

al-Khuza'i (1) on behalf of Salm ibn Ziyad, and Talhah ibn Abdullah died in Sijistan. And Abd al-Aziz ibn Abdullah ibn Amir on behalf of al-Qubba' (2), who is al-Harith ibn Abdullah al-Makhzumi, the governor of Ibn al-Zubayr (3) over Basra. Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr came to Iraq as a governor on behalf of his brother and confirmed Abd al-Aziz over Sijistan, and he was a brave horseman. And Abdullah ibn Adi ibn Haritha ibn Rabi'ah ibn Abd al-Aziz ibn Abd Shams on behalf of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan. And Umayyah ibn Abdullah ibn Khalid ibn Asid ibn Abi al-Ays ibn Umayyah (4) on behalf of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan. Then Abdullah ibn Umayyah ibn Abdullah ibn Khalid ibn Asid on behalf of his father. And Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Bakrah on behalf of al-Hajjaj (5) in the days of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan.

Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Bakrah died in Sijistan. When death approached Ubayd Allah ibn Abi Bakrah, he appointed his son Abu Bardha'ah as successor. Then al-Hajjaj wrote to al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufra (1) assigning him the governorship of Sijistan along with Khorasan. So al-Muhallab appointed Waki' ibn Bakr ibn Wa'il al-Azdi over Sijistan. Then al-Hajjaj appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath al-Kindi. People advised him not to do so, but he did not accept. So he [Ibn al-Ash'ath] disobeyed and revolted against al-Hajjaj and marched against him and fought him. Then he returned to Sijistan defeated. Al-Hajjaj wrote to Rutbil, the king, to seize Abd al-Rahman and send him to him. So he seized him, bound him, and sent him with al-Hajjaj's messengers. Abd al-Rahman threw himself from a roof he was on, broke his neck, and died in Rukhkhaj.

Peace was concluded between al-Hajjaj and Rutbil, the king of Sijistan. Al-Hajjaj appointed Amarah ibn Tamim al-Lakhmi, but Rutbil disliked him, so al-Hajjaj removed him. Al-Hajjaj appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Sulaym al-Kinani, then al-Hajjaj removed him after a year, and appointed Masma' ibn Malik ibn Masma' al-Shaybani. Masma' died in Sijistan and appointed his nephew Muhammad ibn Shayban ibn Malik as successor. So al-Hajjaj employed al-Ashhab ibn Bishr al-Kalbi from the people of Khorasan. Then al-Hajjaj added Sijistan along with Khorasan to Qutaybah ibn Muslim al-Bahili (1). So he sent his brother Amr ibn Muslim. Then al-Hajjaj wrote to him to march to Sijistan himself. So he marched in the year ninety-two in the days of al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik (2). Qutaybah departed from Sijistan, and

Abd Rabbih ibn Abdullah ibn Umayr al-Laythi took control of it. He stayed there for a period. Then something reached [Qutaybah] about him that he disapproved of, so he sent in his place Mani' ibn Mu'awiyah ibn Farwah al-Minqari and ordered him to torture him until he took what had come to him. Mani' did not do that, so Qutaybah removed Mani' ibn Farwah and employed al-Nu'man ibn Awf al-Yashkuri. He tortured Abd Rabbih ibn Abdullah until he killed him. Sulayman ibn Abd al-Malik appointed Yazid ibn al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufra over Iraq. Yazid employed his brother Mudrik ibn al-Muhallab (1) over Sijistan. Rutbil did not give him anything, so Yazid ibn al-Muhallab removed his brother Mudrik and appointed his son Mu'awiyah ibn Yazid [ibn] al-Muhallab. Then Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz (2) assumed power and employed Adi ibn Artah al-Fazari (3) over Iraq. Adi appointed al-Jarrah ibn Abdullah al-Hakami over Khorasan and added Sijistan to him. Then he removed him and appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Nu'aym al-Ghamidi. Al-Sari ibn Abdullah ibn Asim ibn Masma' was over Sijistan, and Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz confirmed him.

Then Yazid ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan (1) assumed power. He appointed Ibn Hubayra al-Fazari over Iraq. Ibn Hubayra employed al-Qa'qa' ibn Suwayd ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Uways ibn Bujayr ibn Uways al-Minqari from the people of Kufa over Sijistan. Then Ibn Hubayra removed al-Qa'qa' and appointed al-Sayyal ibn al-Mundhir ibn al-Nu'man al-Shaybani. In all these years, Rutbil was resisting them. Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan (2) assumed power. He appointed Khalid ibn Abdullah al-Qasri (3) over Iraq. So he appointed Yazid ibn al-Gharif al-Hamdani from the people of Jordan over Sijistan, while Rutbil was resisting.

Then Khalid ibn Abdullah al-Qasri removed Yazid ibn al-Gharif and appointed al-Asfah ibn Abdullah al-Kalbi over Sijistan. He remained in Sijistan until Khalid removed him and appointed Abdullah ibn Abi Burdah ibn Abi Musa al-Ash'ari. He remained governor until Khalid ibn Abdullah was removed and Yusuf ibn Umar al-Thaqafi (1) was appointed. When Yusuf ibn Umar governed Iraq for Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik, he appointed Ibrahim ibn Asim al-Uqayli over Sijistan. So he went to Sijistan and carried Abdullah ibn Abi Burdah in chains to Yusuf. Then Yazid ibn al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik assumed power. He employed Mansur ibn Jumhur (2) over Iraq. Mansur employed Yazid ibn Azzan al-Kalbi over Sijistan. Then Abdullah ibn Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz governed Iraq and appointed Harb ibn Qatan ibn al-Mukhariq al-Hilali over Sijistan. Then Abdullah ibn Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz sent Sa'id ibn Umar ibn Yahya ibn al-Aas al-A'war, but the people of Sijistan expelled him from the country. Bujayr ibn al-Salhab from Bakr ibn Wa'il forged

a covenant in the name of Abdullah ibn Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz, and conflict occurred between Bakr (1) and Tamim. Yazid ibn Umar ibn Hubayra al-Fazari (2) governed Iraq and sent Amir ibn Dubarah al-Murri (3) to Sijistan, but he did not reach it. The state of Banu Hashim (4) came, so Abu Muslim sent Malik ibn al-Haytham al-Khuza'i (5) to

Sijistan. He said: "O people of Sijistan, there is war between us and you until you hand over those of the people of Sham who are with you." They said: "We will ransom them." So they ransomed them for a million [dirhams] and expelled the people of Sham from Sijistan. Then Abu Muslim sent Umar ibn al-Abbas ibn Umayr ibn Utarid ibn Hajib ibn Zurarah over Sijistan. He was highly regarded by Abu Muslim. The people of Sijistan killed his brother Ibrahim ibn al-Abbas (1), and war broke out between them and him. So Abu Muslim sent Abu al-Najm Imran ibn Isma'il ibn Imran to him and told him: "Catch up with Umar ibn al-Abbas. If he has been killed, then you are the Emir of the country." Then Abu Ja'far al-Mansur appointed Ibrahim ibn Hamid al-Marwarrudhi, then removed him. Al-Mansur appointed Ma'n ibn Za'idah ibn Matar ibn Sharik al-Shaybani. He settled in Bust and fought the resisters. Ma'n governed badly, and the people suffered every affliction from him. So they hid swords in bundles of reeds, then jumped on him and killed him. The one who killed him was a man from the people of Taq (2), a district of the districts of Zaranj. That was in the year one hundred and fifty-six. Yazid (3) ibn Mazyad ibn [Za'idah] (4) stayed fighting the people. So Abu Ja'far sent Tamim ibn Amr from

Taym Allah ibn Tha'labah to aid Yazid ibn Mazyad. He arrived in the country and carried a group to Abu Ja'far. Yazid ibn Mazyad came to Iraq. Then Abu Ja'far removed Tamim ibn Amr and appointed Ubayd Allah ibn al-Ala' from Banu Bakr ibn Wa'il over Sijistan. Abu Ja'far died while he was over it. Then it became joined to the [districts] (1) of Khorasan; they appointed men over it on their behalf. That is because the Shurat (Kharijites) (2) dominated it and increased in it. The land tax of Sijistan reaches ten million dirhams, distributed among its armies, its garrison, and its frontiers.

Kerman
Kerman (3) is to the right of Sijistan, paralleling al-Juzjan (4). The greatest city of Kerman is al-Sirjan (5). It is impregnable and majestic; its brave man is a hero. Among its cities and castles are Bimand (6), Khannab (7), Kuhistan, Karistan, Maghun Tamaskan, Sarusaqan, the Citadel of Bam, Manujan, and Narmashir (8).

The country is vast and majestic, but its waters are few. It has many date palms in a city called Jirabt (1). From it, one travels to India from Jirabt to al-Ratq and al-Dahqan (2), then to al-Ball and al-Fahraj (3) - its people call it Fahrah - which is the last city of the district of Kerman. The ruler of Makran claims it is from his district. Then to al-Kharuj, which is the first city of the district of Makran. Then to the city of Fanzbur, which is the Great City of Makran. Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah ibn Habib ibn Abd Shams conquered Kerman and made peace with its king for two million dirhams and two thousand slaves. That was during the Caliphate of Uthman.

As for the countries from Sarakhs to the Indian Sea:

Al-Taliqan
From the city of Sarakhs to al-Taliqan (4) is four stages. Al-Taliqan is between two great mountains. It has a congregational mosque due to its capacity, where people gather on Friday. In it, Taliqani felts are made. From al-Taliqan to al-Faryab (5) is four stages. Al-Faryab is the old city. The second city is called Yahudan, where the governor of al-Faryab resides.

Al-Juzjan
From al-Faryab to al-Juzjan is five stages. It has four cities. The city of al-Juzjan is called Anbar, where the governors reside. The second is called Asan and Sam'akan. The third, where the King of al-Juzjan used to live, is called Kundram (1) and Qurzuman. The fourth is called Shaburqan (2). It had a kingdom in former days. Al-Juzjan parallels Kerman on the land of India.

Balkh
From al-Juzjan to Balkh for one taking the eastern route is four stages. Balkh has districts and cities. Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah conquered it in the days of Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan. The city of Balkh is the Great City of Khorasan. In it, the King Tarkhan, King of Khorasan, used to reside. It is of great standing, having two walls, a wall behind a wall. In former days it had three. It has twelve gates. It is said: The city of Balkh is the center of Khorasan. From it to Fergana is thirty stages eastward. From it to Rayy is thirty stages westward. From it to Sijistan is thirty stages towards the Qibla (south). From it to Kabul and Kandahar is thirty stages. From it to Kerman is thirty stages. From it to Kashmir (3) is thirty stages. From it to Khwarazm is thirty stages.

From it to Multan (1) is thirty stages. A great wall used to surround the villages of Balkh, its estates, and its farms. From a gate of the wall surrounding the farms and villages to the gate opposite it is twelve farsakhs. Outside the wall there is no construction, estate, or village; rather outside it are sands. This Great Wall surrounding the land of Balkh has twelve gates. The second wall surrounding the suburb of the city has four gates. From the Great Wall to the second wall is five farsakhs. A wall on the city between the suburb wall and the city wall is a farsakh. In the suburb is al-Nawbahar (2), which are the residences of the Barmakids. From the gate of the city wall to the gate opposite it is a farsakh. Thus, the area of the city was three miles by three miles. Balkh has forty-seven pulpits (minbars) in cities that are not huge: a city called Khulm (3), a city called Samangan (4), a city called Baghlan (5), a city called

Sakalkand (1), a city called Walwalij (2), a city called Hawzah, a city called Arhan (3), a city called Rawin (4), a city called Tarakan, a city called Nurin, a city called Badakhshan (5), and a city called Jarm (6), which is the last of the eastern cities adjacent to Balkh towards the region of the land of Tibet. As for the cities on the right of the East, the first of them is a city called Khast (7), a city called Panjhar (8), a city called Parwan, and a city called Ghorwand. Al-Fadl ibn Yahya ibn Khalid ibn Barmak (9) conquered it in the days of al-Rashid. It was fortified, and it is among the cities of

Kabul Shah. These cities are between the Great City of Balkh and Bamiyan. Then the city of Bamiyan (1), which is a city on a mountain. There was a Dehghan man there called Asad, which is "Sher" in Persian. He converted to Islam at the hands of Muzahim ibn Bistam in the days of al-Mansur. Muzahim ibn Bistam married his daughter to Muhammad ibn Muzahim, surnamed Abu Harb. When al-Fadl ibn Yahya came to Khorasan, he sent a son of his called al-Hasan to Ghorwand, so he conquered it with a group of commanders. He made him king over Bamiyan and named him after his grandfather Sher-Bamiyan. It is one of the cities of First Tokharistan. Water springs issue from the mountain of Bamiyan. A valley flows from it to Kandahar, a journey of a month. Another river flows from another ravine to Sijistan, a journey of a month. Another river flows to Merv, a journey of thirty days. Another river flows out to Balkh, a journey of twelve days. And another river to Khwarazm, a journey of forty days. All these rivers issue from the mountain of Bamiyan due to its height. In it are mines of copper, lead, and mercury. On the left of the East are cities: a city called Termez (2), a city called Sarmanagan, a city called Darzanka (3), and a city called al-Chaghaniyan (4), which is the largest of

the cities on the left of the East from the city of Balkh. A city [called] Kharun (1), a city called Masand, a city Barsan, a city called Kabr Sara', a city called Qabadhiyan (2), a city called Yuz (3) - which is the land of Hatim ibn Dawood - a city called Wakhsh (4), a city called Halaward, a city called Karbank, a city Idishara', a city called Rustabik - which is the kingdom of al-Harith ibn Asad ibn Bayk, owner of the Bayki beasts - a city called Hulbuk, and a city called Mank, which is the border to the land of the Turks to the place called Rasht, Kumad, and Bamir. Adjacent to the north among the cities of Balkh: a city called Darya Hanin, its interpretation is the Iron Gate. A city called Kesh (5), a city called Nakhshab (6), and a city called Sogd, and from it to the kingdom of Samarkand. As for the countries that are to the right of the river of Balkh and towards the Qibla (south): from Balkh towards the Qibla to Tokharistan and to Andarab (7), and to Bamiyan, which is the first of the western kingdoms of Lower Tokharistan. It is in a great mountain and impregnable citadel. Then to Badakhshan, and to the city of Kabul Shah, an impregnable city

fortified, inaccessible, called Hazarbadin. It is unreachable due to the rough mountains, rugged paths, difficult valleys, and impregnable castles before it. It has a road from Kerman and a road from Sijistan. In it is an impregnable king who hardly renders obedience. However, when al-Fadl ibn Yahya ibn Khalid ibn Barmak governed Khorasan for al-Rashid in the year one hundred and seventy-six (1), he sent armies to the land of Kabul Shah led by Ibrahim ibn Jibril. He mobilized the kings from the lands of Tokharistan and the Dehghans with him. Among the kings was al-Hasan the Sher, King of Bamiyan. They went to the lands and conquered the city of Ghorwand, the Pass of Ghorwand, Sarhud, Sadal Istan, and Shah Bahar, where the idol they worship is located; so it was demolished and burned with fire. Some kings of the cities of Kabul Shah sought safety from al-Fadl ibn Yahya: the people of the city of Kawsan with 'Afriks their king, the people of the city of al-Mazran, and the people of the city of Sarhard with their kings. So he granted them safety and they sent hostages. The Great City of Kabul, which is called Jarus, was conquered by Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah in the Caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan. It is closed off at this time, except that merchants enter it and carry large Kabuli Myrobalan.

Merv al-Rudh
As for the countries from the city of Merv to the city of Balkh: From the city of Merv to Merv al-Rudh (2) is five stages. Merv al-Rudh was conquered by al-Ahnaf ibn Qays, acting under Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Kurayz in the Caliphate of Uthman in the year thirty-one. From Merv al-Rudh to Balkh. Whoever travels from it to Zamm, which is on the river of Balkh, and to Amul, which is also on the river of Balkh, between it and Merv is six journeys. These are the countries adjacent to the Indian Sea from the districts of Khorasan. As for the countries to the right of the river of Balkh: Termez is a majestic city on the Great River of Balkh on its eastern bank, because the city of Balkh is on the western bank of the river. It is a populous city,

wide. Beside Termez on the river also is the city of al-Qawadhiyan (1), a peer of Termez. Then from it to the kingdom of Hashim ibn Banijur, which are Wakhsh and Halaward, two majestic cities possessing defenses. Then to the city of Shuman, which is connected to the kingdom of Hashim ibn Banijur and the family of Hashim. Then al-Ahad Yali, which is the city of Dawood ibn Abi Dawood. Then to al-Washjird (2), which is a city of a great frontier, and a vast country containing seven hundred fortified castles, for they raid the Turks. Between them and the land of Turkestan is four farsakhs. From Termez to al-Chaghaniyan is four stages. Al-Chaghaniyan is a majestic vast country containing districts and several cities, among the districts are Hardan, Naharan, and Kasak. From al-Chaghaniyan to the kingdom of al-Khuttal is three stages. The Great City of al-Khuttal and Washjird, which we mentioned has seven hundred castles and borders the Turks.

Khuttal
From al-Khuttal (3) to Upper Bukharistan and the kingdom of Himarbak: King of Shughnan and Badakhshan. From it the Great Valley to Shughnan. All this is the kingdom of Upper Tokharistan. What is beyond the river of Balkh on the Great Line: The first of that is the city of Farbr, which is Merv [sic - likely means gate to Merv or related]. That is because the Turks come to this city, so the people of Merv and what is connected to it mobilize to it. From Farbr to Bakand is a stage. Bakand is a majestic city with a mix of people. From Bakand to the city of Bukhara (4) is two stages.

Bukhara (1)
Bukhara (2) is a vast country with a mix of people, Arabs and non-Arabs. It has always been strongly fortified. Sa'id ibn Uthman ibn Affan conquered (3) Bukhara (4) in the days of Mu'awiyah (5). Then he left it intending for Samarkand, so its people resisted. It remained closed off until Salm ibn Ziyad conquered it in the days of Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah. Then it rebelled and resisted until Qutaybah ibn Muslim al-Bahili came to it in the days of al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik and conquered it. The land tax of the country, meaning the country of Bukhara (6), reaches one million dirhams. Their dirhams resemble copper.

Sogd
From Bukhara (7) to the land of Sogd (8) for one taking towards the Qibla (south) is seven stages. The land of Sogd

is vast. It has majestic, impregnable, fortified cities, including: Dabbusiyah (1), Kushaniyah (2), Kesh, and Nasaf (3), which is Nakhshab. These districts, meaning the districts of Sogd, were conquered by Qutaybah ibn Muslim al-Bahili in the days of al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik.

Samarkand
From Kesh to the Great City of Sogd is four stages. Samarkand (4) is among the most majestic countries, greatest in standing, most impregnable, having the most men, fiercest heroes, and most patient warriors. It is the throat of the Turks. Samarkand closed up after being conquered several times due to its impregnability, the bravery of its men, and the intensity of its heroes. Qutaybah ibn Muslim al-Bahili conquered it in the days of al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik and made peace with its Dehghans and kings. It had a great wall which collapsed, so al-Rashid, Commander of the Faithful, built it. It has a great river coming from the lands of the Turks like the Euphrates called: Basif. It flows in the land of Samarkand, then to the lands of Sogd, then to Ushrusana (5). It encompasses the lands of Samarkand, Ishtakhanj,

Ushrusana, and Shash. From Samarkand to Ushrusana, the kingdom of Afshin, is five stages eastward. The kingdom of Ushrusana is vast and majestic; it is said that it has four hundred fortresses. It has several large cities, including: Arsamanda, Zamin (1), Manik, and Hisnak. It has a great valley coming from Basif, the river of Samarkand. Gold ingots are found in that valley. There is no gold in any place in Khorasan except what has reached me that is found in this valley. In all the cities of Khorasan there are people from the Arabs of Mudar (2), Rabi'ah (3), and other clans of Yemen, except in Ushrusana. They used to prevent Arabs from being their neighbors until a man from Banu Shayban came to them, stayed there, and married among them. From the city of Ushrusana to Fergana is two stages.

Fergana
The city of Fergana (4) where the King resides is called Kasan. It is a city of great standing and great importance. All these cities are annexed to the district of Samarkand.

Ishtakhanj
Ishtakhanj (5) is a majestic city with fortresses and districts. It was a separate kingdom and

Al-Mu'tasim made the kingdom of Ishtakhanj [under the authority of] Ujayf. From there to Samarkand [Uzbekistan] is two stages. From Ferghana to Al-Shash [Tashkent, Uzbekistan] is five stages. Al-Shash is a majestic city within the administration of Samarkand. Whoever takes [the route] from Samarkand to Al-Shash travels to Khujandah [Khujand, Tajikistan], which is one of the cities of Samarkand, seven stages away. Then from Khujandah to Al-Shash is four stages. Al-Shash. From Al-Shash (1) to the Great Frontier of Isfijab [Sayram, Kazakhstan] is two stages. It is the land from which the Turks are fought, and it is the end of the administration of Samarkand. This is Transoxiana (Ma Wara' al-Nahr), including the cities of Tukharistan [Afghanistan/Tajikistan], Sogdia, Samarkand, Al-Shash, and Ferghana, on the main route. Beyond that are the lands of polytheism, and the generality of the lands of the Turks surrounding Khorasan and Sijistan [Sistan] is Turkestan. The Turks are several races and several kingdoms, among them: the Kharlukhiyya (Karluks), the Taghazghuz (Toquz Oghuz), Turgesh, Kimak, and Ghuzz (Oghuz). Each race of the Turks has a separate kingdom, and they fight one another. They have no [permanent] dwellings or fortresses; rather, they inhabit ribbed Turkish tents (yurts), and their nails are straps from the hides of beasts and cattle, and their coverings are felts. They are the most skilled people in making felts because they are their clothing. There is no cultivation in Turkestan except millet (Dukhn), which is Jawars. Their food is only the milk of mares, and they eat their meat, and most of what they eat is game meat. Iron is scarce among them, and they make their arrows from bones. Yet they surround the land of Khorasan and fight from every direction and raid. There is no land among the lands of Khorasan but that they fight the Turks, and the Turks of other races fight them. These are the cities of Khorasan and Sijistan and their districts, and the distance between every city and its conditions. Let us mention now their governors since they were conquered to this end, and the amount of their land tax (Kharaj).

The Governors of Khorasan. The first to enter Khorasan was Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Kurayz ibn Rabi'ah ibn Habib ibn Abd Shams. Uthman ibn Affan wrote to him in the year thirty, and he was at that time over Basra [Iraq]. And he wrote to Sa'id ibn al-Aas ibn Umayyah ibn Abd Shams (1), who was his governor in Kufa [Iraq], ordering them both to proceed to Khorasan, and saying to each of them that if he preceded to Khorasan, he is the Amir over it. A letter from the King of Tus [Iran] had reached Abdullah ibn Amir saying to him: "I will anticipate you [give you precedence] on condition that you make me king over Nishapur." So he preceded with him (or by him). He wrote a document for him that remains with his descendants to this end. So Abdullah ibn Amir conquered several districts of Khorasan in the year thirty-one. On his vanguard was Abdullah ibn Khazim al-Sulami, and with him was Al-Ahnaf ibn Qays al-Tamimi. Then Abdullah ibn Amir departed and appointed Qays ibn al-Haytham ibn Asma' ibn al-Salt al-Sulami over Khorasan, and left Al-Ahnaf ibn Qays with him. Then Abdullah appointed Hatim ibn al-Nu'man al-Bahili, so he stayed in Khorasan conquering and raiding until Uthman was killed in the year thirty-five. The Commander of the Faithful Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, appointed Ja'dah ibn Hubayrah ibn Amr ibn 'A'idh al-Makhzumi over Khorasan. Mahuyah, the Marzban (Satrap) of Marw [Merv, Turkmenistan], had come to Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, while he was in Basra, and made peace with him. He wrote a document for him while he was in Marw [that remained] to this end. When Ali, peace be upon him, was killed, Mu'awiyah appointed Abdullah ibn Amir over Khorasan. Ibn Amir sent Abdullah ibn Khazim al-Sulami and Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah to it. They traveled together and descended upon Balkh [Afghanistan] until they conquered it.

Then Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah departed and handed over Khorasan to Abdullah ibn Khazim al-Sulami. Then Mu'awiyah appointed Ziyad ibn Abi Sufyan over Basra, Khorasan, and Sijistan. Ziyad sent Al-Hakam ibn Amr al-Ghifari (1), the Companion of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as Amir to Khorasan. He went out to Khorasan in the year forty-four. He was of good conduct and virtuous ways. Ziyad wrote to him when he conquered what he conquered of the districts of Khorasan: "The Commander of the Faithful Mu'awiyah wrote to me to select for him the white and the yellow (silver and gold), so do not distribute anything of the gold and silver." Al-Hakam did not pay attention to his letter; he took out the fifth (Khums) and distributed what remained among the people. He wrote to Ziyad: "I found the Book of Allah before the letter of the Commander of the Faithful Mu'awiyah. 'And if the heavens and the earth were closed up against a servant, then he feared Allah, Allah would make for him a way out from them.' Peace." Al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufrah was one of the men of Al-Hakam ibn Amr. Al-Hakam died in Khorasan. Then Ziyad sent Al-Rabi' ibn Ziyad ibn Anas ibn al-Dayyan ibn Qatan ibn Ziyad al-Harithi (2) as Amir over Khorasan, and Al-Hasan al-Basri (3) was his scribe. Mu'awiyah appointed Khalid ibn Ma'mar...

...al-Sadusi (1) over Khorasan. He traveled intending for it, but Ziyad slipped poison to him, so he died and did not reach Khorasan. Ziyad appointed Abdullah ibn Rabi' ibn Ziyad over Khorasan in place of his father, then removed him and appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Samurah ibn Habib. Then Ziyad died, so Mu'awiyah confirmed Abd al-Rahman over Sijistan and appointed Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad over Khorasan. He dispatched him with armies and ordered him to cross the river from the lands of Tukharistan. He went out with a gathering and raided the lands of Tukharistan (2), with Al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufrah managing the affair and in charge of the war. Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad stayed in Khorasan for two years, then returned to Mu'awiyah, leaving Aslam ibn Zur'ah ibn Amr ibn al-Sa'q al-Kilabi as deputy over Khorasan. [Mu'awiyah] appointed Ubaydullah over Basra and appointed his brother Abdullah ibn Ziyad over Khorasan. He stayed four months, but his weakness and insignificance reached him [Mu'awiyah], so he removed him. After Abdullah ibn Ziyad, Mu'awiyah appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Ziyad over Khorasan, but he did not praise him, so he removed him. Mu'awiyah appointed Sa'id ibn Uthman. Sa'id ibn Uthman had refused and spoken to him with harsh words, so he proceeded to Khorasan and raided Samarkand. It is said: He was the first to cross to Transoxiana. He raided Tukharistan, Bukhara [Uzbekistan] (3), and Samarkand. Aslam ibn Zur'ah al-Kilabi was in charge of the Kharaj (land tax) of Khorasan. Sa'id ibn Uthman demanded the money from him, but he did not give it to him and began sending it to Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad, who was the Amir of Basra. Then Aslam ibn Zur'ah fled from Khorasan and wrote to Mu'awiyah about his news and that Sa'id ibn Uthman wanted to take...

...the money. So Mu'awiyah removed Sa'id ibn Uthman and appointed Aslam ibn Zur'ah. Aslam went out to Khorasan until he reached Marw al-Shahijan (1), where Sa'id ibn Uthman was. Aslam was with a dense gathering. Some of his companions pierced the pavilion of Sa'id ibn Uthman with a spear and killed a slave girl of his. He wrote to Mu'awiyah, who wrote to him and to Aslam: "Both of you come to me." Qutham ibn al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib had gone out to Sa'id ibn Uthman and died in Marw. Malik ibn al-Rayb (2) the poet was with Sa'id ibn Uthman, and Yazid ibn Rabi'ah ibn Mufarrigh al-Himyari (3) was with him. Sa'id ibn Uthman departed from Khorasan. Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad appointed his brother Abbad ibn Ziyad over Khorasan. He went out to it and took Yazid ibn Mufarrigh as a companion. Ibn Mufarrigh left Sa'id and accompanied him [Abbad], but did not praise him nor his companionship; he is where he satirized him and the family of Ziyad.

Then he appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Ziyad over Khorasan. He departed from it and left Qays ibn al-Haytham al-Sulami (1) as deputy. Then Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah appointed Salm ibn Ziyad over Khorasan. Between him and his brother Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad was severe obstinacy. Al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufrah, Abdullah ibn Khazim, Talhah ibn Abdullah ibn Khalaf al-Khuza'i - who is Talhat al-Talhat -, Umar ibn Ubaydullah ibn Ma'mar al-Taymi (2), Abbad ibn Husayn al-Habati (3), Imran ibn Fudayl al-Burjumi, and others from the notables of the people of Basra went out with him. Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad demolished the houses of all who went out with his brother. Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah wrote to him to rebuild them with gypsum, baked brick, and teak from his own money, so he built them. Salm raided Khwarazm [Khwarezm] and conquered the city of Kandakin (4) and Bukhara (5). Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah died, and the fitna of Ibn al-Zubayr occurred. Salm departed and appointed Arfajah ibn al-Ward al-Sa'di as deputy. Abdullah ibn Khazim al-Sulami traveled with Salm following him, but he sent him back and wrote his appointment over Khorasan. When he returned, Arfajah refused to hand over to him, so they fought with arrows. An arrow hit Arfajah and he died. Abdullah ibn Khazim stayed in Khorasan raiding and conquering, being in obedience to Ibn al-Zubayr, until Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan killed Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr. He sent his head to Abdullah ibn Khazim and wrote inviting him to his obedience. He took Mus'ab's head, washed it, perfumed it, shrouded it, and buried it. He answered Abd al-Malik...

...with a harsh answer and did not accept what Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan offered him. The people of Khorasan rose against him and killed him. Waki' ibn al-Dawraqiyyah killed him and pledged allegiance to Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, and they sent his head to him. When matters stabilized for Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, he appointed Umayyah ibn Abdullah ibn Khalid ibn Asid ibn Abi al-Ays ibn Umayyah ibn Abd Shams over Khorasan. Umayyah crossed to Transoxiana and reached Bukhara (1), then left Bukayr ibn Wassaj (2) over it and returned. Umayyah continued over Khorasan until Al-Hajjaj governed Iraq. When Al-Hajjaj took charge, he wrote to Abd al-Malik informing him that the affair of Khorasan had become disordered, so he [Abd al-Malik] returned the command to him. He appointed Al-Muhallab ibn Abi Sufrah over Khorasan and Ubaydullah ibn Abi Bakra over Sijistan. When Al-Muhallab arrived in Khorasan, he stayed for a while, then marched to Tukharistan, then to Kesh [Shahrisabz, Uzbekistan], the city of Sogdia. Then Al-Muhallab fell ill and returned to Marw al-Rudh while sick from gangrene that occurred in his leg. Then Al-Muhallab died in Khorasan, having appointed his son Yazid ibn al-Muhallab as successor. He stayed for a while. Then Al-Hajjaj removed Yazid ibn al-Muhallab and appointed Al-Mufaddal ibn al-Muhallab (3) over Khorasan. He remained...

...in Khorasan until Al-Hajjaj turned against Yazid ibn al-Muhallab and imprisoned him. When Al-Hajjaj turned against Yazid ibn al-Muhallab, he wrote to Qutaybah ibn Muslim al-Bahili, who was his governor in Rayy [Iran], with the governorship of Khorasan, and ordered him to arrest Al-Mufaddal and the rest of the family of Al-Muhallab and send them to him in shackles. He did that. Qutaybah ibn Muslim arrived in Khorasan, sent the family of Al-Muhallab to Al-Hajjaj, proceeded to Bukhara (1) and conquered it. Then he proceeded to Talikan [Taloqan, Afghanistan]. 'Badham' had rebelled, so he fought him until he overcame him and killed him. Al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik became Caliph while Qutaybah was in Khorasan. His affair became great and he became strong over the country. He killed 'Nizak Tarkhan', marched to Khwarazm, then marched to Samarkand and conquered it, and made peace with 'Ghurak', the Ikhshid of Samarkand. Sulayman ibn Abd al-Malik became Caliph, and Al-Hajjaj had died months before that. He appointed Yazid ibn al-Muhallab over Iraq and ordered him to target Al-Hajjaj's associates. When this reached Qutaybah ibn Muslim, he wanted to rebel. Waki' ibn Abi Sud al-Tamimi rose against him and killed him, having no doubt that Sulayman would appoint him over Khorasan, but he did not. Sulayman appointed Yazid ibn al-Muhallab over Khorasan along with Iraq. Yazid ibn al-Muhallab went to Khorasan himself, pursued the companions of Qutaybah, imprisoned Waki' ibn Abi Sud, and inflicted every harm upon him. The districts of Khorasan opposed Yazid ibn al-Muhallab, so he dispersed his brothers and sons in the districts of Khorasan and appointed them over its works. Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz ibn Marwan became Caliph. When news of his caliphate reached Yazid, he departed from Khorasan, leaving his son Makhlad as deputy, and carried all his wealth. Some people advised him not to do so, but he did not accept. He reached Basra, and Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz had already removed him and appointed Adi ibn Artah al-Fazari. Adi compelled him to go to Umar, so he went and he imprisoned him. Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz appointed Al-Jarrah ibn Abdullah al-Hakami (2) over Khorasan and ordered him to take...

...Makhlad ibn Yazid ibn al-Muhallab (1) and secure him, so he did. Delegations from Tibet came to him asking him to send someone to teach them the religion of Islam. Then Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz removed Al-Jarrah ibn Abdullah and appointed Abd al-Rahman ibn Nu'aym al-Ghamidi, and wrote to him to transfer the families of the Muslims and their offspring from Transoxiana to Marw, but they did not do so and stayed. Yazid ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan became Caliph and appointed Maslamah ibn Abd al-Malik (2) over Iraq and Khorasan. Maslamah appointed Sa'id ibn Abd al-Aziz ibn al-Harith ibn al-Hakam ibn Abi al-Aas over Khorasan. He fought the King of Ferghana and besieged Khujandah (3) in the land of Sogdia, killing and taking captives. Then Maslamah removed him and appointed Sa'id ibn Amr al-Harashi (4) from the people of Sham. Then Khorasan and Iraq were combined...

...for Umar ibn Hubayrah al-Fazari. He appointed Muslim ibn Sa'id ibn Aslam ibn Zur'ah al-Kilabi over Khorasan. He arrived in Khorasan and raided but accomplished nothing. The people of Ferghana fought him until they defeated him. Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan became Caliph. Propagandists for Banu Hashim had appeared in Khorasan. He appointed Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Yazid ibn Asad ibn Kurz al-Qasri over Iraq and Khorasan and ordered him to send someone he trusted to Khorasan. Khalid sent his brother Asad ibn Abdullah (1). News of them [the propagandists] reached him, so he took a group he suspected and cut off their hands and feet. The disturbance of Khorasan reached Hisham, so he appointed Ashras ibn Abdullah al-Sulami (2) from his side. Then he removed him and appointed Al-Junayd ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Amr ibn al-Harith ibn Kharijah ibn Sinan al-Murri (3). Then he removed him and appointed Asim ibn Abdullah ibn Yazid al-Hilali. It reached Hisham that Khorasan had fallen into fitna (strife), so he attached it a second time to Khalid ibn Abdullah al-Qasri. He sent his brother Asad ibn Abdullah to it. Asad ibn Abdullah died in Khorasan, and Ja'far ibn Hanzalah al-Bahrani from the people of Sham was appointed deputy over it. Hisham removed Khalid ibn Abdullah from Iraq and appointed Yusuf ibn Umar al-Thaqafi, ordering him to send him a man who had knowledge of Khorasan. He sent Abd al-Karim ibn Salit ibn Atiyyah al-Hanafi to him. He asked him about Khorasan, its condition, and its men. He began recounting to him until he named Nasr ibn Sayyar al-Laythi.

He wrote his appointment over Khorasan. Before that, he was governing one of the districts of Khorasan. He removed Ja'far ibn Hanzalah and took charge of the country. He took Yahya ibn Zayd ibn Ali ibn al-Husayn (1) from Balkh and imprisoned him in the Quhandiz (citadel). He wrote to Hisham, but his letter arrived after Hisham had died. Al-Walid ibn Yazid ibn Abd al-Malik became Caliph. Yahya ibn Zayd schemed until he escaped from prison and went to the area of Nishapur. Nasr ibn Sayyar sent Salm ibn Ahwaz al-Hilali, who caught up with him in Juzjan. He fought him, and Yahya ibn Zayd was struck by a stray arrow and killed. Salm ibn Ahwaz crucified him at the gate of Juzjan. Yahya ibn Zayd remained crucified until Abu Muslim prevailed; he took him down, shrouded him, buried him, and killed everyone who had participated in his killing. The propagandists of Banu Hashim increased in Khorasan in the year one hundred and twenty-six. Nasr ibn Sayyar fought Judi' ibn Ali al-Kirmani al-Azdi (2). Al-Walid was killed, and Yazid ibn al-Walid ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan became Caliph. The affair of Khorasan was disordered, the propagandists of Banu Hashim had increased, and Rabi'ah and Yemen had withdrawn from Nasr ibn Sayyar.

Then Marwan ibn Muhammad ibn Marwan ibn al-Hakam became Caliph. The affair of Abu Muslim had appeared in Khorasan, and Nasr ibn Sayyar was too weak for him. Then Nasr sought truce and peace. Then Abu Muslim killed Nasr ibn Sayyar (1) and prevailed over Khorasan in the year one hundred and thirty. He sent his agents and men, and sent Qahtabah and others to Iraq. Abu al-Abbas Abdullah ibn Muhammad became Commander of the Faithful (Caliph), and the Blessed Hashemite State emerged. Abu Muslim stayed in Khorasan until the year one hundred and thirty-six. Then he asked Abu al-Abbas, Commander of the Faithful, for permission to perform Hajj. He permitted him, so he came to Iraq and appointed Abu Dawud Khalid ibn Ibrahim al-Dhuhli (2) as deputy over Khorasan. Abu al-Abbas, Commander of the Faithful, died, and Abu Ja'far al-Mansur became Caliph while Abu Dawud Khalid ibn Ibrahim was in Khorasan as deputy for Abu Muslim. Then Abu Muslim was killed. Sunbadh came out in Khorasan seeking vengeance for the blood of Abu Muslim. Al-Mansur sent Jahwar ibn Murrar al-Ijli against him, who defeated him, killed him, and dispersed his gathering. Abu Ja'far al-Mansur appointed Abd al-Jabbar ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Azdi (3) over Khorasan in the year...

...one hundred and forty-eight. He went out to it; he used to be in charge of Al-Mansur's police. When his wealth and numbers increased in Khorasan, he showed disobedience and openly declared rebellion. Al-Mansur sent Al-Mahdi, who fought him, captured him, and carried him to Abu Ja'far, who killed him and crucified him at Qasr Ibn Hubayrah in the year one hundred and forty-nine. Al-Mahdi's residence was in Rayy. Qarin, the Ispahbadh of Tabaristan, rebelled, so he sent Khazim ibn Khuzaymah al-Tamimi and Rawh ibn Hatim al-Muhallabi against him. Tabaristan was conquered and Qarin was captured. Al-Mahdi appointed Asid ibn Abdullah al-Khuza'i (1) over Khorasan, and he died there. Then he appointed Humayd ibn Qahtabah al-Ta'i, who stayed there for a while. Then Al-Mansur removed him and appointed Abu Awn Abd al-Malik ibn Yazid. Then he removed Abd al-Malik ibn Yazid. Al-Mahdi had become Caliph, so he returned Humayd ibn Qahtabah (2), who stayed there until he died. Then Al-Mahdi appointed Mu'adh ibn Muslim al-Razi, client of Rabi'ah, over Khorasan. Yusuf al-Barm al-Haruri had rebelled. Al-Mahdi sent Yazid ibn Mazyad ibn Za'idah al-Shaybani to fight Yusuf al-Barm. He fought him until he captured him and carried him to Al-Mahdi, who cut off his hands and feet. Then, following Yusuf al-Barm, Hakim al-A'war known as Al-Muqanna' rebelled. Mu'adh ibn Muslim was the governor of Khorasan, and with him were Uqbah ibn Salm al-Hina'i, Jibril ibn Yahya al-Bajali, and Al-Layth, client of the Commander of the Faithful. Al-Mahdi singled out Sa'id al-Harashi to fight Al-Muqanna'. He continued defeating him until he reached the land of Sogdia and fortified himself in the fortress of Baksh [?]. When the siege intensified against him, he and his companions drank poison and all died, and the fortress was conquered. Al-Mahdi removed Mu'adh ibn Muslim from Khorasan and appointed Al-Musayyab ibn Zuhayr al-Dabbi (3). Then...

...Al-Mahdi removed Al-Musayyab at the end of his caliphate and appointed Al-Fadl ibn Sulayman al-Tusi over Khorasan. He remained over it until Al-Mahdi died. In the caliphate of Musa, Harun al-Rashid appointed Ja'far ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath al-Khuza'i over Khorasan. He became paralyzed and died. He appointed his son Al-Abbas ibn Ja'far ibn al-Ash'ath in his place. Then he removed him and appointed Al-Ghitrif ibn Ata, who was Al-Rashid's maternal uncle. He did not control Khorasan, so he removed him and appointed Hamzah ibn Malik ibn al-Haytham al-Khuza'i (1). Then he removed him and appointed Al-Fadl ibn Yahya ibn Khalid ibn Barmak. He went to Balkh and conquered several districts of Tukharistan, Kabul Shah, and Shughnan. Then he removed Al-Fadl ibn Yahya ibn Khalid and appointed Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan, who was in charge of Al-Rashid's police. Ali ibn Isa arrived in Khorasan while Abu Amr al-Shari had rebelled. He fought him until he killed him. Then Hamzah al-Shari rebelled against Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan in Badghis. Ali ibn Isa marched against him, defeated him, and pursued him until he reached Kabul, where he fought him until he killed him. After Hamzah, Abu al-Khasib rebelled against him in Baward. He fought him and killed him. Majestic wealth came to Ali ibn Isa. Ali had sent Rafi' ibn al-Layth ibn Nasr ibn Sayyar ibn Rafi' al-Laythi (2) to Samarkand. Rafi' rebelled, his power intensified, and his affair became strong. It reached Al-Rashid that this was a plot by Ali ibn Isa. So he sent Harthamah ibn A'yan (3) against him, who arrested him and carried him in irons...

...to Al-Rashid, seized his wealth and carried it. He appointed Harthamah ibn A'yan al-Balkhi over Khorasan in the year one hundred and ninety-one. Then Al-Rashid went out to Khorasan, leaving his son Muhammad al-Amin as deputy in Baghdad, and took Al-Ma'mun out with him to Khorasan. The armies went out with him. When he reached Tus, he fell ill, and his illness intensified. He sent Al-Ma'mun with Harthamah and the commanders to Marw. Al-Rashid died in Tus in Jumada al-Akhirah of the year one hundred and ninety-three, and his grave is in Tus. Al-Ma'mun stayed in Marw as governor over Khorasan, its districts, and all its works. He sent Harthamah ibn A'yan to Samarkand to fight Rafi' ibn al-Layth ibn Nasr ibn Sayyar al-Laythi. He continued fighting him until he conquered Samarkand. Rafi' came out under guarantee of safety; Harthamah carried him to Al-Ma'mun, and Al-Ma'mun carried him to Muhammad and wrote to him about the victory. Al-Ma'mun stayed in Marw for the remainder of the year one hundred and ninety-three and the year one hundred and ninety-four. Then Muhammad wrote to him to come to Baghdad, and sent Al-Abbas ibn Musa ibn Isa, Muhammad ibn Isa ibn Nahik, and Salih the master of the Musalla to him. Al-Ma'mun refused to come and said: "This is a violation of the condition." So he sent Ismah ibn Abi Ismah al-Sabi'i against him with an army. Ismah stayed in Rayy and did not move. So he sent Ali ibn Isa ibn Mahan, whom he had released, to Khorasan. When this reached Al-Ma'mun, he sent Tahir ibn al-Husayn ibn Mus'ab al-Bushanji from Marw with four thousand [men]. He met Ali ibn Isa at Rayy and killed him. Then Al-Ma'mun also sent Harthamah ibn A'yan to Iraq. Al-Ma'mun remained staying in Marw...

...until Muhammad was killed at the end of Muharram in the year one hundred and ninety-eight, and allegiance was pledged to him [Al-Ma'mun] for the Caliphate. Al-Ma'mun stayed in Khorasan in the year one hundred and ninety-nine and the year two hundred, sending men to Iraq. He sent Humayd ibn Abd al-Hamid ibn Rab'i al-Ta'i al-Tusi (1). Then he sent Ali ibn Hisham ibn Khusrow al-Marw al-Rudhi. Then he sent Badi al-Alamayn Ali ibn Abi Sa'id, the cousin (maternal aunt's son) of Al-Fadl ibn Sahl, over the Kharaj of Iraq. Then he sent Al-Hasan ibn Sahl over all affairs. Harthamah returned from Iraq angry and went to Al-Ma'mun. Al-Ma'mun imprisoned him, and he died in prison after three days in Marw in the year two hundred. Then Al-Ma'mun pledged allegiance to Al-Rida Ali ibn Musa ibn Ja'far ibn Muhammad ibn Ali ibn al-Husayn ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, in Marw for the heir apparentship in the year two hundred and two. Then he left Marw in this year and traveled leisurely until he reached Sarakhs and stayed there. Al-Fadl ibn Sahl, his vizier, was killed in Sarakhs in the bathhouse. Al-Ma'mun killed a group because of him. Al-Ma'mun marched to Tus. When he arrived in Tus, he stayed there; that was in the year two hundred and three. Al-Rida, peace be upon him, died in Tus. Al-Ma'mun had corresponded with all the kings of Khorasan and conciliated them until [the land] stabilized. He appointed Raja' ibn Abi al-Dahhak, who was the husband of Al-Fadl ibn Sahl's sister, over all of Khorasan. Al-Ma'mun arrived in Baghdad in the middle of Safar in the year two hundred and four. All of Khorasan became corrupted at the hands of Raja' ibn Abi al-Dahhak. So Al-Ma'mun appointed Ghassan ibn Abbad (2) over Khorasan. He reformed it, it stabilized under his hand, and Al-Ma'mun praised him.

He stayed for the remainder of the year two hundred and four and months of the year two hundred and five. Then Tahir ibn al-Husayn ibn Mus'ab al-Bushanji schemed until Al-Ma'mun appointed him over Khorasan and gave him a covenant for it. He went out to it in the year two hundred and five. Bad opinion from Al-Ma'mun reached him, so he showed opposition without openly declaring rebellion. This reached Al-Ma'mun. It is said that he was tricked with a drink [poison]. Tahir died in the year two hundred and seven. Al-Ma'mun appointed his son Talhah ibn Tahir ibn al-Husayn in his place. He remained Amir in Khorasan for seven years with matters stable. Then Talhah ibn Tahir died in the year two hundred and fifteen. Al-Ma'mun had appointed Abdullah ibn Tahir over the districts of Al-Jabal and Azerbaijan. He went out and stayed in Dinawar sick. Al-Ma'mun appointed him over Khorasan in place of his brother Talhah ibn Tahir and sent him his covenant and contract with Ishaq ibn Ibrahim and Yahya ibn Aktham (1), the Chief Judge. Abdullah ibn Tahir went to Khorasan and settled in Nishapur; no governor of Khorasan before him had settled there. He made it his home. Abdullah ibn Tahir stayed over Khorasan and its works with stable affairs and strong authority, and all the lands were stable, for fourteen years. Then he died in Nishapur in the year two hundred and thirty, being forty-eight years old. Al-Wathiq appointed his son Tahir ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir over Khorasan. He stayed in Khorasan during the caliphates of Al-Wathiq, Al-Mutawakkil, Al-Muntasir, and part of the caliphate of Al-Musta'in. He governed it for eighteen years with stable affairs. Then he died in Nishapur in Rajab of the year two hundred and forty-eight, being forty-four years old. Al-Musta'in appointed his son Muhammad ibn Tahir ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir (2) over Khorasan. He remained governor...

...over it from the year two hundred and forty-eight to the year two hundred and fifty-nine.
