Matters had been disturbed by the rebellion of Al-Hasan ibn Zayd al-Talibi (1) in Tabaristan and others, and the rebellion of Ya'qub ibn al-Layth al-Saffar in Sijistan and his encroachment into the districts of Khorasan. Then Ya'qub ibn al-Layth al-Saffar (2) marched to Nishapur in Shawwal of the year two hundred and fifty-nine. He arrested Muhammad ibn Tahir, secured him and his family, seized their wealth and what their houses contained, and carried them in shackles to a fortress in Kerman called the Fortress of "Bam". They remained in that state until Al-Saffar died and Khorasan was empty of them. Amr ibn al-Layth (3)...

...the brother of Al-Saffar, came to possess it. The family of Tahir remained governors of Khorasan for fifty-five years; five Amirs from them governed it. With the expiration of dynasties, matters vanish, conditions change, incapacity occurs, and deficiency appears. The land tax of Khorasan used to reach in every year from all districts forty million dirhams, excluding the fifths (Akhmas) that are raised from the frontiers, all of which the family of Tahir spent as they saw fit. In addition to that, thirteen million was sent to them from Iraq, excluding gifts. This is the Eastern Quarter. We have mentioned of it what came to our mind to mention, learned its news, and described its conditions. Let us now mention the Qibla (Southern) Quarter and what is in it. And with Allah is success.

[The Second Quarter] The Qibla (Southern) Quarter. Whoever intends to go from Baghdad to Kufa and to the road of Hejaz, Medina, Mecca, and Ta'if (1). From Baghdad to Kufa is thirty farsakhs, which is three stages. The first is Qasr Ibn Hubayrah at twelve farsakhs from Baghdad. Yazid ibn Umar ibn Hubayrah al-Fazari built it in the days of Marwan ibn Muhammad ibn Marwan (2). Ibn Hubayrah was at that time Marwan's governor over Iraq, and he wanted distance from Kufa. It is a thriving, majestic city where workers and governors stay. Its people are a mix of people. It is on a river that takes from the Euphrates called Al-Sarat. Between Qasr Ibn Hubayrah and the main body of the Euphrates is about two miles to a bridge over the main body of the Euphrates called the Bridge of Sura. From Qasr Ibn Hubayrah to a place called Suq Asad (3) west of the Euphrates in the district (Tassuj)...

...called Al-Fallujah (1). From Suq Asad to Kufa. The distances from Baghdad to Kufa are through thriving, large, connected, populated villages containing a mix of non-Arabs and Arabs. Kufa is the Great City of Iraq, the Greatest Metropolis, the Dome of Islam, and the Abode of Migration of the Muslims. It is the first city planned by the Muslims in Iraq in the year fourteen. In it are the tribal quarters of the Arabs. It is on the main body of the Euphrates, and from it its people drink. It is one of the best lands, most spacious, most nutritious, and widest. Its land tax is included in the land tax of the districts of the Sawad. Its districts (Tassuj) attributed to it are: Tassuj al-Jabbah, Tassuj al-Badah, Furat Badiqla, Al-Salihin (2), and Nahr Yusuf. Al-Hirah is three miles from it. Al-Hirah is on Al-Najaf. Al-Najaf (3) was on the coast of the Salt Sea, and in ancient times it used to reach Al-Hirah. It is the dwellings of the family of Buqaylah and others. In it were the dwellings of the kings of Banu Nasr from Lakhm, who are the family of Al-Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir. Most of the people of Al-Hirah are Christians. Among them are those from Arab tribes on the religion of Christianity, from Banu Tamim the family of Adi ibn Zayd al-Ibadi the poet, and from Sulaym, Tayy, and others. Al-Khawarnaq (4) is near it towards the East; between it and Al-Hirah is three miles. Al-Sadir (5) is in a desert near it.

The Plans of Kufa. Umar ibn al-Khattab wrote to Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas (1) when he conquered Iraq, ordering him to settle in Kufa and ordering the people to mark out its plans. Each tribe marked out a plan with its leader. Umar granted land to the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Abs (2) was next to the mosque, then a group of them moved to the far end of Kufa. Salman ibn Rabi'ah al-Bahili (3) marked a plan, and Al-Musayyab ibn Najabah al-Fazari (4), and people from Qays opposite the house of Ibn Mas'ud. Abdullah ibn Mas'ud (5), Talhah ibn Ubaydullah (6), and Amr ibn Hurayth (7) marked out houses around the mosque. Umar granted land to Jubayr ibn Mut'im (8), so he built a house, then sold it to Musa ibn Talhah (9).

He granted Sa'd ibn Qays [land] at the house of Salman ibn Rabi'ah, with the road between them. Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas requested for himself the house which is the house of Umar ibn Sa'd (1). He granted land to Khalid ibn Urfutah, Khabbab ibn al-Aratt (2), Amr ibn al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar, and Umarah ibn Ruwaybah al-Tamimi. He granted land to Abu Mas'ud Uqbah ibn Amr al-Ansari (3). He granted land to Banu Shamkh ibn Fazarah (4) next to Juhaynah (5). He granted Hashim ibn Utbah ibn Abi Waqqas (6) Shahar Suj Khunays (7). He granted land to Shurayh ibn al-Harith al-Ta'i (8). Umar granted Usama ibn Zayd (9) a house between the mosque and the house of Amr ibn al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar. He granted Abu Musa al-Ash'ari (10) half of Al-Ari, which was an open space near the mosque. He granted...

...Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman (1) with a group from Abs half of Al-Ari, which was an open space where the horses of the Muslims were. He granted Amr ibn Maymun al-Awdi the Rahba (plaza) known by Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him. He granted land to Abu Jubayrah al-Ansari, who was in charge of the Divan of the Army. He granted Adi ibn Hatim and the rest of Tayy the area of the Cemetery of Bishr. He granted land to Al-Zubayr ibn al-Awwam. He granted Jarir ibn Abdullah al-Bajali and the rest of Bajila a wide large plot. He granted Al-Ash'ath ibn Qays (2) al-Kindi and Kindah from the direction of Juhaynah to Banu Awd. A group from Al-Azd came and found a gap between Bajila and Kindah, so they settled. Hamdan dispersed in Kufa. Tamim, Bakr, and Asad came and settled the outskirts. He granted land to Abu Abdullah al-Jadali in Bajila. Jarir ibn Abdullah said: "This one has settled among us but is not of us." Umar said to him: "Move to where is better for you." So he moved to Basra, and the generality of Ahmas moved from Jarir ibn Abdullah to the Cemetery. The plans changed and came to be known by people who bought them later and built. Each tribe had a cemetery known by them and their leaders, among them: Cemetery of 'Arzam, Cemetery of Bishr, Cemetery of Azd, Cemetery of Salim, Cemetery of Murad, Cemetery of Kindah, Cemetery of the Sa'idis, Sahara (Desert) of Athir, Sahara of Banu Yashkur, and Sahara of Banu Amir. Umar ibn al-Khattab wrote to Sa'd to make the lanes of Kufa fifty cubits equally. The market was placed from the Palace and the Mosque to the house of Al-Walid, to the Fryers, to the houses of Thaqif and Ashja'. Upon it were shades of mats until the days of Khalid ibn Abdullah al-Qasri, for he built the markets and made for the people of each merchandise a house and an arch, and made their revenues for the soldiers. Ten thousand fighters used to inhabit it.

The Stations from Kufa to Medina and Mecca. Whoever wants to go from Kufa to Hejaz goes out in the direction of the Qibla (South) through populated stations and established watering places containing palaces for the Caliphs of Banu Hashim. The first station is Al-Qadisiyyah (1), then Al-Mughithah (2), then Al-Qar'a', then Waqisah, then Al-Aqabah, then Al-Qa', then Zubalah, then Al-Shuquq, then Bitan, which is the Grave of Al-Ibadi. These four places are the dwellings of Banu Asad. And Al-Tha'labiyyah, which is a city with a wall. Zarud and Al-Ajfar are dwellings of Tayy. Then the city of Fayd (3), which is the city where the governors of the Mecca road stay; its people are Tayy, and it is at the foot of their mountain known as Salma. And Tuz (4), which are dwellings of Tayy. And Sumayra' (5) and Al-Hajir (6); their people are Qays, most of them Banu Abs. And Al-Naqrah and Ma'din al-Naqrah; its people are a mix of Qays and others. From there, whoever wants the City (Medina) of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, turns to Batn Nakhl. Whoever intends for Mecca goes to Mughithat al-Mawan, which are dwellings of Muharib, then Al-Rabadhah, then Al-Salilah, then Al-Umq, then Ma'din Bani Sulaym, then Ufay'iyah, then Al-Maslah, then Ghamrah, from where the Ihram for Hajj is assumed, then Dhat 'Irq, then Bustan Ibn Amir, then Mecca.

The City of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Whoever intends to go to the City (Medina) (1) of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, takes the route from the station called Ma'din al-Naqrah to Batn Nakhl (2), then Al-Usaylah (3), then Turafah (4), then Medina. Medina, as the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, named it Taybah, is in its level ground sweet, wild, and mountainous. That is because it has two mountains, one of them is Uhud and the other is 'Ayr. Its people are the Muhajirun, the Ansar, and the Tabi'un. In it are Arab tribes from Qays ibn 'Aylan, from Muzaynah, Juhaynah, Kinanah, and others. It has four valleys whose water comes at the time of rains and floods from mountains at a place called Harrat Bani Sulaym at a distance of ten farsakhs from Medina. They are Wadi Bathan, Al-Aqiq Al-Kabir, Al-Aqiq Al-Saghir, and Wadi Qanat. The waters of these valleys come at the time of floods, then they all gather at a place called Al-Ghabah, and exit to a valley called Wadi Idam. Then Al-Aqiq Al-Kabir and Al-Aqiq Al-Saghir exit into wells, among them the Well of Rumah, which is the excavation of Bani Mazin, and the Well of 'Urwah. The people of Medina drink for the rest of the year from these two wells and other wells that do not have the fame of these two wells. In it are wells from which palm trees and farms are irrigated, drawn by camels (Nawadih) working the water wheels (Zaraniq). In Medina are gushing flowing springs, among them: Ayn al-Surayyin, Ayn Thaniyat Marwan, Ayn al-Khaniqin, Ayn Abi Ziyad and Khayf al-Qadi, Ayn Burd, and Ayn Azwaj al-Nabi (Spring of the Prophet's Wives), may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Most of the wealth of its people is palm trees, from which is their livelihood and sustenance. Its land tax (Kharaj) is from the tithes of palm trees and charities (Sadaqat). The Great Sea is three days away from it,

and its coast is a place called Al-Jar, to which merchant ships and ships carrying food from Egypt anchor. From Medina to Quba (1) is six miles. In it were the dwellings of the Aws and Khazraj before Islam, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stayed there before proceeding to the location of Medina. He, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, stayed in Quba with Kulthum ibn al-Hadm, then Kulthum died, so he stayed with Sa'd ibn Khaythamah al-Ansari. The house of Sa'd ibn Khaythamah is next to the Mosque of Quba. Then he moved to Medina, and its strongholds were written down, and people laid out plans in it. Before that, they were separated, and the buildings connected one to another until it became a city. From Medina to Mecca are ten populated, inhabited stages. The first of them is Dhu al-Hulayfah, from which the pilgrims enter Ihram if they leave Medina, and it is four miles from Medina. From there to Al-Hafirah, which are the dwellings of Bani Fihr of Quraysh. And to Malal, which at this time are dwellings of a people from the descendants of Ja'far ibn Abi Talib. And to Al-Sayyalah, in which are a people from the descendants of Al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, and there were people from Quraysh and others. And to Al-Rawha', which are dwellings of Muzaynah. And to Al-Ruwaythah, in which are a people from the descendants of Uthman ibn Affan and others of the Arabs. And to Al-Arj, which are also dwellings of Muzaynah. And to Suqya Bani Ghifar, which are dwellings of Bani Kinanah. And to Al-Abwa', which are dwellings of Aslam. And to Al-Juhfah, in which are a people from Bani Sulaym; and Ghadir Khumm (3) is two miles from Al-Juhfah, deviating from the road. And to Qudayd, in which are dwellings of Khuza'ah. And to Usfan. And to Marr al-Zahran, which are dwellings of Kinanah. And to Mecca. Mecca and its Districts. From Medina to Mecca (4) is two hundred and twenty-five miles. The pilgrims stop at these...

stations and other watering places. Some prolong and others shorten according to their speed or slowness in travel. People enter Mecca from Dhu Tuwa, which is lower Mecca, and from the Pass of the Medinans, which is upper Mecca, from where the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, entered. Mecca lies between great mountains, which are valleys with passes. The mountains surrounding it are: Abu Qubays, the greatest mountain from which the sun rises over the Sacred Mosque, and Qu'ayqi'an, Fadih, Al-Muhassab, Thawr near Al-Safa, Hira', Thabir, Tuffahah, Al-Matabikh, Al-Falaq, Al-Hajun, and Saqar. Its passes include: Shi'b al-Hajun, Shi'b Dar Mal Allah, Shi'b al-Batatin, Shi'b Falaq Ibn al-Zubayr, Shi'b Ibn Amir, Shi'b al-Jawf, Shi'b al-Khuz, Shi'b Adhakhir, Shi'b Khat al-Hazamiyah, Shi'b al-Safa, Shi'b al-Razzazin, Shi'b al-Khabbazin (Bakers?), Shi'b al-Jazzarin (Butchers), Shi'b Zuqaq al-Nar, Shi'b Jabal Tuffahah, Shi'b al-Hajjaj, Shi'b al-Attarin (Perfumers), Shi'b Ajyad al-Kabir, Shi'b Ajyad al-Saghir, Shi'b al-Nafar, Shi'b Thawr and Khiyam 'Unqud, Shi'b Yarni, Shi'b Ali, Shi'b Thaniyat al-Madaniyyin, and Shi'b al-Hammam. The Sacred Mosque is between Ajyad and Qu'ayqi'an. The last person to build the Sacred Mosque, add to it, and expand it until the Kaaba became in its center was Al-Mahdi in the year one hundred and sixty-four. The area of the Sacred Mosque measured is one hundred and twenty thousand cubits. The length of the Mosque from the Gate of Bani Jumah to the Gate of Bani Hashim near the Green Flag is four hundred and four cubits. Its width from the Gate of Al-Nadwah to the Gate of Al-Safa is three hundred and four cubits. It contains four hundred and eighty-four marble columns; the length of each column is ten cubits. It has four hundred and ninety-eight arches and twenty-three gates. The Commander of the Faithful Al-Mahdi built the two green flags that are between Al-Safa and Al-Marwah. Between each flag and its companion is one hundred and twelve cubits. Between Al-Safa and Al-Marwah is seven hundred and fifty-four cubits. The height of the Kaaba is twenty-eight cubits. From the Black Corner to the Levantine Corner is twenty-five cubits. From the Western Corner in the Hijr to the Levantine Corner is twenty-two cubits. From the Western Corner to the Yemeni Corner is twenty-five cubits. From...

the Yemeni Corner to the Corner containing the Black Stone is twenty-one cubits. The people of Mecca drank from salty wells and from the canals dug by Umm Ja'far, daughter of Ja'far ibn the Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur, during the caliphate of the Commander of the Faithful Al-Rashid. She channeled water from a place called Al-Mashash in lead pipes; the distance between them is twelve miles. So the people of Mecca and the pilgrims drank from the Pool of Umm Ja'far. Ta'if is two stages from Mecca. Ta'if is the dwelling of Thaqif, and it is one of the districts of Mecca attached to the governor of Mecca. Among the districts of Mecca are Ru'ayla' al-Hawdhah and Ru'ayla' al-Bayad, which are mines of Sulaym, Hilal, and Uqayl from Qays. And Tabalah, whose people are Khath'am. And Najran, belonging to Bani al-Harith ibn Ka'b; these were their dwellings in the Jahiliyyah. And Al-Sarat, whose people are Al-Azd. And 'Asham, a gold mine. And Baysh, Al-Sirrin, Al-Hasbah, and 'Athr. And Jeddah, which is the sea coast. And Rahat, Nakhlah, Dhat 'Irq, Qarn, Usfan, Marr al-Zahran, and Al-Juhfah. Around Mecca are Arab tribes from Qays: Banu Uqayl, Banu Hilal, Banu Numayr, and Banu Nasr. And from Kinanah: Ghifar, Daws, Banu Layth, Khuza'ah, Khath'am, Hakam, and Al-Azd. Mecca has many springs where people's properties are located in Marr al-Zahran, Arafah, Rahat, and Tathlith. It has a gold mine in 'Asham, Dhu 'Alaq, and Ukaz. Its land tax comes from tithes and charities. Provisions are carried to it from Egypt to its coast, which is Jeddah. From Mecca to Yemen. From Mecca to Sana'a (1) is twenty-one stages (2). The first is Al-Mulkan (3), then...

Yalamlam (1), from where the pilgrims of Yemen enter Ihram. Then Al-Lith, then 'Alib, then Qurban, then Qanuna, then Yabah, then Al-Mu'aqqar, then Dhankan, then Zanif, then Rim, then Yabash, then Al-Arsh of Jazan, then Al-Sharjah, then Al-Sal'a', then Balahah, then Al-Mahjam, then Al-'Arah, then Al-Marwah, then Sudan, then Sana'a, which is the great city where governors and Arab nobles reside. Yemen has eighty-four Mikhlifs (provinces), which are like districts and cities. Their names are: Al-Yahsibayn, Yakla, Dhamar, Tamu', 'Ayan, Tamam, Hamal, Qadam, Khaywan, Sanhan, Rayhan, Jurash, Sa'dah, Al-Akhrush, Majnah, Haraz, Hawzan, Qafa'ah, Al-Wazirah, Al-Hajr, Al-Ma'afir, 'Annah, Al-Shawafi, Jablan, Wusab, Al-Sakun, Shar'ab, Al-Janad, Maswar, Al-Thaljah, Al-Mazari', Hayran, Ma'rib, Hudur, 'Alqan, Al-Arsh of Jazan, Al-Khasuf, Al-Sa'id, Balahah which is Mawr, Al-Mahjam, Al-Kadra' which is Siham, Al-Mu'aqqar which is Dhuwal, Zubaydah, Rama', Al-Rakb, Bani Majid, Lahj, Abyan, Bayn al-Wadiyayn, Alhan, Hadramawt, Maqra, Hays, Harad, Al-Haqlayn, 'Ans, Bani Amir, Ma'dhin, Hamlan, Dhi Jarah, Khawlan, Al-Sarw, Al-Dathinah, Kubaybah, and Tabalah. Islands of Yemen. Zayla' (2), which is opposite Al-Mandab. Then Dahlak (3), which is opposite Ghalafiqah (4), and it is the island...

of the Negus. And Rahsuwa, which is opposite Dahlak. And Badi' (1), which is opposite 'Athr, which is the coast of Baysh, the land of Kinanah. Its Coasts. Aden (2), which is the coast of Sana'a and contains the anchorage for ships from China. And Salahit, Al-Mandub, Ghalafiqah, Al-Hardah, Al-Sharjah (3) - which is Sharjat al-Qurays -, 'Athr (4), Al-Hasiyah, Al-Sirrin, and Jeddah. Naming those who inhabit each land from the Arab tribes in Yemen. Baysh: its people are Al-Azd, and in it are people from Bani Kinanah. Al-Khasuf and Al-Sa'id: their people are Ha' (5) and Hakam (6). Al-Kadra' and Al-Mahjam: their people are 'Akk. Al-Husayb: its people are Zubayd and the Ash'aris. Hays: it is the city of Al-Rakb and Bani Majid. Harad: the city of Al-Ma'afir. Al-Janad: the city of Shar'ab. The city of Jayshan belongs to Himyar. Tabalah belongs to Khath'am. Najran belongs to Bani al-Harith ibn Ka'b. Sa'dah belongs to Khawlan. Shar'ab, Qafa'ah, and Al-Hajr are lands of Kindah.

The Third Quarter: Al-Jarbi, which is the Quarter of the North. We have mentioned Al-Tayman, which is the Quarter of the Qibla (South). Let us now mention the Quarter of Al-Jarbi, which is the Quarter of the North, and the cities and districts within it. Whoever wants to go from Baghdad to Al-Mada'in and what adjoins it of the cities and districts (Tasasij) on the banks of the Tigris: Wasit, Basra, Al-Ubullah, Al-Yamama, Bahrain, Oman, Sindh, and India, leaves Baghdad and takes whichever side he likes, the Eastern of the Tigris or the Western, passing through great villages containing dwellings of the Persians until he reaches Al-Mada'in, which is seven farsakhs from Baghdad. Al-Mada'in was the abode of the kings of Persia. The first to settle there was Anushirvan. It consists of several cities on both sides of the Tigris. The Eastern Side contains the city called Al-Atiqah (The Ancient), containing the ancient White Palace whose builder is unknown, and the Congregational Mosque built by the Muslims when it was conquered. Also on the Eastern Side is the city called Asbanir (1), containing the great Iwan of Khosrow (Ctesiphon Arch) which has no equal among the Persians; the height of its roof is eighty cubits. Between the two cities is about a mile. In this one Salman al-Farsi and Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman used to reside, and their graves are there. Following these two cities is a city called Al-Rumiyah, which is said to have been built by the Romans when they conquered the kingdom of Persia. The Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur was there when he killed Abu Muslim. The distance between these three cities is close to two or three miles. On the Western Side of the Tigris is a city called Bahrasir, then Sabat al-Mada'in at a farsakh from Bahrasir. What was on the Eastern Side of the Tigris drank from the Tigris, and what was on the Western Side of the Tigris drank from the Euphrates, coming from a river called Nahr al-Malik which takes from the Euphrates.

All these cities (Al-Mada'in) were conquered in the year fourteen by Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas. From Al-Mada'in to Wasit is five stages. The first is Dayr al-'Aqul (1), which is the city of the Middle Nahrawan, inhabited by noble Dihqans (landed gentry). Then Jarjaraya, which is the city of the Lower Nahrawan, and it is the abode of Persian nobles, among them Raja' ibn Abi al-Dahhak and Ahmad ibn al-Khasib. Then Al-Nu'maniyah, which is the city of the Upper Zab; near it are the dwellings of the family of Nawbakht. In the city of Al-Nu'maniyah is the Monastery of Ezekiel (Dayr Hizqil) where the insane are treated. Then Jabal, an ancient populated city. Then Madaraya, an ancient dwelling of non-Arab nobles. Then Al-Mubarak, an ancient river. After Al-Nu'maniyah on the Western Side of the Tigris is the village known as Ni'madh, a port from which provisions of the Tigris are transferred to the Nile. Then the River Sabis, which is on the Western Side opposite Al-Mubarak, because the city of Al-Mubarak is on the Eastern Side; from it, one travels to the districts (Tassuj) of Badaraya and Bakisaya. Then the Bridges of Al-Khayzuran on the Eastern Side. Then Fam al-Silh, containing the dwellings of Al-Hasan ibn Sahl; to this place Al-Ma'mun came when he visited Al-Hasan ibn Sahl and consummated his marriage with his daughter Buran. Then Wasit, which consists of two cities on the banks of the Tigris. The ancient city is on the Eastern Side of the Tigris. Al-Hajjaj built a city on the Western Side and placed a bridge of boats between them. Al-Hajjaj built his palace in this western city, and the Green Dome called the Green of Wasit, and the Congregational Mosque, and it has a wall. Governors resided there after Al-Hajjaj. Yazid ibn Umar ibn Hubayrah al-Fazari was there when he was defeated by the companions of Qahtabah; he fortified himself in it and was given safety. The inhabitants of these two cities are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs. Whoever is of the Dihqans resides in the Eastern City, which is the city of Kaskar. Its land tax is included in the land tax of the districts of the Sawad. It was named Wasit (Middle) only because it is fifty farsakhs from it to Basra, fifty to Kufa, fifty to Ahwaz, and fifty to Baghdad; therefore, it was named Wasit. Connected to it is the River Aban, where the mats are made from which the Armenian [style] is made, then carried to Armenia to be spun and woven. Then to 'Abdasi (2), then to Al-Madhar, which is the city of Maysan.

The city of Al-Madhar (1) is also on the Tigris. Adjacent to Al-Madhar is the district of Ayzqabadh (2), and the city is called Fasa. From Wasit to Basra is through the Marshes (Al-Bata'ih). They were named Al-Bata'ih because several waters gather in them. Then one goes from the Marshes into the Blind Tigris (Dijlah al-Awra'), then proceeds to Basra and anchors at the bank of the River of Ibn Umar (3). Basra. Basra (4) was the city of the world and the mine of its trade and wealth. It is a rectangular city; its area, based on the original plan laid out at the time of its conquest during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab in the year seventeen, is two farsakhs by one farsakh. Its inner part, which is the side facing...

...North opens onto two rivers belonging to it. One of them is a river known as the River of Ibn Umar, which is a river [...] (1). And Charsianon (2) five hundred knights, and Seleucia (3) five hundred knights, and Thrace five thousand knights, and Macedonia three thousand knights. So the entire army of the lands of the Romans (Byzantines) from the soldiers assigned to the districts and villages is forty thousand knights. There is no mercenary among them; rather, they are soldiers assigned to every region, men who go out with its Patrician at the time of war. We have mentioned the news of the lands of the Romans, their men, cities, fortresses, ports, mountains, passes, valleys, lakes, and the places of raids against them in a book other than this. These are the routes to the frontiers and what is connected to them. Whoever wants to travel from Aleppo on the main road to the West leaves Aleppo to the city of Qinnasrin, then to the place called Talmanas, which is the first district of the Jund (military district) (4) of Homs. Jund Homs. Then from there to the city of Hama (5), which is an ancient city on a river called the Orontes. The people of this city are a folk from Yemen, mostly Bahra' and Tanukh. Then from the city of Hama to the city of Al-Rastan, then to the city of Homs. The city of Homs (6) is one of the most spacious cities of the Levant (Sham), and it has a great river from which its people drink. The people of...

...Homs are all Yemenis from Tayy', Kindah, Himyar, Kalb, Hamdan, and other Yemeni tribes. Abu Ubaydah al-Jarrah (1) conquered it in the year ten by peace treaty, but it rebelled after the conquest, so he made peace with its people a second time. In Homs are regions including: Al-Namma, whose people are Kalb; Al-Rastan; Hama, which is a city on a great river whose people are Bahra' and Tanukh; and Sawran, in which are people from Iyad. And Salamiyah, a city in the desert which Abdullah ibn Salih ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib built; he channeled a river to it and extracted water from its land until he planted saffron in it. Its people are descendants of Abdullah ibn Salih al-Hashimi, their clients, and a mix of people, merchants, and farmers. And Palmyra (Tadmur) (2), an ancient city of wondrous construction. It is said, due to the abundance of wondrous monuments in it, that...

...Solomon son of David, the Prophet, peace be upon him, built it; its people are Kalb. And Talmanas, the dwellings of Iyad; Ibn Abi Du'ad had built it as a residence. And Ma'arrat al-Nu'man, an ancient ruined city whose people are Tanukh. And Al-Barah, whose people are Bahra'. And the city of Apamea (Famiyah), an ancient ruined Roman city on a great lake, whose people are Udhrah and Bahra'. And the city of Shaizar, whose people are a folk from Kindah. And the city of Kafr Tab. And Al-Itmim, an ancient city whose people are a folk from Yemen and other tribes, mostly Kindah. On the coast of the sea from the Jund of Homs are four cities: The city of Latakia (1), whose people are a folk from Yemen from Salih, Zubayd, Hamdan, Yahsub, and others. The city of Jableh (2), whose people are Hamdan, and in it are people from Qays and Iyad. The city of Balaniyas (3), whose people are mixed. And the city of Antartus (4), whose people are a folk from Kindah. The standing regular land tax of Homs, excluding estates, reaches two hundred and twenty thousand dinars. Jund Damascus. From Homs to the city of Damascus (5) is four stages. The first stage is Jusiyah, which belongs to Homs.

The second is Qara, which is the first district of the Jund of Damascus. The third is Al-Qutayfah, where Hisham ibn Abdul Malik ibn Marwan had dwellings. From there to the city of Damascus. Whoever travels from Homs on the postal road takes from Jusiyah (1) to Al-Biqa' (2), then to the city of Baalbek (3). It is one of the majestic cities of the Levant, containing wondrous stone structures and a wondrous spring from which a great river flows. Inside the city are gardens and orchards. From the city of Baalbek to 'Aqabat al-Rumman, then to the city of Damascus. The city of Damascus is a majestic ancient city, the city of the Levant in the Jahiliyyah and Islam. It has no peer in all the Junds of the Levant regarding the abundance of its rivers and construction. Its greatest river is called [Barada] (4). The city of Damascus was conquered during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab in the year fourteen. Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah conquered it from a gate called Bab al-Jabiya by peace treaty after a year-long siege. Khalid ibn al-Walid entered from a gate called Bab al-Sharqi without a treaty, so Abu Ubaydah applied the peace treaty to all of it. They wrote to Umar ibn al-Khattab, and he approved what Abu Ubaydah had done. Damascus was the dwelling of the kings of Ghassan, and it contains ruins of the family of Jafnah (5). The predominant people in the city of...

...Damascus are the people of Yemen, and there are people from Qays. The dwellings of the Umayyads and their palaces constitute most of its dwellings. In it is the Green Palace (Khadra') of Mu'awiyah, which is the Governor's House (Dar al-Imara). And its Mosque, than which there is nothing more beautiful in Islam in terms of marble and gold; Al-Walid ibn Abdul Malik ibn Marwan built it during his caliphate. The Jund of Damascus includes the districts of: Al-Ghouta, whose people are Ghassan and clans of Qays, and in it are people from Rabi'ah. And Hawran; its city is Bosra, and its people are people from Qays from Bani Murrah, except Al-Suwayda, for in it are people from Kalb. And Al-Bathaniyyah; its city is Adhri'at, and its people are people from Yemen and Qays. And Al-Zahir; its city is Amman. And Al-Ghawr; its city is Riha (Jericho). These two cities are the land of Al-Balqa', and its people are people from Qays, and in it is a group from Quraysh. And Jibal; its city is 'Arandal, and its people are people from Ghassan, Balqayn, and others. And Ma'ab. And Zughar, whose people are a mix of people; in it is the village known as Mu'tah where Ja'far ibn Abi Talib and Zayd ibn Harithah ibn Abdullah ibn Rawahah were killed. And Al-Sharah; its city is Adhruh, and its people are clients of Bani Hashim; in it is Al-Humaymah, the dwelling of Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abdul Muttalib and his son. And Golan (Al-Jawlan) (1); its city is Banias, and its people are people from Qays, most of them Bani Murrah, and in it are a few people of Yemen. And Jabal Sanir; its people are Banu Dabbah, and in it are people from Kalb. And Baalbek; its people are people from the Persians, and in its outskirts are people from Yemen. And Jabal al-Jalil (Galilee); its people are people from 'Amilah. And Lebanon Sidon (2); in it are people from Quraysh and Yemen. The Jund of Damascus has coastal districts: the district of 'Arfah, which has an ancient city containing Persian people who were transferred there, and people from Rabi'ah from Bani Hanifah. And the city of Tripoli (3); its people are Persian people whom Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan transferred there; they have a wondrous harbor that accommodates a thousand ships. And Jubayl (4), Sidon, and Beirut (5).

The people of all these districts are Persians whom Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan transferred there. All the districts of Damascus were conquered by Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab in the year fourteen. The land tax of Damascus, excluding estates, reaches three hundred thousand dinars. Jund al-Urdunn (Jordan). From the city of Damascus to Jund al-Urdunn (1) is four stages. The first is Jasim, from the district of Damascus. And Khisfin (2), from the district of Damascus. And Fiq, which has the mentioned Pass ('Aqabah). From there to the city of Tiberias (3), which is the city of Jordan. It is at the bottom of a mountain on a majestic lake from which the famous Jordan River flows. In the city of Tiberias are hot springs that gush forth in summer and winter and do not cease; the hot water enters their bathhouses without needing fuel. The people of the city of Tiberias are a people from the Ash'aris who predominate in it. The Jund of Jordan includes the districts of Tyre (Sur), a coastal city with a shipyard from which the Sultan's ships go out to raid the Romans; it is fortified and majestic, and its people are a mix. And the city of Acre (Akka) (4), which is coastal. And Qadas (5), which is one of its most majestic districts. And Baysan, Fahl,

Jerash, and Al-Sawad. The people of these districts are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs. The districts of Jordan were conquered during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab by Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah, except for the city of Tiberias, for its people made peace with him. The other districts of Jund al-Urdunn were conquered by Khalid ibn al-Walid and Amr ibn al-Aas on behalf of Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah in the year fourteen. The land tax of Jund al-Urdunn reaches, excluding estates, one hundred thousand dinars. Jund Filastin (Palestine). From Jund al-Urdunn to Jund Filastin (1) is three stages. The ancient city of Palestine was a city called Ludd (Lydda). When Sulayman ibn Abdul Malik assumed the Caliphate, he built the city of Ramla and destroyed the city of Ludd, transferring its people to Ramla. Ramla is the city of Palestine. It has a small river from which its people drink. The River of Abu Futrus is twelve miles from it. The people of Ramla drink from well water and from cisterns in which rainwater flows. The people of the city are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs, and its protected people (Dhimmis) are Samaritans. Palestine includes the districts of: the district of Iliya, which is Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem), containing the traces of the Prophets, peace be upon them. And the district of Ludd (2), whose city still stands but is ruined. And Amwas (3), and Nablus (4),

which is an ancient city containing the two holy mountains; below the city is a city carved in stone. In it are a mix of Arabs, non-Arabs, and Samaritans. And Sebastiya, which is attached to Nablus. And Caesarea, a city on the sea coast which was one of the most impregnable cities of Palestine; it was the last city of the land to be conquered, conquered by Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab. And Yibna (1), an ancient city on a hill, about which it is narrated that Usama ibn Zayd said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded me when he dispatched me, saying: "Attack Yibna in the morning and burn" (2). The people of this city are Samaritans. And Jaffa (3), which is on the sea coast; the people of Ramla go to it. And the district of Bayt Jibrin, an ancient city whose people are from Judham; in it is the Dead Lake which produces asphalt (humrah), which is Mumia. And the city of Ashkelon on the sea coast. And the city of Gaza on the sea coast; it is the head of the Third Clime, and in it is the grave of Hashim ibn Abd Manaf. The people of Jund Filastin are a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs, and of Lakhm, Judham, 'Amilah, Kindah, Qays, and Kinanah. The land of Palestine was conquered in the year sixteen after a long siege, until Umar ibn al-Khattab came out and made peace with the people of the district of Iliya, which is Jerusalem. They said: We will not make peace except with the Caliph. So he marched to them until he made peace with them. Most of the districts of Palestine were conquered except Caesarea; Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah assigned Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan to it, and he conquered it in the year eighteen.

The amount of the land tax of Jund Filastin, along with what became estates, reaches three hundred thousand dinars. Whoever wants to travel from the Levant through Palestine to Mecca takes rugged, rough mountains until he reaches Ayla (Eilat/Aqaba), then Midian, then the road continues with the people of Egypt and the Maghreb. Egypt and its Districts. Whoever leaves Palestine heading west wanting Egypt (1) leaves Ramla to the city of Yibna, then to the city of Ashkelon (2) on the sea coast, then to the city of Gaza (3) also on the coast, then to Rafah (4) which is the last of the works of the Levant. Then to a place called Al-Shajaratayn, which is the first border of Egypt. Then to Al-Arish (5), which is the first garrison of Egypt and its works. Al-Arish is inhabited by people from Judham and others; it is a village on the sea coast. From Al-Arish to a village called Al-Baqarah. From there to a village called Al-Waridah in mountains of sand. Then to Al-Farama (6), which is the first city of Egypt, containing a mix of people; between it and the Green Sea is three miles. From Al-Farama to a village called Jirjir is a stage. From there to a village called Qafus is a stage. From there to a village called Ghayfah, then Al-Fustat. Al-Fustat (7) was known as Bab al-Yun (Babylon), which is the place known as the Palace (Al-Qasr). When...

...Amr ibn al-Aas conquered Bab al-Yun during the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab in the year twenty, the Arab tribes marked out lots around the tent (Fustat) of Amr ibn al-Aas, so it was named Al-Fustat for this reason. Then they expanded in the land and laid out plans on the Nile. The Arab tribes marked out lots in places attributed to each tribe. Amr ibn al-Aas built its Congregational Mosque and its Governor's House known as Dar al-Raml. He placed the markets surrounding the Congregational Mosque on the eastern side of the Nile. He assigned a guard and a supervisor for each tribe. He built the Fortress of Giza on the western side of the Nile and made it a garrison for the Muslims and settled people in it. He wrote to Umar ibn al-Khattab about that, who wrote back: "Do not put water between me and the Muslims." Amr conquered the districts of Egypt by peace treaty except Alexandria (1), for he besieged its people for three years, then conquered it in the year twenty-three because there was no city in the land like it in fortification, size, and abundance of equipment. The districts of Egypt are attributed to their cities because each district has a city distinguished by some matter. Among the cities of Upper Egypt (Al-Sa'id) and its districts is the city of Memphis (Manf) (2), a standing ruined city; the people of Egypt say it is the city Pharaoh used to inhabit. And the city of Busir Kuridus (3). And the city of Dalas (4), to which Dalasi bridles are attributed. And the city of Fayyum (5); it used to be said in former days "Egypt and Fayyum",

due to the majesty of Fayyum and the abundance of its construction. In it is the described wheat, and linen (Khaysh) is made there. And the city of Al-Qays, where Qaysi garments and excellent wool cloaks are made. And the city of Al-Bahnasa, where Bahnasawi curtains are made. And the city of Ahnas, where cloaks are made and where the Labakh tree is found. And the city of Taha, where the described wheat and jugs called Bawaqil by the people of Egypt are found. And Ansina, an ancient city; it is said that Pharaoh's magicians were from there, and that a remnant of magic remains in it; it is on the eastern side of the Nile. And the city of Al-Ashmunayn, where excellent horses, beasts, and mules are found; it is one of the great cities of Egypt. And the city of Asyut (1), one of the great cities of Upper Egypt; in it crimson (Qirmiz) carpets resembling Armenian ones are made. And Qahqawa, containing an ancient city called Butij. And a city called Bashmur, containing the Yusufi variegated wheat. And the city of Akhmim (2), on the eastern side of the Nile; it has a coast, and cut carpets and Akhmimi leathers are made there; and the monastery known as the Monastery of Abu Shenouda, said to contain the graves of two of the disciples of Christ. And the city of Ibshayah, called Al-Balyana. From Ibshayah one travels to the Oases (Al-Wahat) through a desert and rough mountains for six stages. Then to the Outer Oasis (Al-Kharga), lands containing fortresses, farms, flowing springs, running waters, bees, varieties of trees, vines, rice farms, and other things. Then to the Inner Oasis (Al-Dakhla), which has a city called Al-Farfarun; its people are a mix of Egyptians and others. From the city of Ibshayah, called the city of Al-Balyana (3), to the city of Hu (4). The city of Hu is...

...an ancient city that had four districts: the district of Hu and the district of Dendera west of the Nile, and the district of Qa and the district of Qena on the eastern side. It fell into ruin and its population decreased due to the many Bedouins, rebels, and highwaymen who went out to it in the region, so people moved away from it to more populated places. From the city of Hu to the city of Qift (1) is two stages. It is a city on the eastern side containing traces of past kings and a temple (Birba). From Qift one travels to the emerald mines, a mine called Kharbat al-Malik, eight stages from the city of Qift. In it are two mountains, one called Al-Arus and the other Al-Khusum, containing emerald mines. In it is a place called Kawm al-Sabuni, Kawm Mahran, Makabir, and Safsid. All these are mines where gems are found. The excavations from which gems are extracted are called "Shiyam", singular "Shimah". There was an ancient mine called Sarumit, a mine from the Jahiliyyah, as well as the mine of Makabir. From the mine called Kharbat al-Malik to Jabal Sa'id, a gold dust mine, is a stage. And to the place called Al-Kalbi, a place called Al-Shukri, a place called Al-Ajli, a place called Al-Allaqi al-Adna, and a place called Al-Rifah, which is the sea coast of Kharbat al-Malik. All these are gold dust mines. From Al-Kharbah to the mine called Raham, a gold dust mine, is three stages. At Raham are people from Bali, Juhaynah, and others of mixed people aiming for trade. These are the gem mines and the nearby gold dust mines connected to them. From the city of Qift to the city of Luxor (Al-Uqsur), a city that has fallen into ruin, and the city of Qus took its place; it is on the bank of the Nile on the eastern side. And the district of Esna (2), and the city of Esna is on the western side of the Nile. It is said that its people are Al-Maris...

...and from there come the Maris donkeys. Then the district of Edfu (1) on the western side of the Nile. And the district of San on the western side. Then the great city of Aswan (2), containing the mine merchants; it is on the eastern side of the Nile, possessing many palm trees, crops, and trade from what comes from the lands of Nubia and Beja. The last city of the lands of Islam from this side is a city on an island in the middle of the Nile called Philae (Bilaq) (3), with a stone wall. Then the border of the lands of Nubia (4) at a place called Al-Qasr, about a mile from Philae. Gold Dust Mines. Whoever wants the mines, the gold dust mines, leaves Aswan to a place called Al-Dayqah between two mountains, then Al-Buwayb, then Al-Baydiyah, then Bayt Ibn Ziyad, then 'Udhayfir the Red Mountain, then the White Mountain (Jabal al-Bayad), then the Grave of Abu Mas'ud, then 'Afar, then Wadi al-Allaqi. All these places are gold dust mines sought by prospectors (Ashab al-Matalib). Wadi al-Allaqi is like a great city with a multitude of people and a mix of Arabs and non-Arabs, prospectors. It has markets and trade. Their drink is from wells dug in Wadi al-Allaqi. Most of those in Al-Allaqi are people from Rabi'ah from Bani Hanifah from the people of Al-Yamama (5) who moved there with families and offspring.

Wadi al-Allaqi and what surrounds it are mines for gold dust. People work in everything near it. Every group of merchants and non-merchants has slaves from the Sudan (Blacks) working in excavation, then they extract the gold dust like yellow arsenic, then it is smelted. From Al-Allaqi to a place called Wadi al-Jabal is a stage. Then to a place called 'Inab. Then to a place called Kabar, where people gather to seek gold dust; in it are people from Al-Yamama from Rabi'ah. From Al-Allaqi to a mine called Batn Wah is a stage. From Al-Allaqi to a place called A'mad is two stages. To a mine called Ma' al-Sakhrah is a stage. To a mine called Al-Akhshab is two stages. To a mine called Mizab, inhabited by Lama and Juhaynah, is four stages. To a mine called 'Arabah Batha is two stages. From Al-Allaqi to Aidhab (1) is four stages. Aidhab is the coast of the Salt Sea; people embark from it to Mecca, Hejaz, and Yemen. Merchants come to it and carry gold dust, ivory, and other things in ships. From Al-Allaqi to Barkan, the last of the gold dust mines reached by Muslims, is thirty stages. From Al-Allaqi (2) to a place called Dah, inhabited by people from Bani Sulaym and others from Mudar, is ten stages. From Al-Allaqi to a mine called Al-Santa, containing people from Mudar and others, is ten stages. From Al-Allaqi to a mine called Al-Rifq is ten stages. From Al-Allaqi to a mine called Sakhtit is ten stages. These are the mines that Muslims reach and seek for gold dust.

The Land of Nubia. As for whoever heads from Al-Allaqi to the land of the Nubians called Alwa, he travels thirty stages, some to Kabaw, then to a place called Al-Abwab (The Gates), then to the great city of Alwa called Soba, where the King of Alwa resides. Muslims frequent it, and from there comes news of the start of the Nile. It is said that the island of Alwa is connected to the island of Sindh, and the Nile flows from behind Alwa to the land of Sindh in the river called Mehran, just as it flows in the Nile of Egypt, and it rises in it at the time of its rise in Egypt. In the island in the land of Alwa are things like what is in the islands of Sindh, such as elephants, rhinoceroses, and the like. In the river Mehran are crocodiles as in the Nile of Egypt. From Aswan to the first of the lands of the Nubians called Muqurra, a place called Mawa. In this place was Zakariya ibn Qirqi, the deputy of his father Qirqi, King of Nubia. From Mawa to the great city of Nubia where the King of Nubia resides, which is Sai and Dongola, is thirty stages. The Land of Beja. From Al-Allaqi to the land of the Beja (1), who are called the Hadaribah and the Kadanin, is twenty-five stages. The city of the King of the Hadaribah Beja is called Hajar (2); Muslims come to it for trade. The Beja live in leather tents, pluck their beards, and remove the nipple of boys' breasts so their breasts do not resemble women's breasts. They eat sorghum and the like, ride camels, fight on them as horses are fought on, and throw spears without missing.

From Al-Allaqi to the land of the Beja called the Zanafijah is twenty-five stages. The city inhabited by the King of the Zanafijah is called Baqlin. Muslims might go there for trade. Their sect is like the sect of the Hadaribah; they have no law, but used to worship an idol they call "Hahahakhwa". As for the cities of Egypt in the Lower Land, the first is the city of Athribis (Atrib) (1); it has a vast district, and in it is the village known as Banha, which has the famous honey. Then the city of Heliopolis (Ayn Shams) (2), an ancient city said to contain dwellings of Pharaoh and wondrous ruins. In it are two huge soaring obelisks of solid stone with writing in the ancient tongue; water drips from the top of one of them, the cause of which is unknown. Then the city of Natu, the city of Basta (Bubastis), the city of Tarabiyah, the city of Qurbit, the city of San (Tanis), and the city of Iblil. These nine cities are called the Districts of Al-Hawf. Then the city of Bana, a majestic ancient city. The city of Busir, a peer to Bana in greatness and majesty. The city of Samanud (Sebennytos). The city of Nusa. The city of Al-Awsiyah, which is the city of Damira. And the city of Al-Bujum. These six cities on the eastern side of the Nile are called the Districts of Batn al-Rif. And the city of Sakha, the city of Tida, the city of Al-Afrahun, the city of Tawah, and the city of Lower Manuf. These seven cities and districts are in an island of the Nile between the Damietta branch and the Western branch. As for the cities on the coast of the Salt Sea, the first is Al-Farama (Pelusium), the ancient city from which we enter Egypt. Then the city of Tinnis, surrounded by the great Salt Sea and a lake whose water comes from the Nile. It is an ancient city where fine thick and thin garments are made, including Dabiqi, Qasab, Burud, velvet, brocade, and varieties of clothes. It has the anchorage for ships arriving from the Levant and the Maghreb (3). Then the city of Shata (4) on the sea coast, where Sharub garments are made.

Al-Shatwiyyah, then the city of Damietta [Damietta, Egypt] «1», which is on the seacoast and where the Nile water ends. Then it separates from Damietta, so some of it exits into the Lake of Tinnis [Lake Manzala, Egypt], which is a lake in which ships and large vessels sail, and the rest of the Nile water flows into the Salt Sea. In Damietta, thick Dabiqi garments, Sharub garments, and linen are made. And Burah, which is a fortress on the seacoast belonging to the administration of Damietta, where garments and papyrus rolls are made. Then the Fortress of Nuqayzah on the seacoast. Then the city of Al-Burullus [Burullus, Egypt] «2» on the coast of the Salt Sea, which is a place of Ribat (frontier station). Then the city of Rashid [Rosetta, Egypt] «3», which is a populated, inhabited city having a port in which the Nile water flows into the Salt Sea, and vessels enter it from the sea until they are in the Nile. And the city of Ikhnu «4», which is on the seacoast. And the city called Wasimah, where papyrus rolls are made. Then the great, majestic city of Alexandria [Alexandria, Egypt], whose vastness, majesty, and the abundance of the monuments of the ancients cannot be described. Among the wondrous monuments in it is the Lighthouse [Pharos of Alexandria] which is on the seacoast at the mouth of the greatest harbor; it is a meticulously built, sturdy lighthouse, its height is one hundred and seventy-five cubits. It has fire pits in which fires are lit if the watchmen see vessels in the sea from a far distance. It has two obelisks of variegated stone on copper crabs, and upon them is ancient writing. Its monuments and wonders are many. It has a canal which fresh water enters from the Nile, then it pours into the Salt Sea. Alexandria has districts (Kuras) that are not on the coast of the Salt Sea, but are on the coast of...

...the Nile canals: Kura of Al-Buhayrah [Beheira, Egypt], Kura of Masil «1», and Kura of Al-Malidus. These Kuras are on the canal of Alexandria which enters the city. And Kura of Tarnut [Kom Terenuthis, Egypt] «2», Kura of Qartasa «3», Kura of Kharbata «4»—which is also on the canal—Kura of Sa «5», Kura of Shabas «6», Kura of Al-Hayz, Kura of Al-Badaqun, and Kura of Al-Sharak. These Kuras are on a canal from the Nile called: Al-Nastaru. Alexandria has, after that, among the Kuras: Kura of Maryut [Mariout, Egypt] «7», which is a populated Kura possessing vineyards and trees, and it has described fruits. Then Kura of Lubyah [Libya], then Kura of Maraqiyah [Marmarica, Egypt/Libya] «8». These two Kuras are on the coast of the Salt Sea; the lower parts of their villages are inhabited by people from Banu Mudlij of Kinanah, and most of it is inhabited by people from the Berbers, and in it are villages and fortresses. All the Kuras of Egypt were conquered during the Caliphate of Omar ibn Al-Khattab and the Emir Amr ibn Al-Aas ibn Wa'il Al-Sahmi. The land tax (Kharaj) of Egypt reached, at the hands of Amr during the Caliphate of Omar in the first year from the poll tax (Jizya) of the heads of...

...the men, fourteen million Dinars. Then Amr collected in the second year ten million, so Omar wrote to him, 'O traitor.' And Abdullah ibn Sa'd ibn Abi Sarh collected it during the Caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan at twelve million Dinars. Then its men converted to Islam, so the land tax during the days of Muawiyah, along with the poll tax of the men's heads, reached five million Dinars. It reached in the days of Harun Al-Rashid four million Dinars, then the money of Egypt settled at three million Dinars. The drinking water of Egypt and all its villages is from the water of the Nile, summer and winter. It increases in the days of summer and comes from the land of Alwa [Alodia, Sudan]; its source is from springs and its increase is from rains that come in the summer, so it spreads over the face of the earth until it covers all the lands. Then its decrease begins in a month of the Coptic months called: 'Babah', which is Tishrin Al-Awwal (October), so people begin cultivation and sowing crops because the land of Egypt does not receive rain except for light rain, except for what is on the coasts. The non-Arabs of Egypt are all Copts; those in the Sa'id (Upper Egypt) are called Al-Maris, and those in the lower land are called Al-Bima. The Road to Mecca from Egypt: Whoever wants the Hajj from Egypt and exits from Egypt to Mecca, the first stop is called Jubb Umayrah, where the pilgrims gather on the day of their departure. Then a stop called Al-Qarqarah in a desert with no water. Then a stop called: Ajrud [Agarud, Egypt], which has an ancient well with a deep rope and brackish water. Then to the Bridge of Al-Qulzum «1». Whoever wants to enter the city of Al-Qulzum [Suez, Egypt], which is a great city on the seacoast containing merchants who prepare provisions from Egypt to the Hijaz and to Yemen, and it has the anchorage for ships, and its people are a mixture of people, its merchants are people of wealth. From Al-Qulzum, people descend into a wilderness and desert for six stages to Ayla, and they provision water for these six stages. The city of Ayla [Aqaba, Jordan] is majestic on the coast of the Salt Sea, and in it gather the pilgrims of Syria, the pilgrims of Egypt...

...and the Maghreb. It has many trades and its people are a mixture of people. In it are people who mention they are clients (Mawali) of Uthman ibn Affan. In it is a Hibara cloak said to be the cloak of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; it is said he gifted it to Ru'bah ibn Yuhannah when he came to Tabuk. From Ayla «1» to Sharaf Al-Ba'l. From Sharaf Al-Ba'l to Madyan [Al-Bad', Saudi Arabia] «2», which is an ancient, populated city with many springs, flowing fresh rivers, gardens, orchards, and palm trees, and its people are a mixture of people. Whoever wants to leave from there to Mecca takes the route on the coast of the Salt Sea to a place called: Aynuna [Sharma, Saudi Arabia] «3», in which there is habitation and palm trees, and it has mines where people seek gold. Then to Al-Awnid «4», which is like it. Then to Al-Sala. Then to Al-Nabk [Al Nabk, Saudi Arabia] «5». Then to Al-Qusaybah «6». Then to Al-Bahrah. Then to Al-Mughithah, which is moist. Then to Zuba «7». Then to Al-Wajh [Al Wajh, Saudi Arabia]. Then to Mankhus, and in Mankhus are divers who extract pearls. Then to Al-Hawra [Umm Lajj, Saudi Arabia] «8». Then to Al-Jar [near Yanbu, Saudi Arabia]. Then to Al-Juhfa [Rabigh, Saudi Arabia] «9». Then to Qudayd «10». Then to Usfan. Then to Batn Marr [Wadi Fatima, Saudi Arabia].

Whoever wants to travel on the road to the City of the Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace [Medina], takes from Madyan to a stop called: Aghra. Then to Qalis «1». Then to Shaghb [Sharma, Saudi Arabia]. Then to Bada [Bada, Saudi Arabia]. Then to Al-Suqya. Then to Dhu Al-Marwah. Then to Dhu Jashb. Then to Al-Madinah. These are the stops from Egypt to Mecca and Medina. The Maghreb: As for whoever wants to travel from Egypt to Barqa and the farthest Maghreb «2», he proceeds from Al-Fustat [Old Cairo] on the western side of the Nile until he comes to Tarnut [Kom Terenuthis]. Then he proceeds to a stop known as Al-Muna, whose people have deserted it. Then to the Great Monastery known as Bu Mina [Abu Mena, Egypt], and in it is the described church, wondrous in construction with much marble. Then to the stop known as Dhat Al-Hammam, and in it is a congregational mosque, and it is part of the administration of the Kura of Alexandria. Then he proceeds into stops belonging to Banu Mudlij in the wilderness, some of which are on the coast and some near the coast. Among them: The stop known as Al-Tahunah, the stop known as Al-Kana'is, and the stop known as Jubb Al-Awsaj. Then he proceeds into the administration of Lubyah [Libya], which is a Kura that functions like the Kuras of Alexandria. Among them: A stop known as Manzil Ma'n, then the stop known as Qasr Al-Shammas, then Kharbat Al-Qawm, then Al-Ramadah, which is the first of the Berber stops inhabited by a people from Mazata and others from the ancient non-Arabs, and in it are a people from the Arabs from Bali, Juhaynah, Banu Mudlij, and mixtures. Then he proceeds to Aqabah [Solum, Egypt], which is on the coast of the Salt Sea, difficult to traverse, rugged, rough, and fearful. If he ascends it, he comes to a stop known as Al-Qasr Al-Abyad. Then the Caves of Raqim. Then the Castles of the Romans (Qusur Al-Rum). Then Jubb Al-Raml. These are the dwellings of the Berbers from Masalah ibn Lawata and mixtures of people. Then he proceeds to Wadi Mukhayl [Mukhayli, Libya], which is a stop like a city having a congregational mosque, water cisterns, established markets, and a fortified fortress, and in it are mixtures of people, most of them Berbers from Masalah, Zunarah, Mas'ubah, Marawah, and Fatitah. From Wadi Mukhayl to the city of Barqa is three stages in the dwellings of the Berbers from Marawah, Mufratah, Mas'ubah, Zakudah, and others from the clans of Lawata.

Barqa: The city of Barqa [Al Marj, Libya] «1» is in a wide meadow with red soil, intensely red. It is a city with a wall, iron gates, and a trench; Al-Mutawakkil ala Allah ordered the building of the wall. The drinking water of its people is rainwater that comes from the mountain in valleys to great cisterns which the Caliphs and Emirs made for the drinking of the people of the city of Barqa. Around the city are suburbs belonging to it inhabited by the soldiers and non-soldiers. In the houses of the city and the suburbs are mixtures of people, and most of those in it are soldiers of old who now have children and descendants. Between the city of Barqa and the coast of the Salt Sea is six miles. On the seacoast is a city called Ajiyah having markets, guard posts, a congregational mosque, gardens, farms, and many fruits. And another coast called Tulmaythah [Tolmeita, Libya] where ships anchor at certain times. Barqa has two mountains; one is called the Eastern, in which are a people of Arabs from Al-Azd, Lakhm, Judham, Sadaf, and others from the people of Yemen. The other is called the Western, in which are a people from Ghassan and a people from Judham, Al-Azd, Najib, and others from the clans of the Arabs. And villages of Berber clans from Lawata, from Zakudah, Mufratah, and Zunarah. In these two mountains are flowing springs, trees, fruits, fortresses, and ancient wells of the Romans. Barqa has many regions inhabited by these clans of Berbers. Among its cities is Berniq [Benghazi, Libya] «2», which is a city on the coast of the Salt Sea and has a harbor wondrous in its arrangement and quality, in which ships pass. Its people are a people from the descendants of the ancient Romans who were its inhabitants in the past, and a people from the Berbers from Tahlalah, Suwah, Masusah, Maghaghah, Wahilah, and Judanah. Berniq is two stages from the city of Barqa and has regions attributed to it. And the city of Ajdabiya [Ajdabiya, Libya], which is a city with a fortress, and in it is a congregational mosque and established markets; from Berniq to it is two stages. From Barqa to it is four stages. Its people are a people from the Berbers from Zunarah, Wahilah, Masusah, Suwah, Tahlalah, and others, and Judanah, and they are the dominant ones over it. It has regions and a coast on the Salt Sea at a distance of six miles from the city where ships anchor. It is the last of the dwellings of Lawata among the cities.

The clans of Lawata say that they are from the children of Lawata ibn Barr ibn Qays Aylan. Some of them say they are a people from Lakhm whose first ones were from the people of Syria, then they were transferred to these lands. And some of them say they are from the Romans. Sirte: From the city of Ajdabiya to the city of Sirte [Sirte, Libya] «1» on the coast of the Salt Sea is five stages. One stage of it is from the dwellings of Lawata, and among them are a people from Mazata and they are the dominant ones over it. Among them [the stages]: Al-Faruj, Qasr Al-Atash, Al-Yahudiyyah, Qasr Al-Abbadi, and the city of Sirte. The people of these stops and the people of the city of Sirte are Mandasah, Mahnaha, Fantas, and others. The last of their stops is at two stages from the city of Sirte at a place called Tawurgha [Tawergha, Libya], which is the last border of Barqa. Mazata are all Ibadis «2», although they do not understand jurisprudence and have no religion. The land tax of Barqa is an established canon; Al-Rashid had sent a client (Mawla) of his called Bashar, so he distributed the land tax at twenty-four thousand Dinars on every estate, a known amount other than the tithes, charities, and poll taxes (Jawali). The amount of the tithes, charities, and poll taxes is fifteen thousand Dinars; it may increase and may decrease. The tithes are for the places that have no olive trees, no trees, and no hospitable villages. Barqa has an administration called: Awjila [Awjila, Libya], which is in a desert westward; whoever wants to go out to it turns towards the Qibla (south), then comes to two cities, one called Jalu [Jalu, Libya] and the other Waddan [Waddan, Libya]. They possess palm trees, dates, and Qasb (dry dates) than which nothing is better. The land of Waddan is the more pleasing of the two.

Waddan: Among the administrations of Barqa that were added to it is Waddan «1», which is a land reached from a desert and it is among what is added to the administration of Sirte. From the city of Sirte to it, towards the Qibla, is five stages. In it are Muslim people who claim they are Arabs from Yemen, and most of them are from Mazata and they are the dominant ones over it. Most of what is carried from it is dates, for in it are varieties of dates. A man from its people governs it, and it has no land tax. Zuwayla: Behind that is the land of Zuwayla [Zawila, Libya] «2» towards the Qibla. They are Muslim people, all Ibadis; they perform Hajj to the Sacred House. Most of them are narrators [of traditions]. They export black slaves from the Miriyyin, Zaghawiyyin, Marwiyyin, and others from the races of the Sudan (Blacks) due to their proximity to them, and they capture them. It reached me that the kings of the Sudan sell the Sudan (people) without anything [in return] and without war. From Zuwayla come the Zuwayli hides. It is a land of palm trees and cultivation of durra and others. In it are mixtures from the people of Khurasan, from Basra, and Kufa. Behind Zuwayla at fifteen stages is a city called: 'Kawar' [Kaouar, Niger]. In it are a people of Muslims from various generations, most of them Berbers who bring the Sudan. Between Zuwayla and the city of Kawar, and what follows Zuwayla towards the road of Awjila «3» and Ajdabiya «4», are a people called: Lamta, who are the most similar thing to the Berbers. They are the owners of the white Lamti shields.

Fezzan: A race known as Fezzan «1» [Fezzan, Libya], mixtures of people having a leader who is obeyed among them. It is a wide land and a great city. Between them and Mazata is war, always igniting. Barqa is called Antabulus; this is its ancient name. Amr ibn Al-Aas conquered it in the year twenty-three by treaty. From the last administration of Barqa from the place called: Tawurgha to Tripoli is six stages. The dwellings of Mazata end at Tawurgha and one enters the dwellings of Hawara. The first of that is Wardasah, then Labdah [Leptis Magna, Libya], which is a fortress like a city on the seacoast. Hawara claim that they are from the ancient Berbers and that Mazata and Lawata were from them, but were cut off from them, left their dwellings, and went to the land of Barqa and others. Hawara claim they are a people from Yemen who became ignorant of their lineages. The clans of Hawara relate to each other as the Arabs relate to each other; among them are Banu Allah-an, Malilah, and Warastafah. The clans of Allah-an are Banu Darsa, Banu Marzban, Banu Warfallah, and Banu Masratah. The dwellings of Hawara are from the end of the administration of Sirte to Tripoli. Tripoli: Tripoli «2» [Tripoli, Libya] is an ancient, majestic city on the seacoast, populated and inhabited. Its people are mixtures of people. Amr ibn Al-Aas conquered it in the year twenty-three in the Caliphate of Omar ibn Al-Khattab, and it was the last thing conquered in the Maghreb in the Caliphate of Omar. From Tripoli to the land of Nafusa «3» [Nafusa Mountains, Libya], who are a people of non-Arab tongues, all Ibadis having a leader...

...called: Ilyas, they do not depart from his command. Their dwellings are in the mountains of Tripoli in estates, villages, farms, and many settlements. They do not pay land tax to a Sultan nor do they give obedience except to a leader of theirs in Tahert «1», who is the leader of the Ibadis called Abd Al-Wahhab ibn Abd Al-Rahman ibn Rustam, a Persian «2». The dwellings of Nafusa are connected from the border of Tripoli adjoining the Qibla to near Kairouan, and they have many tribes and diverse clans. From Tripoli on the Great Highway to a city called: Gabes «3» [Gabes, Tunisia]—great, on the Salt Sea, populated, with many trees, fruits, and flowing springs; its people are mixtures of Arabs, non-Arabs, and Berbers, and in it is a governor on behalf of Ibn Al-Aghlab, the ruler of Ifriqiya—is five populated stages inhabited by a people of Berbers from Zenata, Lawata, and the ancient Africans. The first of them is Wablah, the first stage from Tripoli. Then Sabrah [Sabratha, Libya], which is a stop with ancient stone idols. Then the Palace of Banu Habban. Then Bam and Qabb. Then Al-Fasilat. Then Gabes. Kairouan: From Gabes to the city of Kairouan «4» [Kairouan, Tunisia] is four stages. The first of them is Ayn Al-Zaytunah, uninhabited. Then...

...Lals, a palace in which there is habitation. Then Ghadir Al-A'rabi. Then Qalshanah «1», which is the place of rest for whoever exits Kairouan or comes to it. Then the Great City of Kairouan, which Uqba ibn Nafi Al-Fihri «2» laid out in the year sixty during the Caliphate of Muawiyah. Uqba was the one who conquered most of the Maghreb, although the first to enter the land of Ifriqiya and conquer it was Abdullah ibn Sa'd ibn Abi Sarh during the Caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan in the year thirty-six. Kairouan is a city that had a wall of brick and clay, so Ziyadat Allah ibn Ibrahim ibn Al-Aghlab demolished it when Imran ibn Mujalid, Abd Al-Salam ibn Al-Mufarrij, and Mansur Al-Tunbudhi revolted against him, for they revolted against him in Kairouan, and they were from the old soldiers who had come with Ibn Al-Ash'ath. Their drinking water is from rain; when it is winter and rains and floods occur, the rainwater enters from the valleys into great cisterns called Al-Mu'ajil. From them, the water carriers drink. They have a valley called Wadi Al-Sarawil south of the city in which salty water comes because it is in salt flats; people use it for what they need. The dwellings of Banu Al-Aghlab are at two miles from the city of Kairouan in palaces upon which several walls have been built. They remained their dwellings until Ibrahim ibn Ahmed moved from them and settled in a place called: Al-Raqqadah «3» [Raqqada, Tunisia] at eight miles from the city of Kairouan, and he built a palace there.

In the city of Kairouan are mixtures from Quraysh and from all the clans of Arabs from Mudar, Rabi'a, and Qahtan. In it are varieties of non-Arabs from the people of Khurasan and those who arrived with the governors of Banu Hashim from the soldiers. In it are non-Arabs from the non-Arabs of the country, the Berbers, the Romans, and the likes of that. From Kairouan to Sousse «1» [Sousse, Tunisia], which is on the coast of the Salt Sea, is one stage. In it is an arsenal (Dar Sina'ah) where ships are made, and the people of Sousse are mixtures of people. From Kairouan to the place called Al-Jazirah is one stage; it is the Island of Abu Sharik [Cape Bon, Tunisia], extending into the sea, surrounded by sea water, with much trade. In it are a people from the clan of Omar ibn Al-Khattab and all clans of Arabs and non-Arabs. It has several cities, not large, in which people are dispersed. Its governor resides in a city called Al-Bawasah near Iqlibiyah [Kelibia, Tunisia] «2», from which one sails to Sicily «3» [Sicily, Italy]. From Kairouan to the city of Safutra is two light stages; it is a large city in which are a people from Quraysh, Quda'a, and others. From Kairouan to the city of Tunis «4» [Tunis, Tunisia], which is on the seacoast and has an arsenal. It is a great city; from it was Hammad Al-Barbari, the client of Harun Al-Rashid, who is the governor of Yemen. Tunis had a wall of brick and clay, and its wall adjoining the sea was of stone. Its people rebelled against Ziyadat Allah ibn Ibrahim ibn Al-Aghlab, and among them were Mansur Al-Tunbudhi, Husayn Al-Tujibi, and Al-Qari' Al-Balawi. He fought them, and when he prevailed over them, he demolished the wall of the city after killing...

...a great multitude of them. From the coast of Tunis, one crosses to the Island of Al-Andalus, and we have mentioned the Island of Al-Andalus and its conditions when we mentioned Tahert. From Kairouan to the city of Baja [Beja, Tunisia] «1» is three stages. The city of Baja is a large city with an ancient stone wall. In it are a people from the old soldiers of Banu Hashim and a people of non-Arabs. Adjacent to the city of Baja are a people of Berbers said to be Wazdajah, resistant, not paying obedience to Ibn Al-Aghlab. From Kairouan to the city of Al-Arbus [Laribus, Tunisia] «2» is two stages; it is a large, populated city with mixtures of people. From Kairouan to a city called Majanah [Majanat al-Tib] is four stages. In this city are mines of silver, kohl (antimony), iron, litharge, and lead amidst mountains and ravines. Its people are a people called Al-Sanajirah; it is said their first ones were from Sinjar from the dwellings of Rabi'a, and they are soldiers for the Sultan. In it are varieties of non-Arabs from the Berbers and others. From Kairouan towards the Qibla is the land of Qammuda [Kammouda, Tunisia], which is a wide land containing cities and fortresses. The city where the governor resides at this time is famous. The Great Ancient City, which is called Sbeitla [Sbeitla, Tunisia], is the one conquered in the days of Uthman ibn Affan; Abdullah ibn Omar ibn Al-Khattab and Abdullah ibn Al-Zubayr besieged it, and the Emir of the army was Abdullah ibn Sa'd ibn Abi Sarh in the year thirty-seven. From Qammuda to the city of Gafsa [Gafsa, Tunisia], which is a fortified city with a stone wall. In it are water springs inside the city, and it is paved with flagstones. Around it is much habitation and described fruits. From Gafsa to the cities of Qastiliya «3», which are four cities in a wide land possessing palm trees...

...and olives. The Great City is called Tozeur [Tozeur, Tunisia] «1», and the governors reside in it. The second is called Al-Hamma. The third is Taqiyus «2». The fourth is Nafta [Nefta, Tunisia] «3». Around these cities are four salt flats (Sabkha). The people of these cities are non-Arab people from the ancient Romans, the Africans, and the Berbers. From the cities of Qastiliya to the cities of Nafzawa [Nefzaoua, Tunisia] «4» is three stages. Nafzawa is several cities; the Great City where the governors reside is called Bashrah. In it are a people from the ancient Africans and the Berbers. The sands surround the cities that are towards the Qibla. Towards the Qibla from Kairouan is a land called Al-Sahel (The Coast)—not a seacoast—very black from olives, trees, and vineyards. It consists of many connected villages. This land has two cities, one called Sah and the other Qabishah. From the land of Al-Sahel to a city called Asfaqus [Sfax, Tunisia] «5» is two stages from Sah and Qabishah. It is on the seacoast; the Salt Sea strikes its wall. It is the last of the Al-Sahel land. From Asfaqus to a place called Binzart [Bizerte, Tunisia] «6» is a journey of eight days. In all the stages are fortresses close to each other where worshippers and those stationed in Ribat stay.

From Kairouan to the land of Al-Zab is ten stages. The Great City of Al-Zab is Tubna [Tobna, Algeria] «1», which the governors inhabit. In it are mixtures of Quraysh, Arabs, soldiers, non-Arabs, Africans, Romans, and Berbers. Al-Zab is a wide land. In it is an ancient city called: Baghaya [Baghai, Algeria] «2»; in it are tribes from the soldiers, non-Arabs from the people of Khurasan, and non-Arabs from the non-Arabs of the country from the remnants of the Romans. Around it are a people of Berbers from Hawara in a majestic mountain called: Auras [Aures Mountains, Algeria] «3», upon which snow falls. And a city called: Tijis from the administration of Baghaya; around it are non-Arab Berber people called: Nafzah. And a great, majestic city called: Mila [Mila, Algeria], populated, fortified, never governed by a governor. It has a fortress within a fortress containing a man from Banu Sulaym called: Musa ibn Al-Abbas ibn Abd Al-Samad on behalf of Ibn Al-Aghlab. The coasts of the sea are near this city. It has a port called: Jijel [Jijel, Algeria], a port called Qal'at Khattab, a port called Iskidah [Skikda, Algeria], a port called Malr, and a port called Marsa Danhajah. All this land is populated, having many trees and fruits, and they are in mountains and springs. And a city called: Setif [Setif, Algeria] «4»; in it are a people from Banu Asad ibn Khuzaymah, workers on behalf of Ibn Al-Aghlab. And a city called Balzamah [Belezma, Algeria]; its people are a people from Banu Tamim and clients of Banu Tamim, and they have rebelled against Ibn Al-Aghlab at this time. And a city called Niqawus [Ngaous, Algeria], with much population and fruit; in it are a people from the soldiers, and around it are Berbers from Miknasah, a clan of Zenata, and around them are a people called Awriyah. Tubna is the Great City of Al-Zab, and it is in the middle of Al-Zab, and the governors reside in it.

And a city called Maqra [Magra, Algeria] having many fortresses. The Great City Maqra's people are a people from Banu Dabbah, and in it are a people of non-Arabs, and around it are a people of Berbers called Banu Zandaj, a people called Kuzbarah, and a people called Sarasah. From it to fortresses called Barhalas, Talmah, and Habrur; in them are a people from Banu Tamim from Banu Sa'd called Banu Al-Samsamah who rebelled against Ibn Al-Aghlab, and Ibn Al-Aghlab defeated some of them and imprisoned them. And the city of Ahah, which is on the mountain; its people rebelled against Ibn Al-Aghlab, and those who opposed him were a people from Hawara called Banu Sa'man, Banu Warjil, and others. And the city of Arba [Larbaa, Algeria] «1», which is the last of the cities of Al-Zab towards the Maghreb at the end of the administration of Banu Al-Aghlab, and the Musawwadah (Abbasids) did not pass beyond it. If one going out exits the administration of Al-Zab heading west, he comes to a people called Banu Barzal, and they are a branch of Banu Dammar from Zenata, and they are all Shurat (Kharijites). We have mentioned the conquest of Ifriqiya and its news in a book we devoted to it. From this place is the land which Al-Hassan ibn Sulayman ibn Sulayman ibn Al-Husayn ibn Ali ibn Al-Husayn ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, took over. The first of the cities in his hand is a city called Haz; its inhabitants are a people of the ancient Berbers called Banu Barniyan from Zenata also. Then cities, some of whose inhabitants are Sanhaja and Zawawah, known as Al-Baranis; they are people of habitation, agriculture, and livestock. The land is attributed to Haz. Between it and the administration of Adnah «2» is a journey of three days. Then to a people called Banu Dammar from Zenata in a wide land, and they are all Shurat having a leader from them called Musadif ibn Jartil in a land of agriculture and livestock; between him and Haz is one stage. From it to a fortress called Fortress of Ibn Karram, and its people are not Shurat, but they are Jama'iyyah (Sunni/Community); their land is a land of agriculture. Then he proceeds to a land called Matijah [Mitidja, Algeria], in which men from the children of Al-Hassan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, dominate, called Banu Muhammad ibn Ja'far. It is a wide land containing several cities and fortresses, and it is a land of agriculture and habitation. Between this land and the Fortress of Musadif ibn Jartil is a journey of three days towards...

...the sea. Then the city of Madkarah, in which are the children of Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him. And the city of Al-Khadra «1». Connected to this are many cities, fortresses, villages, and farms. The children of Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, dominate this land. Every man of them resides fortified in a city and region, and their number is many so that the land is known by them and attributed to them. The last of the cities in their hands is the city close to the seacoast called Suq Ibrahim. It is the famous city in which is a man called Isa ibn Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan. Then from this to Tahert [Tiaret, Algeria]. The Great City, the city of Tahert, is majestic in value, great in status, called 'Iraq of the Maghreb'. It has mixtures of people. A people of Persians called Banu Muhammad ibn Aflah ibn Abd Al-Wahhab ibn Abd Al-Rahman ibn Rustam Al-Farisi dominate it. Abd Al-Rahman ibn Rustam used to govern Ifriqiya, and his children went to Tahert and became Ibadis and the head of the Ibadis; they are the leaders of the Ibadis of the Maghreb. Connected to the city of Tahert is a great land attributed to Tahert under the obedience of Muhammad ibn Aflah ibn Abd Al-Wahhab ibn Abd Al-Rahman ibn Rustam. The fortress on the coast of the Red Sea [Mediterranean] where the ships of Tahert anchor is called Marsa Farrukh. The Island of Al-Andalus and its Cities: Whoever wants the Island of Al-Andalus [Spain/Portugal] «2» proceeds from Kairouan to Tunis as we mentioned, which is on the coast of the Salt Sea, then rides the Salt Sea sailing in it for a journey of ten days along the coast «3», not venturing deep, until he aligns with the Island of Al-Andalus from a place called Tenes [Tenes, Algeria] «4». Between it and Tahert is a journey of four...

...days. Or he proceeds to Tahert, arrives at the Island (Island of Al-Andalus), crosses the deep in a day and a night until he comes to the land of Tudmir [Murcia region, Spain] «1», which is a wide, populated land having two cities, one called Al-Askar and the other Lorca [Lorca, Spain]; in each one is a pulpit (Minbar). Then he exits from it to the city which the dominator from Banu Umayyad inhabits, which is a city called Cordoba [Cordoba, Spain] «2». He travels six days from this place in connected villages, settlements, meadows, valleys, rivers, springs, and farms. Before he comes to the city of Cordoba from Tudmir, he comes to a city called Ilbirah [Elvira/Granada, Spain] «3», settled by those who had come to the country from the soldiers of Damascus from Mudar, and most of them are Qays and mixed clans of Arabs.
