Between it and Cordoba is a journey of two days. West of it is a city called Rayya [Malaga region, Spain] «4», settled by the soldiers of Jordan, and they are all Yemenis from various clans. West of Rayya «5» is a city called Shadunah [Medina Sidonia, Spain] «6», settled by the soldiers of Homs, most of whom are Yemenis, and among them are a small number from Nizar. West of Shadunah is a city called Al-Jazirah [Algeciras, Spain], settled by Berbers and a few mixtures of Arabs. West of the city called Al-Jazirah is a city called Ishbiliyah [Seville, Spain] «7» on a great river.

It is the river of Cordoba. The Majus [Vikings], who are called Al-Rus, entered it in the year two hundred and twenty-nine, so they pillaged, looted, burned, and killed. West of Seville is a city called Al-Baslah [Niebla, Spain] «1», settled by the Arabs when they first entered the country with Tariq, the client of Musa ibn Nusayr Al-Lakhmi. West of it is a city called Baja [Beja, Portugal], settled by Arabs also with Tariq. West of it on the Surrounding Salt Sea [Atlantic] is a city called Al-Ushbunah [Lisbon, Portugal] «2». West of it on the sea also is a city called Ahsunabah [Faro/Algarve, Portugal], and it is Al-Andalus in the west on the sea that takes to the Sea of the Khazars. Adjoining the east from this city is [a city] called Maridah [Merida, Spain] «3» on a great river; between it and Cordoba is four days. It is west of Cordoba and aligns with the land of Polytheism (Shirk) and a race of them called the Jalaliqah (Galicians), and it is in the Island. Then he exits from Cordoba going east to a city called Jayyan [Jaen, Spain], and in it are those who were from the soldiers of Qinnasrin and Al-Awasim, and they are mixtures of Arabs from Ma'add and Yemen. From Jayyan to the north (left) is to the city of Tulaytulah [Toledo, Spain] «4», which is an impregnable, majestic city; there is no city in the Island more impregnable than it. Its people oppose Banu Umayya. They are mixtures of Arabs, Berbers, and clients (Mawali). It has a great river called Duwayr [Tagus? Text says Duwayr but geography suggests Tagus at Toledo]. From Toledo, for one taking east, is to a city called Wadi Al-Hijarah [Guadalajara, Spain]. A man from the Berbers called Masl ibn Faraj Al-Sanhaji was over it, governing it and calling for Banu Umayya. Then his children and offspring came...

...after him to this end in the country. Then from it going east to the city of Saraqustah [Zaragoza, Spain] «1», which is one of the greatest cities of the Frontier (Thughr) of Al-Andalus on a river called Abrah [Ebro]. To the north (left) of it is a city called Nutilah [Tudela, Spain] aligned with the land of Polytheism (Shirk) who are called the Baskins [Basques]. To the north (left) of this city is a city called Washqah [Huesca, Spain], which borders the Franks of a race called the Jasiqs [Gascons]. From Zaragoza to the Qibla (south) is a city called Turtushah [Tortosa, Spain] «2», which is the last Frontier of Al-Andalus in the east bordering the Franks; it is on this river descending from Zaragoza. From Tortosa, for one taking west, is to a land called Balansiyah [Valencia, Spain] «3», which is a wide, majestic land settled by Berber tribes. They did not give Banu Umayya obedience. They have a great river in a land called Al-Shaqr [Jucar]. From it to the land of Tudmir, the first land. This is the Island of Al-Andalus and its cities. We returned to the mention of Tahert in the main road of the Maghreb: From the city of Tahert «4» and what the administration of Ibn Aflah Al-Rustami encompasses to the kingdom of a man from Hawara called Ibn Masalah the Ibadi, except that he is an opponent of Ibn Aflah and fights him. His city which he inhabits is called Al-Jabal. From it to a city called Yalal [Hillil, Algeria] near the Salt Sea is a journey of half a day; it has farms, villages, settlements, crops, and trees. Then from the kingdom of Ibn Masalah Al-Hawari to...

...a kingdom belonging to Banu Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan also, other than the kingdom we mentioned, which is the city of Madkarah. Their residence is in the Great City called Ghutlas. The people of this kingdom are a people from the clans of Berbers from all their tribes, and most of them are a people called Banu Matmatah, and they are many clans. They have in their kingdom a great city called Ayzaraj where some of them are. The people of this city are Matmatah. And a city also owned by a man from them called Ubayd Allah, called the Beautiful City (Al-Madinah Al-Hasanah) if interpreted from the tongue of the Berbers to Arabic. Then to the Great City famous in the West called Tlemcen [Tlemcen, Algeria] «1». It has a stone wall and behind it another stone wall. In it is a great multitude, palaces, and constructed houses. A man from them called Muhammad ibn Al-Qasim ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman resides in it. Around this city are a people of Berbers called Miknasah and Sarasah. Then to the city called the City of the Alawites; it was in the hands of the Alawites from the children of Muhammad ibn Sulayman, then they left it, so a man from the sons of the kings of Zenata called Ali ibn Hamid ibn Marhum Al-Zanati inhabited it. Then from it to a city called Namaltah, in which is Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman. The last of the kingdom of Banu Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan is the city of Falus, which is a great city whose people are Berber clans from Matmatah, Tarjah, Jazulah, Sanhaja, Anjafah, and Anharah. Then after the kingdom of Banu Muhammad ibn Sulayman is the kingdom of a man called Salih ibn Sa'id who claims he is from Himyar, while the people of the country claim he is from the people of the country, a Nafzi. The name of his Great City which he inhabits is Bakur [Al Hoceima area, Morocco], and it is on the Salt Sea. From this city crossed a man from the children of Hisham ibn Abd Al-Malik ibn Marwan and those with him from the family of Marwan to the Island of Al-Andalus when they fled from Banu Abbas. The kingdom of Salih ibn Sa'id Al-Himyari is a journey of ten days in settlements, fortresses, villages, houses, agriculture, livestock, and fertility. The last of his kingdom is a city called Marhanah on a mountain, beneath which are rivers, valleys, and settlements. Then one proceeds...

...from it to the kingdom of Banu Idris ibn Idris ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Hassan ibn Al-Hassan ibn Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon them. The first border of their kingdom is a land called Ghamira [Ghomara, Morocco], in which is a man called Ubayd Allah ibn Omar ibn Idris. Then to a land called Malhas belonging to Khanah, at which the pilgrims of Sus Al-Aqsa and Tangier [Tangier, Morocco] «1» gather; Ali ibn Idris owns it. Then the Fortress of Sadinah, which is a great land containing Muhammad ibn Omar ibn Idris. Then from the Fortress of Sadinah to the Great River called Lamhar; in it are fortresses, settlements, and a wide land governed by a man from the children of Dawud ibn Idris ibn Idris. And to a river called Sebu [Sebou River, Morocco], governed by Hamza ibn Dawud ibn Idris ibn Idris. Then one enters the Great City called the City of Ifriqiya—on the Great River called Qas [Fez River]—in it is Yahya ibn Yahya ibn Idris ibn Idris ibn Idris. It is a majestic city with much habitation and houses. On the western side of the river Qas—which is a river said to be greater than all rivers of the earth, upon which are three thousand mills grinding—is the city called City of the People of Andalus [Fez, Morocco]. Dawud ibn Idris inhabits it. Each one of Yahya ibn Yahya and Dawud ibn Idris opposes his companion, repelling him and fighting him. On the edge of Qas is a city called [...] «2» inhabited by Barqasanah, a people of the ancient Berbers. On the river Qas are majestic settlements, villages, estates, and farms on its two banks. Its water comes from springs from the south (Qibla), except they say it does not increase or decrease. It overflows into the river called Sebu, which we have mentioned, and Sebu empties into the Salt Sea. The kingdom of Banu Idris is wide and large. Abu Ma'bad Abd Al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Maymun ibn Abd Al-Wahhab ibn Abd Al-Rahman ibn Rustam Al-Taharti told me, saying: Tahert is a large, inhabited city between mountains and valleys having no open space. Between it and the Salt Sea is a journey of three stages in level land, and in some of it are salt flats and a river called Wadi Shalif [Chelif River, Algeria]. Upon it are villages and habitation; it overflows just as the Nile of Egypt overflows. Safflower, flax, sesame, and other grains are grown on it. It goes to a mountain called Anqiq, then exits to the land of Nafzah «3», then goes to the Salt Sea. The drinking water of the people of the city of Tahert is from rivers and springs, some coming from a desert and some from a mountain in the south (Qibla) called...

...Jazul. The crops of that land have never failed unless wind or hail strikes them. It is a mountain connected to Sus; the people of Sus call it Daran [Atlas Mountains], and in Tahert it is called Jazul, and in Al-Zab it is called Auras. Whoever exits from Tahert traveling the road between the Qibla and the West goes to a city called Uzka, three stages. The dominant ones over it are a clan from Zenata called Banu Masrah; their leader was Abd Al-Rahman ibn Udamut ibn Sinan, and after him his son became leader, so a son of his called Zayd moved to a place called Tharinah and his son is in it. From the city of Uzka, for one traveling west to the land of Zenata, then he proceeds to the city of Sijilmasa [Rissani, Morocco] after traveling seven stages or thereabouts, according to diligence in marching or slowing down. His travel is in villages that are not inhabited, and in some of them is a desert. Sijilmasa: Sijilmasa «1» is a city on a river called Ziz. There is no spring or well in it. Between it and the sea is several stages. The people of Sijilmasa are mixtures, and the dominant ones over it are the Berbers, most of them Sanhaja. Their crop is millet and durra. Their cultivation relies on rains due to the scarcity of water among them; if it does not rain, they have no crops. From the city of Sijilmasa are villages known as Banu Dar'ah. In it is a city, not large, called Tamdult [near Akka, Morocco] «2» belonging to Yahya ibn Idris the Alawite; it has a fortress where Abdullah ibn Idris was. Around it are mines of gold and silver found like plants; it is said the winds blow it about. The dominant ones over them are a people of Berbers called Banu Tarja. Sus Al-Aqsa: From the city called Tamalt «3» to a city called Al-Sus «4», which is Sus...

...Al-Aqsa [Souss, Morocco], settled by Banu Abdullah ibn Idris ibn Idris. Its people are mixtures of Berbers, and the dominant ones over them are Madasah. From Al-Sus to a land called Aghmat [Aghmat, Morocco] «1», which is a fertile land containing pasture and farms in plain and mountain. Its people are a people of Berbers from Sanhaja. From Aghmat to Massa. Massa [Massa, Morocco] is a village on the sea to which trades are carried. In it is the mosque known as the Mosque of Bahlul, and in it is the Ribat on the seacoast. At the Mosque of Bahlul, the sea casts up the sewn vessels which are made in Al-Ubulla [near Basra, Iraq] in which one sails to China. From Sijilmasa, for one traveling heading towards the Qibla (south) wanting the land of the Sudan (Blacks) from all clans of the Sudan, he travels in a wilderness and desert for the amount of fifty stages. Then he meets a people called Anbiyah from Sanhaja in a desert; they have no fixed abode. It is the custom of all of them to veil themselves with their turbans, a sunnah among them, and they do not wear shirts; they only wrap themselves in their garments. Their livelihood is from camels; they have no crops or food. Then he proceeds to a land called Ghust [Aoudaghost, Mauritania], which is an inhabited valley containing houses. In it is a king of theirs who has no religion and no Sharia; he raids the lands of the Sudan, and their kingdoms are many. The Book of Al-Buldan is completed, and praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and may Allah bless Muhammad and his pure family. Written by Ali ibn Abi Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Kindi Al-Anmati, may Allah forgive him and whoever says Amen, and praise be to Allah, sufficient are His bounties, and His blessings be upon Muhammad and his family. Its completion agreed with the morning of Saturday, the twenty-first of Shawwal, year six hundred and seven. Authored by Ahmed ibn Abi Yaqub ibn Wadih Al-Katib.
Addenda. These addenda have been narrated by the notables in their works from Al-Ya'qubi, and were mentioned at the end of the Book of Countries (Kitab al-Buldan) printed in Leiden in 1861 AD.

The Mosques of Basra. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, the author of the Book of Roads and Kingdoms, recounted that there were seven thousand mosques in Basra. The River of Ahwaz. "Sheikh Jamal al-Din Muhammad ibn Ibrahim al-Watwat (al-Kutubi) al-Warraq, who died in the year 718, said in his book (Manahij al-Fikr wa Mabahij al-Ibar) that Ibn Abi Ya'qub mentioned that its water - (the River of Ahwaz (1)) - comes from two valleys. One of them springs from Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran] and flows until it passes the Weir (Shadhurwan) of Tustar [Shushtar, Iran], Askar Mukram [Iran], and Jundishapur [Iran]. It has a bridge over it whose length is five hundred and sixty-three steps, and it is called Al-Masruqan (with Damma on the Meem, un-dotted Sin, and Qaf). The other springs from Hamadhan [Hamadan, Iran] and flows to Susa [Shush, Iran] and is called Al-Hinduwan. Then they both flow to Al-Manadhir al-Kubra, where one pours into the other and they become a single river called Dujayl al-Ahwaz. Then it flows to Ahwaz [Ahvaz, Iran], then passes until it pours into the Sea of Fars [Persian Gulf] at Hisn Mahdi. It dries up in the summer, and the place of its flow becomes a road traveled by caravans. (The people of this region have a special tongue resembling gibberish, though the Persian language predominates among them). Shiraz (2) is the great city of Fars [Iran]. It is a majestic, great city where governors stay. It has such spaciousness that...

...there is no house but that its owner has a garden in it, containing all fruits, aromatic plants, herbs, and everything that is in gardens. Its people drink from springs flowing in rivers coming from mountains upon which snow falls. Nisibis (1). Al-Ya'qubi said: It is a great city with many rivers, gardens, and orchards. It has a great river called Al-Hirmas, over which are ancient Roman stone bridges. Its people are a folk from Rabi'ah from Banu Taghlib. It was conquered by Ghanm ibn Iyad al-Ghanmi (Iyad ibn Ghanm al-Fihri) during the caliphate of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, in the year eighteen. Ibn Wadih al-Ya'qubi said: The second Qinnasrin (2) is Hiyar Bani al-Qa'qa'. Ibn Wadih counted in the district of Aleppo (3): Martahwan (4) and the district of Ma'arrat Misrin. Mopsuestia (Al-Massisah). Ibn Ya'qub said: The city of Mopsuestia (5) was built by Abu Ja'far al-Mansur during his caliphate...

...and before that it was a garrison (1). Al-Ma'mun built Kafarbaya (2), so the river Jayhan (3) became between them. Over the river is a great ancient bridge arched with stone consisting of three arches on an elevation of the ground. Anazarbus (Ayn Zarbah). Ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Among the Syrian Frontiers other than these three cities (Antioch (4), Mopsuestia, and Tarsus) is the city of Ayn Zarbah (5), which is in the environs of Mopsuestia. Malatya. Ibn Abi Ya'qub said: The city of Malatya (6) was ancient, built by Alexander. It is one of the lands of the Romans, famous, bordering Syria. Al-Ya'qubi said: Malatya is the great city. It was ancient, then the Romans destroyed it, so Al-Mansur rebuilt it in the year one hundred and thirty-nine. He made a single wall for it and transferred several Arab tribes to it.

He said: It is on level ground surrounded by the mountains of the Romans. Its water is from springs and valleys from the Euphrates. Al-Mutanabbi lightened it [the name] due to necessity. Ra'ban and Duluk. Ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Ra'ban (1) and Duluk (2) are two districts close to each other. As for Duluk, it is an ancient city with a mention. It was populated and has a high castle of Roman construction built with stones. It had a canal mounted on arches carrying water up to the castle. Around it are beautiful buildings carved in stone, and around it are many waters and orchards with many fruits. It is said that the station of David, peace be upon him, was there, and that from there he prepared the army to Cyrrhus (Qurus) (3), so Uriah ibn Hannan was killed there. The city and the castle have fallen into ruin, and it remains now a village with farmers. Kaysum (4). Ibn Shaddad (5) said: Ibn Abi Ya'qub mentioned it and counted it in Kitab al-Buldan among the Awasim (protecting strongholds).

Manbij. Ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Manbij (1) is an ancient city conquered by peace treaty, concluded by Amr ibn al-Aas on behalf of Abu Ubaydah ibn al-Jarrah. It is on the Great Euphrates. Adana. Ahmad the Scribe (Al-Ya'qubi) said: Adana was built by Al-Rashid, who is also the one who built Tarsus. Bab Iskandarunah. Ahmad the Scribe (Al-Ya'qubi) said: Bab Iskandarunah (2) is a city on the sea coast near Antioch, built by Ahmad ibn Abi Dawud (Du'ad) al-Iyad during the caliphate of Al-Wathiq. Tiflis. Tiflis (3) is a city in Armenia. Between it and Qaliqala (4) is thirty farsakhs. From Qaliqala begin the great rivers. The first is the Euphrates, which has been mentioned; it takes from Qaliqala at two farsakhs, then cuts westward to Dabil, then to Warthan, then pours into the Sea of the Khazars (Caspian Sea). The second great one (The Kura) exits from the city of Qaliqala, then cuts through the city of Tiflis eastward to the city of Bardha'a and its land, then approaches the Sea of the Khazars where it meets the Aras (Al-Rass) and they become a single river.

It is said that behind the Aras are three hundred ruined cities, which are the ones Allah Almighty mentioned: "And the Companions of the Rass." Hanzalah ibn Safwan was sent to them, but they killed him, so they were destroyed. Other things have been said about the Companions of the Rass. Armenia is divided into three sections. The first section: The city of Dabil, the city of Qaliqala, the city of Khilat, the city of Shamshat, and the city of Al-Sawad. The second part: The city of Bardha'a, the city of Baylaqan, the city of Qabala (Qibla), and the city of Al-Bab wa al-Abwab (Derbent). The third: The city of Jurzan (Kharzan), the city of Tiflis, and the city known by the Mosque of Dhu al-Qarnayn. Armenia was conquered during the caliphate of Uthman; it was conquered by Sulayman (Salman) ibn Rabi'ah al-Bahili in the year twenty-four. Armenia. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Armenia (1) is in three sections. The first section includes Qaliqala, Khilat, Shamshat, and what is between that. The second section includes Jurzan (Khazan), Tiflis, the city of Bab al-Lan, and what is between that. The third section includes Bardha'a, which is the city of Arran, Baylaqan, and Bab al-Abwab. Ahmad ibn Wadih al-Ya'qubi al-Asbahani mentioned that he stayed long in the lands of Armenia, etc... Musk. Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn al-Khalil ibn Sa'id al-Tamimi al-Maqdisi said in his book titled "Jayb al-Arus wa Rayhan al-Nufus": Musk (2) is of many varieties and different genera. The best of it...

...and highest is the Tibetan. It is brought from a place called Dhu Samt, between which and Tibet is a two-month journey. It is brought to Tibet, then carried to Khorasan... He said: Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, the client of the Abbasids, said: A group of scholars of the musk source mentioned to me that its sources in the land of Tibet and elsewhere are known. The importers have built therein a structure resembling a minaret about the length of a bone of an arm. This animal from whose navels musk is formed comes and rubs its navel against that minaret, so the navels fall there. The importers come to it at a time of the year they know and pick that up, permissible for them. When they arrive with it in Tibet, it is tithed... He said: The best musk is that whose deer graze on a grass called (Al-Kadahmas) which grows in Tibet and Kashmir (1) or one of them. Ibn Abi Ya'qub mentioned that the name of this grass is Al-Kandahsa. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: The best musk is the Tibetan, then after the Sogdian musk, and after the Sogdian the Chinese musk. The best Chinese is what is brought from Khanfu (Guangzhou), which is the great city that is the port of China where the ships of Muslim merchants anchor. Then it is carried by sea to the Strait. When it approaches the land of Al-Ubullah, its scent rises, so merchants cannot hide it from the tax collectors. When it exits the ship, its scent improves and the scent of the sea leaves it. Then the Indian musk, which is what arrives at Al-Daybul (Al-Daybuli) then is prepared by sea; it is inferior to the first. After the Indian is the Qanbari musk, which is good musk but inferior to the Tibetan in value, substance, color, and scent. It is brought from a land called Qanbar from China, and it grows (between China and Tibet). Perhaps they deceived with it and attributed it to the Tibetan. He said: Following it in quality is the Tughuzghuz (Tugharghari) musk, which is heavy musk leaning towards blackness. It is brought from the land of the Turks, the Tughuzghuz (Tugharghar). Merchants import it and deceive with it, but it has no substance or color, and is slow to grind, not free from coarseness. Following it in quality...

...is the Qasari musk, brought from a town called Qasar between India and China. He said: It may catch up to the Chinese, but it is inferior to it in value, substance, and scent. He said: And the Jirjiri musk, which is musk resembling the Tibetan and similar to it; it is yellow with a pungent scent. After it is the 'Asmari musk, which is the weakest of all types of musk and the lowest in value; from a pod weighing an ounce, a dirham weight of musk comes out. Then the Mountain musk, which is what is brought from the land of Sindh from the land of Multan (Al-Muliyan). It has many (large) pods and good color, but it has a weak scent. He said: (etc.) what the merchants of Khorasan bought of the Sogdian from Tibet and carried on backs to Khorasan, then it is carried from Khorasan to the horizons. Ambergris. Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Tamimi (1) said: My father told me from his father from Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub that he said: Ambergris (2) is of many types and different varieties, and its sources are varied. It differs in excellence by its sources and substance. Its best type, highest, most superior, best in color, purest in substance, and most expensive is the Shihri Ambergris, which is what the Sea of India casts to the coast of Shihr in the land of Yemen. They claimed that it comes out of the sea in the form of ambergris or a large rock. Al-Tamimi said etc... He said: My father told me from his father from Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, he said: The wind and the intensity of the waves cut it and throw it to the coasts while it is boiling; nothing approaches it due to the intensity of its heat and boiling. When it stays for days and the air hits it, it solidifies, so people gather it from the coasts connected to its sources. He said: Perhaps the great fish called the Whale (Al-Bal/Akbal) comes and swallows some of that floating ambergris while it is boiling. It does not settle in its belly until it dies and floats, and the sea casts it to the coast. Its belly is cut open and what is in it of ambergris is extracted; this is the Fish Ambergris, also called the Swallowed.

He said: Perhaps the sea casts a piece of ambergris, and a black bird resembling a swallow sees it, comes to it, and flutters with its wings. If it approaches it and lands on it, its claws and beak get stuck in it, so it dies and decays, and its beak and claws remain in the ambergris; this is the Beaked Ambergris. He said: After the Shihri Ambergris is the Zanj Ambergris, which is brought from the lands of the Zanj to Aden; it is white ambergris. After it is the Salahit Ambergris, and it varies in excellence. The best Salahit is the blue, greasy, with much oil; it is the one used in Ghawali (perfumes). After the Salahit is the Qaquli Ambergris; it is gray, good for scent (wind), good-looking, light, with slight dryness. It is inferior to the Salahit, not suitable for Ghawali nor for boiling (Ta'liya) and purification except out of necessity. It is suitable for powders and calcined substances. This ambergris is brought from the sea of Qaqula to Aden. After the Qaquli is the Indian Ambergris, brought to the inner coasts of India, then carried to Basra and elsewhere. After it is the Zanj, brought from the coasts of the Zanj; it is similar to the Indian and close to it (thus Al-Tamimi mentioned) in "Jayb al-Arus", for he places the Zanj after the Shihri and mentioned the Zanj also after the Indian. He said: And ambergris brought from India called Karkbalus, attributed to a people from India who import it known as Karkbalus. They bring it near Oman, and ship owners buy it from them. He said: As for the Ambergris, it is inferior to all these types. It is brought from the sea of Andalusia, and merchants carry it to Egypt. It is similar in color to the Shihri Ambergris, and perhaps one is deceived by it... Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: A group of people knowledgeable about ambergris told me that it is in mountains growing on the sea floor, of different colors. Winds and the intense agitation of the sea in severe winters uproot it; therefore, it hardly comes out in the summer. Oud (Aloeswood) (1). Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: It (the Qumari Oud) has the age of mature water. Ibn Abi...

...Ya'qub [said]: After the Qaquli Oud is the Sanfi Oud. It is imported from a land called Sanf in the region of China. Between it and China is a mountain that cannot be traversed. It is the most majestic of Ouds and the most lasting in clothes. Some prefer it over the Qaquli and see that it is better, more fragrant, and safer from burnt smell. Some also ranked it above the Qumari. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Among the Oud is also a variety called Al-Qushur, moist blue. It has a sweeter scent than the Qat'i but is inferior to it in value (and the best Chinese is a type of it called the Qat'i). He said: From the Chinese also are other varieties inferior to these varieties, among them the Mantawi, which is the Mantay; its pieces are large, smooth, black, with no knots. Their scents are not praiseworthy. They are suitable for medicines, powders, and electuaries. From it is a variety known as Al-Jalay, and a variety known as Al-Lawafi (Al-Lawaqi), which is the Luqayni (Al-Luqayni). These are Ouds close in value. Al-Tamimi said: Some people ranked the Chinese Oud differently than the arrangement of Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, saying etc. Indian Spikenard (Sumbul). As for Indian Spikenard, Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Spikenard (1) is of varieties. Its best is the Red Sparrows (Al-Asafir), the threaded (Al-Musallal). The threaded is that which has been cleaned of its down and wiped, containing stripped sparrows. If a person holds it in his palm for an hour then smells it, its scent is like the scent of apples or similar. Then the one following it, which is a type of Sparrows, red with much whiteness, and the mixed (Al-Shamt), better in scent, close to the first. Then the lowest of it, which is fine spikenard and majestic, not among what enters into good perfume. As for its origin, it is a grass growing in the land of India and also in the land of Tibet. It is said that it grows in valleys in India just as crops grow, then it dries, and people come to harvest it...

...and collect it. It is said that the valleys where this spikenard grows have many vipers, and no one comes to them except wearing long thick boots soled with wood or iron. They said: Those vipers have horns containing the deadly poison called Bish (Aconite), and it is said it is from the horns of the vipers. A group of scholars said: It is a plant growing in those valleys, and it is of two types. A type is heath-like (Khalanji), its color leaning towards yellowness, and it is the better of them. Another type leans towards blackness; they know it and avoid it. Perhaps some were ignorant of it and died from touching it, especially if their hand had sweated or was moist. Some Caliphs used to order that someone be entrusted with the ships coming from the land of India to Al-Ubullah and other ports to inspect the spikenard and test it. The Bish would be extracted from it, taken with iron pincers, and no one touched it but that he died instantly. That used to be collected in a container and sometimes thrown into the sea. Cloves. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: Cloves (1) are all one genus. Its best and finest is the dry, desiccated flower, pungent, sharp-tasting, sweet-smelling. From it is the flower and from it is the fruit. The flower of it is what is small and resembles the sticks of the branches of black hellebore in appearance. The fruit of it is what is thick and resembles date pits or olive stones. It is said it is the fruit of large trees resembling the lote tree. Others said (etc.). He said: It is imported from the lands of Sofala of India and its furthest parts. In the places where it is, it has very sharp, radiating scents, so much so that they call the places of cloves the Scent of Paradise due to the sharpness of its scent (etc.). Ghawali (Perfumes). Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Tamimi mentioned in his book titled "Jayb al-Arus" in the chapter...

...of Ghawali many of them. We mention from that what used to be made for Caliphs, Kings, and notables. Among that is a Ghaliya of the Caliphs' Ghawali (from Ahmad Abi Ya'qub): One hundred mithqals of rare Tibetan musk are taken, ground etc... This Ghaliya in which ambergris and musk are equal used to be made for Humayd al-Tusi, and Al-Ma'mun used to like it very much. This Ghaliya used to be made for Umm Ja'far... And they used to make this Ghaliya for Muhammad ibn Sulayman... And they also used to make for Umm Ja'far the Ambergris Ghaliya etc. Recipe for Ramik and another Sukk. Al-Tamimi mentioned from Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub that he made it and it is the best Sukk (1) there is. Ibn Abi Ya'qub said: The recipe for making Ramik (2) is to take good mature gallnuts etc. Ban (Ben Oil) (3). As for its quality (Ban oil) with spices until it becomes high Ban, there is Kufan and Medinan.

As for the Kufan, Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, client of the descendants of Al-Abbas, said: In it the oil is taken etc... As for the Medinan Ban: The people of Medina cook it with good spices etc... Except that this oil is not suitable for Ghawali because it overpowers the scents of ambergris and musk with the scents of spices and their sharpness. Kings do not use it except to oil their hands in winter, and women use it in their perfumes and veils. Apple Water. As for apple water and its distillation from which it is made, Al-Tamimi said from Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub regarding the making of perfumed apple water: You take Levantine apples etc. Pills to Remove Bad Breath. A recipe for another royal pill (to remove bad breath) mentioned by Al-Tamimi in his book (Jayb al-Arus wa Rayhan al-Nufus). He said: He took it from Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, and it is etc. Naming the Christians of Al-Hirah 'Al-Ibad'. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: The Christians of Al-Hirah were named Al-Ibad (The Servants/Worshippers) only because five of them came as a delegation to Khosrow. He said to one of them: What is your name? He said: Abd al-Masih (Servant of the Messiah). He said to the second: What is your name? He said: Abd Yalil. He said to the third: What is your name? He said: Abd Yasu' (Servant of Jesus). He said to the fourth: What is your name? He said: Abdullah (Servant of Allah). He said to the fifth: What is your name? He said: Abd Amr. Khosrow said: You are all 'Ibad (Servants), so they were named Al-Ibad. What Caliphs and Kings Spent. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub, from the descendants of Ja'far ibn Wahb, said: Al-Wathiq distributed in his days wealth in charity, gifts, and acts of righteousness in Baghdad, Samarra, Kufa, Basra, Medina, and Mecca five million dinars. Al-Walid ibn Hamad ibn Abi Dawud (Du'ad) came on his behalf...

...to Baghdad after the fire that occurred in the markets in Baghdad, having with him five hundred thousand dinars. He distributed it among the merchants whose wealth was lost in the fire, so their conditions improved, and they built their markets with gypsum and baked brick and made the doors of their shops iron doors. Ahmad the Scribe said: He (Ahmad ibn Tulun) spent on it (the Mosque) one hundred and twenty thousand dinars. The craftsmen said to him: On what example should the minaret be made? He never fiddled in a council, but he took a roll of paper and began fiddling with it, so some of it came out and some remained in his hand. Those present were amazed. He said: Make the minaret on this example (spiral), so they made it. When the building of the Mosque was completed, Ahmad ibn Tulun saw in his dream as if Allah Almighty had manifested to the Maqsura around the Mosque but did not manifest to the Mosque. He asked the interpreters, and they said: What is around it will be ruined and it will remain standing alone. He said: From where did you get this? They said: From the saying of the Almighty: "And when his Lord manifested to the mountain, He made it crumbled to dust" [Al-A'raf: 143]. And his saying (Prophet), peace be upon him: "If Allah manifests to something, it humbles itself to Him" (1). And it was as they said.

Eulogy of Ibn Tulun. Muhammad (Ahmad) ibn Abi Ya'qub the Scribe narrated, saying: When it was the night of Eid al-Fitr of the year 292 (1), I remembered what the family of Ibn Tulun (2) were in on such a night, of beautiful attire with weapons, colored banners and flags, famous (or month/fame) clothes, abundance of horses, and sounds of trumpets and drums. A thought (a lesson and a thought) overcame me because of that. I slept that night and heard a caller saying: Kingship, possession, and ornamentation have gone... when the Banu Tulun passed away. Ahmad ibn Abi Ya'qub said: If you ask about the majesty of their reign... graze and turn to the pastures of the square. Look at those palaces and what they contained... and frolic in the bloom of that garden. If you take a lesson, in it also is a lesson... informing you how the two eras (night and day) change.

O Harun's killing, you uprooted their origins... and turned the head of their Amir, Shayban, grey. Neither the might of Qays availed them when he came... in a clamorous army, nor Ghassan. And 'Adiyyah the brave hero and Khazraj... were not helped by their brother Adnan. It (the dominion) was driven to the family of Prophecy and Guidance... and torn away from the party of Satan. Similar to this is what Al-Ya'qubi recounted, he said: ... I headed to the door of Hamduna, daughter of Al-Rashid. Daqaq, her client, came out, and in her hand was a fan on which was written on the first face: The vulva is more in need of two penises than the penis is of two vulvas. On the second side of the fan was written: Just as the millstone (1) is more in need of two mules than the mule is of two millstones. Description of Samarkand. Ibn al-Wadih al-Ya'qubi said in describing Samarkand: Samarkand rose so it is said of it... The Adornment of Khorasan, the Paradise of Districts. Are not its towers suspended... where they cannot be discerned by sight? And below its towers are its trenches... deep, no breach can be attempted. As if it, while in the middle of its wall... surrounded by shadows and trees, is a full moon. Its rivers are the Galaxy and the... fortresses are like the shining stars.
